name: Braille Displays vs. Notetakers: Everything You Need to Know
abstract: Learn core concepts of braille devices during this interactive session. Topics cover comparing types of braille devices, demonstrating school and work scenarios, how to work with new users, and learning resources to keep users’ skills sharp.
description:
In this interactive session, audience members will engage with the East Texas Lighthouse Assistive Technology team learning core concepts and applications for braille displays and notetakers. Topics covered in this session will include the differences and similarities between braille displays and notetakers, school and work scenarios best suited for each device, and the timing and approach to introduce these devices to new learners.

Presenters will demonstrate scenarios and tasks which are better suited for braille displays or notetakers. In addition to providing reference materials created by the ETLB Assistive Technology team, attendees will be shown, through live demonstration, the variety of learning resources which are available for users to keep their skills sharp with their current and future braille devices.

name: Benchmarking Accessibility in User Research
abstract: UX researchers employ the System Usability Scale to measure usability, but it doesn't effectively capture data for assistive technology users. Fable’s Accessible Usability Scale fills this gap. Presenters will explore the usability trends uncovered.
description:
How do you know if your website or app is accessible? You can audit it against the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines. You can test with users of assistive technology and people with disabilities. But how do you quantify your accessibility?  

In the world of UX, we have the System Usability Scale to measure experiences. Now, we have a new tool, the Accessible Usability Scale, to measure the experience of assistive technology users. It's a 10-question survey that will give you a numeric score that you can use to compare and evaluate experiences across different digital products, websites and apps. This adapted version of the System Usability Scale better captures the lived experience of assistive technology users in task-oriented research. 
 
With hundreds of AUS results reviewed and synthesized since 2020, Fable researchers have been building a practice of evaluating UX with the AUS as a key tool. This presentation will explore why a new measurement tool was needed to effectively capture assistive technology user experiences, and the usability trends that have been uncovered since its implementation.

name: Rapid Prototyping with Accessibility in Mind
abstract: In this session, you’ll learn the tools and best practices for building accessible rapid prototyping and running usability studies with users who rely on assistive technologies.
description:
User testing with Accessibility in mind is always an afterthought.For a user who relies on assistive technologies to experience a digital product for the first time, accessibility needs to be fully implemented. Feedback from this group of users is often received through a customer support channel or after a formal legal complaint. 
This session aims to showcase a content-first approach to building accessible prototyping that can be evaluated by assistive technology users early in the design process.
This session will go into detail on how testing for accessibility during the conceptualization stage provides a better experience for all users while educating UX professionals about web accessibility guidelines.

name: Ramping Up Your Accessibility Testing: A Beginner's Guide
abstract: How to get started with accessibility testing? The learnings, the mistakes, a tried and tested process and useful tips to improve your testing skills, whether you're an auditor or simply want to learn to test for accessibility as part of your job.
description:
As an experienced accessibility professional that is new to accessibility testing, I will share the learnings of this part year, the mistakes I've made and pass on the most useful tips and feedback I received. 

The goal is for you to leave with a better understanding of how accessibility testing works and the key things you should be looking for when testing a website or app. I will present you with a practical and simplified approach to the testing process so you can get started and quickly become a better and more efficient accessibility tester. 

Whether you are new to accessibility testing, are looking to become an accessibility auditor or simply want to have the skills to do some accessibility testing as part of your job, this talk is for you.

name: How to Profit from Your DE&I Efforts
abstract: DE&I gives a competitive advantage, but getting started can be daunting. This session shows the way. Attend to learn about: easy wins, the importance of diverse customers, and how others made DE&I a focus.
description: We're all looking for a path to higher growth and improved profitability. But, have you ever considered focusing on Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DE&I) to get there? By keeping DE&I at the forefront for hiring and customer acquisition, corporations can see 30% better EBITDA results. But less than 1% of corporations do it. This session will cover where organizations often fall short (so you can avoid the pitfalls). Plus, we'll show you how to outpace competitors in this space moving forward. Quick tip: accessibility is a great place to start.

name: The UDL Practicum: Impactfully Addressing Evolving Needs
abstract: The past few years have highlighted a need for more inclusive, accessible and flexible learning environments. Northwestern developed a uniquely structured faculty UDL practicum that has led a culture shift. Learn how to replicate this on your campus.
description:
The past few years have brought significant change and challenges for both students and instructors. Students have experienced new barriers to learning along with different impacts of previously existing barriers. In this new normal, instructors are continuing to adjust to the challenge of offering more inclusive, accessible, and flexible learning opportunities. To help faculty adjust to these changing times, Northwestern created the Universal Design for Learning Practicum. This practicum, attended by over 300 faculty, focused on practical implementation of the three UDL principles multiple means of representation, expression, and engagement. The topic was one of interest, but the unique structure which weaved together interactive synchronous sessions, asynchronous learning activities, individual consultations, and opportunities to learn with and from peers is what made this a transformational learning experience for faculty.
The practicum was a collaborative effort of over 60 people and ten different units on campus. This session will lay a roadmap for other higher education institutions to follow to successfully implement UDL/accessibility initiatives. The session will focus on how partnerships were developed and fostered to create the practicum, the planning of both the structure and the content of the practicum, the practicum’s execution, and the results both in faculty learning and the impact it has had on students in classes across campus.

name: Automated Open-Source Keyboard Checker by IBM
abstract: Manual keyboard accessibility testing is repetitive, and prone to error. IBM has released a novel visualization keyboard checking mode as part of the free open-source IBM Checker to make it easier, more efficient, and less error prone.
description:
One of the major impediments of implementing accessibility for a web application or product before going to market is that there is going to be a significant amount manual testing. 

Keyboard accessibility is essential for users who are blind, who use alternative input devices, or use voice enabled command and control that emulates the keyboard interface.  Because most UX designers are only taught about color-contrast and alt-text, keyboard operability is often not designed in, not implemented and not checked (if at all) until the project is near completion. The perceived extra effort for manually checking for good keyboard operability leaves it up to developers to add it on the end of the project life cycle.     

We here at IBM have been pioneering new features as part of our open-source IBM Equal Access Accessibly Checker to create novel yet effective user interfaces that will make manual keyboard testing easier, more comprehensive, and less error prone. During this talk we will discuss our state-of-the-art visualization approach to identifying errors with keyboard navigation and operability and why we made some of our design decisions. 

This talk includes the results of a multi-year project, a user research phase, and iterations on implementation.  We’ll explore the results on how it makes manual keyboard testing faster for auditors, designers as well as developers. And we will demonstrate the new features in our open-source checker.

name: A Quick Path to Web Accessibility and Avoiding Liability
abstract: Worried about website liability? By understanding why websites are sued, you can create a better plan that we use that mixes manual and automated testing, good customer service, and a good lifecycle model perfect to your situation.
description:
Deciding to make your website accessible is an easy decision – knowing how to start and what to do can be a daunting endeavor! Let Converge Accessibility group show you an approach that has proven successful for many organizations.
This presentation presents the steps any organization to start the process of bringing web sites into compliance with accessibility laws and regulations. We will share the lessons learned from hundreds of other customers and a simple, logical approach to solve real-world web accessibility problems that incorporates accessibility into organization’s culture.
Ken Nakata will introduce the laws concerning website accessibility and some very practical and immediate steps that can be taken to reduce web site liability, such as creating an accessibility statement and the types of issues that tend to create liability. 
Jeff Singleton will take the conversation deeper into the technical aspects of establishing the testing approach and developing a plan for the initial web accessibly audit. Attendees will learn how to kick start an accessibility program, how to balance manual and automated testing, and how to create a simple end-to-end web accessibility lifecycle that fits any development environment.
The goal of this session is to provide attendees enough information and understanding about how to initiate an accessibility review of their existing websites based on a logical approach that has worked for others.

name: The Importance of Marketing in Your Accessibility Program
abstract: For an accessibility program to be successful, you will need to engage people in your organization, many who have conflicting priorities. This session will cover the importance of creating an engagement plan for your program as well as best practices
description:
Accessibility can be overwhelming for individuals. There are a lot of acronyms, unfamiliar terms and not well understood technologies. People know it is important, but they are not exactly sure what they need to do in their role or how it applies to them.  This uncertainty is particularly common in divisions outside of product and engineering.   As digital accessibility is ingrained in all our communications across the organization, it is essential that all employees be educated.  But what is the best way to engage them?   
 
Few who step into a role in creating an accessibility program realize how important marketing is to the success of your program.  However, it is crucial to engage teams across your organization. 

This session will discuss of our lessons learned while starting up an accessibility program at Pegasystems. 

Some challenges we ran into include lack of engagement, low attendance and not aware of offerings. 

Some lessons learned and recommendations include communicating in multiple channels, bringing content to the audience (rather then driving them to your own location), leveraging managers for influence and identifying passionate, evangelists within the organization who can support your efforts.  Also, be bold and and be creative.

name: Native Mobile Accessibility – Dreaming and Brainstorming
abstract: Learn about the power of Native Mobile Devices, the capabilities they have that Websites don't, and how CVS is leveraging this to deliver delightful health care experiences. Then brainstorm with us about other awesome things mobile can do for people!
description:
Native Mobile Applications are often seen with a company as extensions of, or even copies of, their corresponding web offerings. Designed as copies of the user experiences and business values. This leads to clunky experiences and a lack of success of Native Mobile offerings and ultimately to… inaccessibility and inclusivity.

A certain amount of feature and value parity within offerings makes sense. However, there is also a great deal of power for users in leveraging Native Centric features to deliver values that only a device that is carried on your person 24/7, with intricate sensors and features of its own, can provide! In this session we will discuss:

-	The collection of native specific devices and sensors.
-	How companies like Uber and Lyft have built entire market segments from Native.
-	How CVS is using these in SpokenRx to deliver customer value om the health sector.
-	A myriad of other ideas to kick start conversation.

Finally, we will close out with open discussion about other features that we can bring to Native Applications to better serve users with disabilities and their needs.

name: Visual Search Deficits in People with MD: A VR Study
abstract: This study is investigating how current commercial VR and eye tracking technologies could be utilised and how they perform on people with MD. We discuss observations, testimonials, findings and suggestions on how a VR headset can be used efficiently.
description:
MD (Macular Degeneration) is caused by changes to the macula, hindering predominantly the central vision which is used when looking straight at something. However, MD does not affect the peripheral vision, and people with MD can perceive the environment to a certain extent, generally  lacking of clarity and detail compared to central vision. This condition is often very disabling in everyday life and it can be very frightening for the person experiencing it.

The aim of this study was to investigate whether Virtual Reality (VR) technologies with integrated eye-tracking can be used to assess and to train people’s skills to search for objects in space when central vision is degraded. Eye-tracking has not been used with people with visual impairments in VR and as such we are exploring the efficiency of using such measures for future research. For this study, 20 participants (fully sighted and with MD) were recruited and were asked to spatially detect and identify 3D objects within a custom-designed VR space. They were asked to find these objects while continuous real-time eye gaze movement and fixation tracking were enabled together with the tracking of behavioural and verbal responses. Results show a deficit in visual detection and discrimination in people with MD that can be explained by altered visual search patterns as measured by eye tracking. These findings will help us understand visual search deficits in people with MD and provide opportunity for training and education.

name: New Projects at Smith-Kettlewell on Blindness and Low Vision
abstract: Learn about the new Smith-Kettlewell Rehabilitation Engineering Research Center and its research and development projects focusing on blindness and low vision.
description:
Smith-Kettlewell is proud to announce a new five-year award of the Rehabilitation Engineering Research Center (RERC) grant on Blindness and Low Vision. This award is from the National Institute on Disability, Independent Living, and Rehabilitation Research. It supports Smith-Kettlewell as a center promoting the independence and well-being of people with visual impairments through research and development to improve the understanding of, and provide solutions for, challenges facing the blind and low-vision community.

The new RERC grant will support a total of eight projects within three main areas of focus, led both by researchers at Smith-Kettlewell and by outside collaborators. These projects include: 

(a) Access to education and information: Audio-Tactile Media, AI-Enhanced Video Accessibility for YouDescribe and a Smith-Kettlewell Summer Institute; 

(b) Navigation and spatial interactions: Mobilizing Non-Visual Digital Maps, VR Tools and Training to Improve Auditory Environmental Perception and AI Tools for Micro-Navigation; and 

(c) Optimizing function with residual vision: Assessment and Rehab of Higher Visual Function Deficits for Cerebral Visual Impairment and Strategies to Improve Walking Safety with Central Field Loss.

In this session, leaders of most of these projects will give details of their plans and potential opportunities for collaboration.

name: Get to know the PDF/UA Processor Liaison Working Group
abstract: Developers providing support for accessibility needs, including remediation, developers working on PDF processors that interface with end-users, including PDF viewers and web browsers, and Assistive Technology (AT) experts.
description:
The PDF Association has begun working on a new specification around Processor Requirements for PDF/UA compliant files. A PDF processor is any software that allows someone to view a PDF, interact with it, and fill in forms, for example. This also includes assistive technologies. There is confusion and inconsistency regarding how PDFs are processed. While commonly used web technologies typically deliver consistent results, the same cannot be said for PDF processors. Results may vary when viewing PDFs in a browser versus viewing them with different desktop applications. In addition, different assistive technologies handle PDFs differently. The goal is to bring together processor and AT developers to discuss current functionality and what can be done differently in accordance with the new PDF specifications to provide better end-user experiences. This session is designed to report on the work that has already been done and to invite—and even inspire—developers providing support for accessibility needs; this includes people who remediate and fix PDFs, developers working on PDF processors that interface with end-users like PDF viewers and web browsers, and Assistive Technology (AT) experts.

name: Transforming Accessibility at Intuit, One Lunch at a Time
abstract: Intuit‘s Lunch and Learns started when COVID forced us to work remotely. With 100+ sessions and thousands of participants, it has transformed conversations about accessibility, inclusive design, living with a disability, and neurodiversity.
description:
Try to remember March 2020. The COVID epidemic was raging and businesses sent everyone home to work remotely. Ted Drake and Sagar Barbhaya were at the 2020 CSUN ATC conference. Returning to our homes, we wondered if we could continue the energy and curiosity found at a conference, only transforming it for a virtual work environment. 

The following week,  we launched Intuit’s Zoom-based Accessibility Lunch and Learn series. It was an experiment planned to last only a few weeks. We reached out to our Accessibility Champion network and quickly arranged daily lectures, mostly based on presentations already given at onboarding and other training events. 

As the epidemic grew, we turned inward and focused less on accessibility and more on our mental health, living with a disability, and celebrating our diversity. 

The key transformation came with a talk about sobriety in the workplace. The speaker’s courage to discuss her journey led to  heartfelt conversations about mental health, the loss of community, and the struggle where colleagues were trying to encourage hope with “happy hours” and alcohol-related team building activities. This presentation led to immediate improvements in our workplace language and pandemic policies. It also showed a lunch and learn was more than a lecture. It could be the community we were aching for. 

With more than 100 presentations and thousands of participants, we continue to learn something new every week.

name: The Most Accessible Publishing Spec is Now a W3C Standard
abstract: The EPUB 3.3 specification completed the rigorous process to become an official W3C Publishing Recommendation. This presentation will cover what you must know, including the “Accessibility Conformance and Discoverability” 1.1 portion of the Standard.
description:
80% of Higher Education content is being delivered in EPUB 3. This session, designed as a comprehensive introduction for beginners and an update for the advanced, will cover the basics of modern publishing standards using EPUB 3. We cannot cover everything, but we can explain what every educational professional should know, and we will provide a comprehensive list of resources that will be invaluable.

The European Accessibility Act goes fully into effect in 2025. It requires all digital publications be accessible, or it cannot be sold! Higher Educational publishers serve a global market, the accessibility of the EPUB 3.3 Standard, including the “EPUB Accessibility Conformance and Discoverability” portion, is having a profound impact on the uptake of adoption by the whole publishing industry. Major publishers in the US have been leading the transition, and the rest of the publishing industry is scrambling to meet accessibility requirements. This migration to Born Accessible publishing sets the stage for our presentation.

In a Nutshell:

•	W3C EPUB 3.3 Publishing Recommendation
•	EPUB Accessibility Specification 1.1
•	Accessibility Checker for EPUB (ACE)
•	Simple Manual Accessibility Reporting Tool (SMART)
•	Distributors of Higher Ed Content
•	Accessibility Metadata 
•	Importance of third-party certification 
•	The relationship between Born Accessible EPUB 3.3, Reading Systems, and Assistive Technology 
•	Accessibility of Reading Systems
•	Authoring tools
•	Comprehensive list

name: Visual Tracking and Readability Issues on Mobile
abstract: Reading on mobile devices presents unique challenges, both for people with disabilities and those without. Attend this session to learn how these challenges can be addressed, both by websites/apps and end users!
description:
Mobile devices present unique challenges related to text readability, due to small screen size, screen orientation, small text size, device instability, and other environmental factors. Compounding these challenges, most mobile browsers do not offer extension capabilities (as desktop browsers do) that allow users to customize their reading experience. 

This presentation will cover the ways in which these challenges affect text readability, with a focus on cognitive and visual aspects of reading. These issues will be discussed in the context of common visual disabilities such as binocular vision issues, as well as cognitive reading challenges like dyslexia, ADHD, and other neurodiverse conditions. 

In addition to discussing challenges for mobile text display, this presentation will also provide suggestions and examples of how some websites or mobile apps provide tools or technologies that can alleviate these issues. 

This presentation will also discuss the ways in which improving readability has been shown to help bottom-line metrics such as Time On Page and Subscriber Conversion Rate, which all companies care about and are responsive to. 

Lastly, this presentation will demonstrate various browsers that do offer extension support, discuss some of the pros and cons of their different approaches, and some of the challenges that remain to be solved in terms of ease of use, and inclusivity.

name: How Alexa is Helping PWD Stay in Touch with Loved Ones
abstract: The past two years have shifted how we communicate with loved ones. Come and learn how Alexa is now providing real-time or near real-time accommodations in video calls for people with speech impairments or that are Deaf/HoH.
description:
The Alexa for Everyone (AFE) team develops experiences for customers with all abilities, expanding the reach of Alexa across the spectrum of abilities for vision, hearing, speech, cognition, and motor functions. Juliana Tarpey (Product Manager for AFE and formally PM for Alexa Communications) will discuss the shifting communication trends seen over the past two years, and the role that Alexa plays in helping PWD stay connected with loved ones. 

Juliana will share changes in customer behavior and provide an overview of shifting communication mediums and technologies. We will then unpack how Alexa, most known for its voice forward experiences, is also providing real time accommodations during video calls for people speech impairments or are Deaf or HoH. Since last year, Alexa has released two new features (which we will showcase) that are providing real time on-screen accommodations to help customers communicate with out of group contacts; With Call Captioning, Deaf and HoH customers can see captions for their calls in near real time. RTT (Real Time Text) as a standard, enables customers with speech impairments to type text that is displayed live on the screen, while they see each other on video during the call. We’ll also explore how Alexa helps give remote relatives peace of mind, using tools for care givers to provide support from afar, which include the ability to reach emergency contacts.

name: Accessible Edtech for Elementary Math with AI-Learners
abstract: Learn to evaluate math learning tools that are accessible and engaging for students with cognitive, behavioral, and physical disabilities. Explore the first research-backed edtech company with math games that are compatible with assistive devices.
description:
Parents and educators want to provide their students with the best math learning tools available. But how do they decide which tool is best? There are hundreds of edtech websites and choosing the best one is not an easy task, especially when selecting a tool that is fully compatible with assistive technologies (AT).
Our presentation will cover criteria that a parent or educator can look for when selecting a math learning tool that is accessible for students who use AT and maximizes learning through effective personalization and engagement features. We will then demonstrate how the AI-Learners website meets all of these criteria. 
Parents, educators, and AT professionals will leave with AI-Learners as a new free tool to use with their students, and all participants will learn how to evaluate and develop a website that meets the needs of students who use assistive technology.

name: Promoting Tech Access & Use Across Stakeholder Groups
abstract: Technology First created a foundation for Ohio to promote access and use of technology through a variety of state funded projects.  This session will provide details of these projects including successes, barriers, and lessons learned.
description:
The Ohio Department of Developmental Disabilities (DODD) has promoted use of technology through a variety of methods.  This session will overview these projects and discuss successes, barriers, and lessons learned.
Tech Ambassador Project – A grant was provided to recruit, supervise, and facilitate a network of Technology Ambassadors across the state of Ohio.  Through this project, eight people supported in our system and a family member share their technology success stories and consult with teams across the state.
Innovative Technology Solutions – DODD has offered grants to providers that want to be innovative through technology either for the people they are supporting or for their agency.  
Technology Education Contracts – DODD developed a contract with Tech First Shift to offer several levels of certification for anyone across the state interested in learning more about the use of technology. DODD has contracted with subject matter experts to train on topics promoting technology access and use across the state.
Tech & Residential Providers – DODD is contracting with subject matter experts to work directly with residential providers to implement a plan to access and use technology throughout their organization.  
Tech & Housing Corps – DODD is offering a grant to Housing Corporations across the state.  This grant will equip housing with technology for ease of access and use.  
In conclusion, these efforts will be tied to Ohio's Technology First movement.

name: Advance Your Return on Accessibility (ROA) with Testing
abstract: Finding the balance of utilizing automated testing with manual, expert analysis when conducting accessibility tests on your websites & apps can be challenging. Both have their strengths and weaknesses. Are both forms of accessibility testing needed?
description: There are two ways to conduct accessibility testing on your websites and applications: automated, rules-based testing and manual, expert analysis. The scan and the audit. Both forms of testing are needed and both have their strengths and weaknesses. We will look at how and when to use these methods and how each method will influence your Return on Accessibility (ROA).

name: Accessible Transactional Documents Made Easy for the Masses
abstract: Service organizations must make the billions of statements, invoices and letters accessible.  We will discuss how to easily do this at scale and show tools that will help large organizations provide digital and accessible alternate formats.
description:
How do you make transactional documents accessible easily to the consumer?  Informational documents, letters, statements, invoices that contain personal and confidential information are delivered either via the email or digitally to consumers daily.  Typically, these documents contain time critical payment, and personal information.  Document types include banking, wealth, telecom statements and billing, health documents, communications from local, state and federal governments and information from health providers. An example could include credit card statements that are regulated and have a payment date that, if past, include monetary penalties. These communications are time critical. With millions to billions of these documents posted or sent, many consumers request these documents be accessible.
Documents are systematically generated and typically were printed and mailed or made into digital formats.  The print ready file that is generated for traditional print and mail contains all the information required to convert a document to an accessible PDF, HTML, braille, large print, eText or Audio. 
Print ready files like PDF, PostScript, AFP, Xerox, HP contain information that include fonts, text positioning and the critical style sheet. name: The Future of Accessibility in Telecom
abstract: Kevin and Keith will discuss the future of telecommunication solutions for deaf, deafblind, hard of hearing, and other disabilities.

name: Using AI to Automate Large Scale Document Remediation
abstract: Allyant demonstrates how advanced technologies, like AI, can ensure that volume documents generated from internal systems are accessible.
description:
Producing accessible PDF documents at an enterprise scale is never easy. More so, the Customer Communication Management (CCM) systems used to create statements, letters, policies, invoices, records, and more require specific expertise to build accessible templates, not always fully supporting complex content. Worse yet, they tend to lack fully integrated, innovative best-practice testing tools to ensure outputs meet ADA and accessibility standards like WCAG and PDF/UA. The result: an untenable ability to remediate the ever-increasing number of existing PDFs and reach a state of relative compliance.

We will use Allyant's highly advanced deep neural network AI to show how document generation becomes more intelligent over time. Furthermore, as the solution produces files, the algorithms are continually enhanced through our quality assurance and post-processing methodology. Essentially, the tool is "taught" through accessible sample documents how to properly tag PDF documents. This ensures those documents are fully accessible to work seamlessly with screen readers and other assistive technologies.

name: Quest for the Holy Braille: Dynamic Tactile Device Update
abstract: Last year APH, HumanWare and DOT Inc partnered to design the Dynamic Tactile Device, a tool that produces tactile graphics and standard braille on the same surface. This session will explain the milestones achieved, the current status of the project.
description:
In 2020 APH put out a Request For Information (RFI) to search for a partner who possessed the technology and dream of designing the first tactile device capable of producing both tactile graphics and standard braille on the same surface. HumanWare and DOT Inc answered the call and have since partnered with APH to develop the Dynamic Tactile Device (DTD).  

APH is the largest producer of tactile textbooks in the country, however, these textbooks often take months to produce and can arrive late, leaving the student at a further disadvantage when learning. The primary goal of the DTD project is to create a tactile E-Reader capable of displaying a textbook in a natural fashion that mimics the experience a student has when reading a physical textbook. Once produced, this textbook will be digitally sent to the student or teacher, eliminating the significant production time and cost it takes to emboss, bind, pack and ship the book to the student. This E-Textbook reader is just one of several tactile experiences that will be opened up by this innovative tool.  

Attendees of this session will be introduced to the DTD project, understand the current status of this undertaking and learn how to get involved going forward. This massive project will only succeed with the community’s help and input.

name: Design and Application of Tactile Icon Labels
abstract: For non-visual operation of an appliance, tactile labeling is an important method for identification of touch surface buttons.  This session introduces tactile icon labeling, including usage, advantages, disadvantages, and future considerations.
description:
For non-visual operation of an appliance, tactile labeling is an important method for identification of buttons on touch surfaces.  Popular labeling methods such as bump dots and braille tape are low cost and effective but there is room for improvement and standardization.  We have developed a collection of tactile icon stickers for home appliance labeling that takes tactile labeling to the next level.  With over 5,000 tactile icon appliance labeling packages sold we have a unique perspective on the design and application of tactile icon labels.  
Key elements of the session:
1. Advantages and disadvantages of existing tactile labeling methods
2. What are tactile icons and how do they improve upon existing tactile labeling methods?
3. Labeling a microwave oven with tactile icons
4. Why are the tactile icons the way they are?
  a. What we learned from our study with visually impaired test subjects
  b. Assembly and manufacturing constraints  
5. Where are tactile icons helpful and where are they not helpful.
 a. Includes information about current appliances and how to avoid appliances that can not be labeled with stickers  
6. Future considerations

name: What's the ROI on Document Accessibility?
abstract: There is a misconception that providing accessible documents is expensive and time-consuming. However, when done properly, it is the opposite and can provide organizations with an edge.
description:
Document accessibility isn’t a new concept, but there’s something that has been changing, especially within the last decade, it is becoming more and more the standard and less and less the exception, and the cost for being non-compliant has reached substantial amounts. Organizations are realizing how important it is to make customer-facing information accessible, compliant, and usable. Because of this, they are learning to incorporate document accessibility into their daily routines. For many, this is still a new concept, and therefore need help understanding the importance of having a document accessibility workflow in place.
Lawsuits and litigation issues for being non-compliant are on the rise, but some solutions will prevent this from ever happening; solutions that can combine automation, Artificial Intelligence/Computer Learning, and manual remediation to establish a solid workflow that will deliver document accessibility, compliance, and usability.
This session will describe the various advantages of having a functioning and successful document accessibility plan that, when implemented properly, will deliver an ideal ROI.

name: Making Libraries Accessible with Voice Assistants
abstract: Discover how voice assistants can enable visually impaired end-user to find and read content from libraries.
description:
Pratsam has developed services for both the Amazon Alexa and Google Assistant platforms, providing libraries with a plug-and-play service that can give the print-disabled end-user a good experience when accessing a library. Supporting both DAISY and DAISY Online, the Pratsam Reader Voice service can be customized for libraries, schools, companies and other organizations and easily integrated with already existing workflows and online distribution systems.

Time has been invested in developing but also testing the service with real end-users and professional UX specialists, to make the service as intuitive, usable and accessible as possible. In this session, Pratsam will present the challenges and solutions made to enable the end-user to have a smooth experience and be able to find and access content with voice only.

From 15+ years of developing both apps and hardware players for the playback of accessible DAISY books, a lot of experience has been gained at Pratsam on how to design audiobook player user interfaces for the visually impaired. Pratsam started developing a proof-of-concept for an online library service supporting digital voice assistants in 2019.

Pratsam has built an online solution, delivering over 40.000 accessible books online to print disabled end users, for the national special library Celia in Finland. The service is used by over 50.000 print-disabled end-users today.

name: Taking the Design(er) Out of the Design System
abstract: Reprioritizing the purpose of a design system, to focus on the people at the forefront. Consider people of all abilities by going beyond WCAG and be groundbreaking in terms of accessibility, in order to build a better design system for everyone.
description: While the title was chosen to spark interest and engage a good debate amongst designers and accessibility engineers, design and designers should never be excluded from the creation of a design system. More so the purpose of a design system should be reprioritized with a primary focus on the people who directly engage with the products built with design systems and secondary focus on teams who use design systems to build products. The goal being a highly useable and accessible system which has been facilitated by visual design, not lead by it. Reprioritizing the purpose of a design system: Firstly, to benefit people and secondly, teams that build products. Multidisciplinary collaboration: Adopt a collaboration first approach. Subgroups for each component consist of design, accessibility, engineering, and test to collaborate at all stages of the component creation process. Research and Testing: Include people and make them the primary focus in testing and research. Incorporate Usability, A/B Testing and people journey exploration through personas. Consistency across components: Explore the bigger picture. Contextual testing of components grouped together instead of in silo. Going beyond WCAG: Be groundbreaking instead of minimum accessibility. Challenging historically accepted common patterns: Test patterns and see which work best as not all common patterns are as accessible as they could be. Instead of “X did this” and “X did that” why not “Our design system puts people first”

name: Free Open-Source Tool to Simplify PC or MAC and AT Use
abstract: The NEW Morphic is a Free open-source program for Windows and macOS.  It installs in seconds and provides 1-click access to key accessibility and other computer features for those who struggle with computers (from young to old).
description:
Morphic is a new free open-source program for Windows and macOS that makes computers simpler and makes assistive technologies person needs more ubiquitous. 

Morphic is a revolutionary development in two different ways. 
1) First, Morphic make it much easier to discover and use the many built-in accessibility features in their computers. It also makes it much easier for them to move their settings between the different computer they need to use. This included the built-in accessibility features and any AT that is installed on computers at school, the library, etc. What used to be complicated and require going into and navigating the hierarchical settings panels – can now be done with a single click – from the desktop. 

2) Secondly, Morphic allows anyone to create simple, custom MorphicBars for themselves or for family members, friends, or those they care for.  These custom MorphicBars appear down the side of the screen and provide 1-click access to any program, website, or accessibility/usability feature on the computer. 
This is especially helpful to those who struggle with computers or are unable to use them at all. Instead of having to figure out what "programs" are, or how to "launch" or "close" or "switch" between them, and or how to navigate "windows" that cover each other up, menus that need to be understood etc, – they can have a single row of buttons down the side of their screen that gives them access to all of the basic programs and functions they need.

name: The Accessible Forms Checklist
abstract: The web is full of inaccessible forms. Yet, there's so much to know about how to make forms accessible that tackling inaccessible forms can feel overwhelming. In this talk, we will guide you through a high-level overview of accessible forms.
description:
Forms are one of the most important features in websites. They are a critical method of communication between people and companies. Yet far too often this communication is difficult or impossible due to poor accessibility.  

Accessible forms are easy to understand, complete, and submit. Instructions, cues, and requirements must be clearly identified to users. It must be simple to recover from errors. 

In this session, you will learn how to find accessibility errors in forms by using our high-level checklist. 

Our goal is to help build your knowledge around the WCAG success criteria related to forms. We will cover many topics, including: 
• Using labels and groups to identity elements 
• Exposing the required and invalid attributes 
• Having clear errors and instructions  
• Robust, accessible names for controls

description:
Everyone should be able to fully enjoy entertainment from music, streaming services, apps, games, and more. In recent years, Amazon has been working on significant enhancements to hearing accessibility to ensure its customers have easier access to audio for their many sources of entertainment. In this session, we will discuss the latest advancements from Amazon Devices.
Objectives:
• Learn how Amazon has been working on enhancements to hearing accessibility
• Learn how Amazon worked with industry leaders to help customers use their existing assistive technology (like hearing aids) with our products
• Learn how Amazon has built innovative audio personalization enhancements for Echo, Prime Video, and Fire TV

name: Amazing Projects by America's Brightest for America's Bravest

name: Making a Horizontal Scroll (as) Accessible (as possible)
abstract: Horizontal scrolls pose challenges for assistive technology users and hide website content from people with disabilities. Leveraging inclusive user research, we identify obstacles AT users face, and suggest design solutions and alternatives.
description:
Our CVS Health Inclusive Digital Design team believes that including people with disabilities in user research leads to more inclusive, accessible, usable, and generally more delightful experiences for everyone. When it came to designing a horizontally scrolling component as part of our Design System, we wanted to ensure the voices of assistive technology (AT) users were included in our solution. 

A horizontally scrolling component is a way of managing an overflow of related items in a single horizontal flow. From a product perspective, a horizontal scroll (or carousel, or slider) provides more opportunities to engage users by adding content to a section of the screen.  

However, horizontal scrolls are knowingly frustrating obstacles for AT users. Working with the Design System team, we set out to understand accessibility barriers with horizontal scrolls, find ways to mitigate those problems, and identify the best (and worst) contexts to use horizontal scrolls. We interviewed a range of AT users, including screen reader, magnification, voice, and switch users. 

From our research, it is clear that there are always better options available. From a user’s perspective, a horizontal scroll hides content, which it can be laborious to discover. Also, AT users generally try to avoid interacting with horizontal scrolls. Ultimately, since horizontal scrolls are likely to remain commonplace, we developed a detailed set of guidelines to minimize the barriers this component can create.

name: WAI Curricula: A Framework to Build Your Own Courses
abstract: Find out how the WAI Curricula can help you build, compare, and select courses on web Accessibility. Explore how to include accessibility in your existing ICT courses using a rigorously vetted, high quality set of learning outcomes.

This modular, role-based resource contains learning outcomes, as well as ideas for teaching and assessment. IT leverages the existing WAI informational resources to help instructors build their own courses on Web accessibility.

The session will:
- Explore the roles addressed as well as the existing curricula.
- Provide examples on how instructors could create their own courses based on existing curricula.
- Provide examples on how to include the learning objectives in already existing ICT courses, including design, developer, and authoring courses.
- Explain how to leverage other existing WAI informational resources to teach, learn, and advocate for Web accessibility.

name: VoiceOver Recognition: Machine Learning in Action

name: Usability is Everything for Accessible Documents
abstract: The session will compare different approaches to automate document remediation at scale and each approach's respective impacts on compliance and usability.
description:
This session will explore the challenges and opportunities of making system-generated, high-volume documents, otherwise known as “transactional documents,” accessible at scale. Workflows to remediate transactional documents, which are highly variable from a data perspective, but also uniform from a layout perspective (i.e., bank statements, explanations of benefits, invoices, pay stubs, transcripts, tuition bills, tax bills, etc.), are ideal candidates for automated remediation and quality assurance.
In addition to presenting a real-world enterprise use case for high-volume transactional document remediation, the session will also compare different approaches to automated remediation and their respective impacts on compliance and usability.
The session will also outline three distinct ways in which automated testing at scale can help ensure compliance and usability
•AI-assisted remediation template development
•Automated validation workflows

Finally, the session will share the best practices the Crawford Technologies organization has learned working with enterprises and large organizations to enable automated high-volume transactional document remediation at scale.

name: Tools to Support & Simplify Your Accessible Material Process
abstract: Providing accessible course materials is challenging and time consuming. This session will show how Texthelp tools support learners as they interact with course content and institutions as they remediate content and provide accommodations.
description:
Course content is more complex and varied each year. Given the development of technology, essential pieces of the curriculum come in a variety of places and file formats: printed and digital textbooks, journal articles, websites, LMSs, third party websites, PDFs, ePubs, documents, and more. All file types and content must be accessible and interact with the text-to-speech tool. Due to the continued focus on doing more with less paired with an increase in the number of students accessing support through the Disability/Accessibility Resource Office, professionals struggle to keep up with the demands expected of them when it comes to accessible course materials. A more user-friendly and time-efficient process is needed for the sustainability of our institutions and our offices both today and in the future. 

This session will focus on how Texthelp tools can augment and support the process of creating, providing and consuming accessible course materials through the lens of both professionals and students. Attendees will learn how students can independently gain access to course content formats and online environments by using Read&Write and OrbitNote. Through these tools and their direct interaction with course content, campuses will see a decrease in need for post-production remediation of content. For those creating STEM materials, Equatio provides a quick and easy process to make content accessible to all learners with disabilities.

name: Building a Roadmap for Accessible Gaming
abstract: RNIB’s 2022 Accessible Gaming Research highlighted six areas of improvement to make gaming more accessible. We will present what these are, the work done so far to advance them and why 3D audio may not yet be living up to its accessibility potential.
description:
RNIB’s 2022 Accessible Gaming Research highlighted six potential areas of improvement and have been working with the industry to advance these. The areas are:
●	Participatory design: end-user engagement and user testing with real people 
●	Knowledge sharing and learning resources for practitioners
●	Motivations and mandates for making video games accessible 
●	Infrastructure challenges for designing accessible gaming experiences
●	Interface challenges for designing accessible gaming experiences
●	Future research areas in accessible gaming 

One accessibility feature, 3D audio, can precisely pinpoint to a user where sounds are coming from but this either requires an extensive speaker array or audio encoding using an HRTF (Head Related Transfer Function). HRTFs should ideally be personalised and require head tracking to present a persistent virtual world around the user (for sighted gamers the software knows their head is facing the screen). These features are available but are rarely advertised or fully utilised and as such may have much more potential as an accessibility feature then they are currently realising. Research is needed to ascertain the extent to which these features could help. 
This presentation aims to outline the six areas of improvement and what has been done so far to advance these. We will also discuss head tracking and personalised HRTFs and whether research and intervention is needed to ensure these live up to their accessibility potential.

name: Partnering with ERGs to Scale Your Accessibility Program
abstract: Take your accessibility program to the next level by partnering with employee resource groups in your organization. We’ll talk about building authentic relationships, creating shared goals, and prioritizing initiatives that are mutually beneficial.
description: This session will cover how accessibility teams can partner with their company's employee or business resource groups (ERGs/BRGs) to grow advocacy, build executive sponsorship, and scale accessibility-related initiatives across the enterprise. Examples from the ERG partnerships built within the Cigna organization, primarily with the ABLE (Achieving Better Lives for Everyone) ERG which is focused on supporting caregivers and employees with disabilities will be shared. I will discuss how we’ve been able to collaborate with the ERG to stand up an executive level Digital Accessibility Steering Committee, socialize and provide training opportunities, and support implementation of an enterprise digital accessibility policy. I will provide actionable guidance on how to build connections and tips for what initiatives to prioritize depending on where an organization is at in their accessibility program maturity journey.

name: Navigation Drone Using Light Touch Contact
abstract: We propose a navigation system to help the visually impaired get to their desired destinations safely and independently. We also describe their challenges based on workshops and interviews, as well as the human characteristics that the system uses.
description:
We propose a navigation system that helps a visually impaired person (VIP) get to their desired destination safely and independently, even when it is a place to which the person is not used to going. Currently, VIPs often travel with white canes and guide dogs. With a white cane, it is difficult to determine the presence of a wide range of obstacles. Furthermore, there are VIPs who cannot have a guide dog for various reasons. In either case, it can be difficult to navigate to where the user wants to go.  In addition, visual information is important for maintaining balance in posture. When users have less visual information, it can be difficult to maintain posture. 
Based on the above considerations, a navigation system with a light touch contact (LTC) and a drone is proposed. The LTC is a phenomenon in which a small force of approximately 0.2–0.5 N is applied to a part of the human body, thereby stabilizing the posture. The system applies the resultant force of the contact force for LTC and the inductive force that tells the user where to go. It was confirmed by experiments using a toy drone that both induction and stabilization of posture could be achieved in able-bodied persons with their eyes closed. The proposed system reduced the walker's vibration observed with linear accelerations. In the future, we expect the system to be embedded in such devices as drones with strings. Sensors are used to recognize the surroundings and current location and guide the user.

name: How to Build a Business Case for Document Accessibility
abstract: There is a misconception that providing accessible documents is expensive and time-consuming. However, when done properly it is the opposite and can provide organizations with an edge.
description:
Document accessibility has been around for a long time, from its beginnings with Braille in the early 1800s to the digital era starting in the late 1980s. This certainly isn’t a new concept, but something has been changing, especially within the last decade. It is becoming more and more the standard and less and less the exception. Organizations realize how important it is to make customer-facing information accessible, compliant and usable, and because of this, they are learning to incorporate document accessibility into their daily routines. name: Eliminate Students’ Dependency on Alternative Materials
abstract: Enabling students to independently use digitally published materials in the EPUB format can enhance their learning and eliminate a ton of work for the DSO office! Which EPUB reading apps are worth recommending and why? Get up-to-date guidance.
description:
EPUB is the preferred digital file format used by publishers to distribute textbooks, and it is the most accessible mainstream publishing format ever developed. However, the app or device used has an incredible impact on the reading experience, and especially for students using Assistive Technology. If a first-year student is trained in using a great EPUB reading system, you will find that their demands for alternative materials drops through the floor. This session will provide guidance to DSO professionals on what reading apps and devices they can recommend to their students and why.
EPUB Reading Systems in Higher Ed are rigorously evaluated with Assistive Technology by persons with print disabilities and accessibility experts. The results are tracked at http://www.epubtest.org. All the major Reading Systems and Apps used in Higher Ed are evaluated, including popular specialized apps used by students with disabilities. 
We will start with our experts providing a detailed explanation of the testing methodology that uses controlled EPUB test books, including Math and STEM titles. Most of the session we will spend providing results and recommendations on which Reading Systems to recommend to students, and we will highlight some of the latest developments that benefit learners with print disabilities. Finally, we will provide an extensive list of resources and demonstration videos as well as how to easily keep up to date with the ongoing testing.

name: Design System Accessibility
abstract: A Design System is the backbone of any application, and far too often accessibility is only an afterthought. Learn how to improve accessibility and performance of your product, while also maintaining a consistent look and feel across your brand.
description:
What is wrong with Design Systems today?
Accessibility is often an afterthought, with many available design systems having numerous errors.

What are Design Systems?
A design system is a collection of components which work like building blocks to build a web application.

Why is it important for a Design System to be Accessible?
Because Design Systems are the building blocks of an application, they are used in all facets of all Intuit products. Given their prevalence throughout the applications, it is critical that they meet the highest standards of accessibility.

If my Design System is Accessible, am I done worrying about accessibility?
Yes, while building a strong foundation is essential, it is not enough to ensure that the components are used correctly, or that other custom elements are built correctly.

What design system do we have here at Intuit?
We have 1 design system: a component library that follows a set of standards compiled by designers, product managers, and us, the accessibility team. We also have 8 different products to design for. We solve for this by making our design system dynamic, so that certain elements can change while the base component remains the same.

What special accessibility considerations have been made for Intuit?
Accessibility is a part of the design process, and is taken into consideration before implementation has even begun. On top of this, I am currently adding automation testing for accessibility all throughout the design system.

name: 10 Tips for Good Storytelling
abstract: Sometimes, selecting the right code snippet can be just as important as choosing the right story or metaphor for your audience, but oftentimes we ignore the latter. In this session, discover 10 effective communication strategies.
description:
One of my regrets early in my career is that I didn’t share enough stories of digital accessibility successes that were happening across the organization. Over time, I have learned that great storytelling can be a creative and effective way to move teams forward, gain momentum, and make progress. In this presentation, discover practical tips for storytelling that have helped contribute to organizational improvement.  

Digital accessibility is equal parts art and science, it is both code and story. Encouraging teams to make improvement can be difficult when compliance is looming, but creative approaches to communication can make a big impact.  

Hear practical examples and lessons learned from an accessibility manager that can be used to help you communicate using impactful, lasting and effective storytelling that is accessible and inclusive. In this presentation, experience first-hand 10 effective communication practices that you can use to tell great stories and impact your audience.  

1.	Lead with a story.
2.	PowerPoint? 
3.	Know your content.
4.	Know your audience. 
5.	The medium is the message. 
6.	Make it accessible. 
7.	The hook.  
8.	Change it up. 
9.	Tell other’s stories. 
10.	Feedback is a gift.

In this session, Amazon accessibility experts share some of the neat things Alexa can do and how we’re working hard to create experiences that delight customers with disabilities.
description: Alexa makes it easier for customers to order groceries and household essentials, ask product questions, use smart home products and collaborate with their caregivers. In this session, Amazon accessibility experts share some of the neat things Alexa can do and how we’re working hard to create experiences that delight customers with disabilities.

name: A Powerful Tool to Make PowerPoint STEM Contents Accessible
abstract: Our new tool: an add-on for Microsoft PowerPoint (PPT) allows you to make any technical part included in PPT slides for STEM education be accessible.  Accessible slides also can be made easily from a PDF source.
description:
In many cases, print-disabled students hardly access important technical parts such as math formulas, diagrams and tables included in STEM educational materials created with Microsoft PowerPoint (PPT), which are commonly used in online lectures.

We have recently developed a powerful tool to realize a systematic-processing mechanism for adding alt texts/aloud reading with a TTS (text-to-speech) voice into PPT STEM contents: so-called "an add-on" for PPT by making use of VBA (Visual Basic for Application).  It allows you to automatically/systematically convert inaccessible technical parts into various accessible forms such as an image object with an alt text/an audio object (aloud reading) and place them in the PPT slide.  Infty software: "InftyReader" (an OCR system for STEM) and "ChattyInfty" (an accessible STEM-document editor) carry out the conversion automatically in the background.

In case that a math formula is not in PPT, you can create it directly in ChattyInfty (which is easily done in an intuitive manner) and insert that formula into the PPT slide together with alt text or aloud reading generated by ChattyInfty.  Otherwise, you may start with a PDF source; at first, you convert a math formula in PDF into a ChattyInfty form once with InftyReader OCR and then, insert it into PPT. 

If a lecture script (narration) is prepared in ChattyInfty, you can add the speech presentation generated by ChattyInfty to each slide and convert entire PPT into an accessible MP4 video.

name: Supporting Assistive Technology Users in the Enterprise
abstract: This lively session between two seasoned AT Specialists working with the public and private sectors for decades will discuss the many facets of supporting AT users in the enterprise and essential systems and skills that need to be in place.
description:
Various disability legislation exists to ensure employees with disabilities have equal access to everything from the hiring process, use of all internal systems and communication within an enterprise, requests for accommodation, training and Helpdesk support.  There have also been great advances in Assistive Technology (AT) for persons with disabilities for greater access to IT systems, standards around how to make complex websites accessible and tools for monitoring the accessibility of web sites and remediating documents.  However, providing seamless support to the employee with a disability in all these areas, what TCS Access calls the “last mile of accessibility”, can be daunting for enterprises.  Such support requires extensive planning, support from many individuals and internal teams and continual monitoring.  Based on its decades long experience working in enterprise environments with Employees with Disabilities, management and Helpdesk support, TCS Access created this session to help enterprises understand the expertise and processes they need to fully support their employees with disabilities.

name: Reflow... Did You Mean Mobile?
abstract: A deep dive into WCAG Success Criterion 1.4.10 Reflow, what it's intended to cover, and why it frequently gets confused with mobile. What are the overlaps and what kinds of things would constitute a failure of this criteria?
description:
How did an accessibility guideline designed for people who have low vision get mixed up with needing to support mobile? Reflow is meant to help people easily perceive information when they zoom their screen. But modern browsers tend to treat zoom the same way they treat mobile breakpoints. This session will cover what types of issues constitute a Reflow failure according to WCAG, and where this success criterion overlaps with responsive web design.
