name: Making Sense of Large Data Visualizations
abstract: Highcharts and Elsevier share recent research into interactive web charts. Our user studies focused on line charts with large amounts of data. Can we use automated text descriptions combined with sonification to improve the usability of these charts?
description:
Highcharts is a world leading provider of accessible charting tools for the web, used by 80 of the top 100 Fortune companies. Recently Highcharts and global publishing company Elsevier’s Digital Accessibility Team collaborated to provide better accessibility for line charts with large datasets.

Line charts are often used to visualize datasets with thousands of data points. This presents a challenge for non-visual access, as providing access to individual data points is not sufficient. A reader of a line chart with a large amount of data will aim to extract information about trends, patterns, and outliers from the chart.

Can we make this information more accessible by communicating it through text and sound? What is the most intuitive way to experience this data through sound? And to which extent can we automate the text description?

Human authored text descriptions of charts are historically difficult to beat, but can in many cases be impractical – such as where data is dynamically loaded in real-time. Automated text descriptions can also be designed to be more objective and less prone to biases. Will users be able to trust these descriptions? Will they still prefer those created by a human?

With each of the new accessibility research questions we will provide user feedback from non-sighted users on our approaches. We will share findings about best practices, and show screen reader demos to help illustrate design considerations.

name: European Digital Rights – Human Rights for a Digital Age?
description: We need the law to protect the most fundamental rights of all people, also in the context of innovative assistive technologies. For years, this was mostly the task of Human Rights law. Can Digital Rights proposed by the EU step up to the challenge?

name: CSUN's Legacy: Sessions that Changed our Careers
description:
The CSUN Assistive Technology Conference has transformed the accessibility and inclusive design community over the past 38 years. It's a global gathering of designers, developers, educators, rehabilitation experts, and researchers. The true strength of the conference is the spectrum of conversations that happen in hallways, sessions, tradeshows, and even the late-night bar runs. It's a house filled with global family members who can't wait to share what they've learned.
Everyone that attends a CSUN Conference gains new perspectives, but some sessions and events have a profound impact on your understanding of accessibility and inclusion. Jennison Asuncion and Ted Drake, the 2023 Program Chairs, will share moments that had a profound impact. They will summarize the moment, what they learned, and how they used that information to change their careers. You will be inspired to embrace the CSUN experience, whether it is a profound conversation in a session, a chance meeting in the hallway, chaotic audience participation, or starting a new collaboration over drinks at the bar.

name: A User Lead Evaluation of Non Visual Navigational Tech
abstract: How helpful are non visual assistive digital tools for people with vision loss? A user lead study considers the likely candidates and explores their helpfulness in a practical everyday context.
description: The venerable white cane and guide dog have long been established as a vital tools enabling blind and partially sighted people around the world to independently and safely navigate our environments. For the last two decades these core mobility skills have been augmented by specialist GPS solutions supporting outdoor navigation with dozens of apps and dedicated devices now available. However indoor navigation out of the range of GPS signals has remained stubbornly difficult problem to crack, until now. Over the last 12 months several public trials of emerging navigation solutions have been made available across the U.K.’s public transport system for blind and partially sighted people to experience and feedback. This evaluation aims to identify the key attributes needed for success to inform future development and public investment. In this paper the presenters will compare and contrast the strengths and weaknesses of each technology in order to offer a user light perspective on their suitability for everything use. As well as potential implications for public buildings, venue owners businesses and other stakeholders we will have case studies from users who provide a full and frank assessment of their experiences. The core technologies that will be considered and evaluated include AIRA, NaviLens, GoodMaps, WayMap and MyEyes. The presenters will consider the relevance and usefulness of each application across a range of practical everyday contexts.

name: Fully Inclusive Communications in Education
abstract: Communicating with individuals who require methods such as ASL, braille, accessible PDFs, and others can be intimidating, but it doesn’t have to be. This session will discuss solutions that can make it all easy.
description:
This session will discuss the importance of making various types of communication accessible to allow individuals who require accessible information to be provided in whichever format makes it easy for them to ingest. The key is to promote inclusivity, focusing on the education arena.

Often, people who require accessible PDFs, accessible videos, a way to communicate live with another person, or to be able to ingest information provided to them are faced with barriers that prevent them from doing so. This happens in all aspects of life, but when it occurs in the education world, it can greatly impact the individual’s career journey.

With thousands of documents used to help students navigate their learning path and with learning material that extends beyond documents, it is not only crucial but essential to make these communications accessible by whatever means are necessary. A strategic approach is needed to comply with not only doing the right thing but also meeting regulatory requirements in the US and worldwide to make information accessible.

Some solutions make this all possible, and we will discuss the best way to implement these and how these can make these communications easy and accessible to all.

name: Live Captions in Virtual Reality (VR)
description: This session presents the results of a study on the use of captioning for deaf/hh people in a live virtual reality tour, and discusses best approaches for use of captions in VR.
secondary_topics: Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), & Cross/Mixed Reality (XR)

name: How to Implement Accessible Website Carousels
abstract: This session covers common accessibility barriers with carousels and provides solutions.
description:
A common feature of modern websites is what many refer to as sliders or carousels—a rotating banner of information resulting in "scenes" of text, images, and call-to-action buttons designed to navigate people to specific content. And though these are widely popular, they most often result in accessibility and compliance issues, hindering access to information for those using screen readers or other assistive technologies. 
 
In this session, attendees will learn the key techniques to identify when to use carousels and how to ensure they are accessible to all users. Allyant experts will provide a real-time demonstration of screen reading software and the outcomes of accessible and inaccessible carousels in action and provide an alternative, fully accessible solution.

name: The Snack Talk: 15 Minute Immersive A11y Trainings
abstract: Want to grow your digital team’s accessibility awareness and engagement but don’t have the resources? Introducing the Snack Talk: 15 minute immersive, single-topic trainings that have transformed Kroger’s accessibility program one snack at a time.
description:
Kroger Technology & Digital, like many organizations, is in the beginning stages of its accessibility journey. Past audits of our digital products have exposed that similar accessibility issues have been repeated year after year. We realized teams needed to be trained on the basics of accessibility in order to effectuate real change.

Initial attempts at training used the typical slide presentation format and lasted thirty minutes to an hour. Engagement in accessibility after the trainings was not what we hoped for, and we had limited resources to continuously train teams. We had to find a way to build empathy and train product teams on accessibility in a fun, interactive way that maximized the impact and best utilized the presenters’ time.   

Enter the Accessibility Snack Talk: 15 minute, snack-sized, immersive trainings conducted during our established accessibility office hours, with a look behind the scenes of accessible design and a new topic every other week. Instead of using the typical Powerpoint slide, we created simple HTML pages to demonstrate the material and provide the opportunity to  look directly at the code that creates an accessible experience and tie that back to their role in the development process.

In this session, we will guide our audience through the formation of the Snack Talk: how and why we got started, the topics we tackle and methods we use, the impact it has had on our teams at Kroger, and how we see it expanding our acce

name: How Google is Addressing Reading A11y Across Products
abstract: In this session, a cross functional team will share some research insights and our process in developing a set of reading capabilities to support online reading.
description: Join us to learn about what Google has been recently working on in the reading space and how we are thinking about these functionalities as broader capabilities, rather than one-off accessibility features. We’ll cover how our research, design, and engineering processes have informed our work in this space, and dive into abilities-based design and how it’s relevant to assistive technology.

name: Creating Accessible Social Media Content
abstract: Social media is a great tool to form connections, advertise, learn, and be entertained. In order for social media to be inclusive, it is critical that social media content is accessible.
description: Social media is a great tool to form connections, advertise, learn, and be entertained.  In order for social media to be inclusive, it is critical that social media content is accessible.  This talk will guide you through simple ways to make your social media content more accessible to screen reader users and the Deaf/HoH community.  During this talk, you will learn how to utilize accessibility features built into social media platforms, and about best practices for creating accessible social media content.

name: Working Internationally: How Accessibility Differs in Australia and the US
abstract: A talk about the differences in working in the accessibility industry in Australia and the United States.
description: AccessibilityOz has been operating in Australia since 2011, in the US since 2015 and in the EU / UK since 2017. Here Gian Wild, the CEO (and an Australian) talks with Sheryl Dwyer, the Operations Manager (and an original American) about the differences in working in the accessibility industry in both countries. From how people speak (z versus zed), to misunderstandings (see you in a fortnight) and other cultural differences, learn about what it means to be truly international.

name: A Fun Stump-the-Designers at IBM
abstract: Engage with good design visualizations and vote on which are better designs. Identify characteristics that make the best accessible designs. Interact with the presenters by providing feedback on the design decisions. Experience accessible designs.
description:
One of the major challenges facing designers is dropping into accessibility and gaining the wisdom of knowing what is good, better, and best design decisions. Applying design thinking approaches to accessibility challenges in designing delightful experiences has yielded an approach to introducing accessibility to designers. Evaluating real-world designs for better accessibility can enlighten designers on how to make better decisions. Practical examples will be a great reference and foundation for designers going forward. 

Some design decisions are good and follow some of the basic guidelines in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG), but reading that document feels like a bunch of lawyers are talking to geeks. WCAG is written for front-end developers and subject matter experts, not designers. We found that designers need pictures and sketches of good designs that have been re-designed, and re-sketched to be even better accessible designs. Seeing and participating in the evaluation process is how designers experience the process of making better design decisions. 

Most UX designers are only taught about color contrast, alt-text, and maybe labels.  How to make the best accessible design decisions is not taught in design schools. This fun session will provide a way for designers to not only learn good and better designs but how to even make the best design decisions.

A large enterprise company like IBM has a variety of real-world use cases. These examples have been h

name: How to Provide Students with Real-Time, Accessible Education
abstract: How to easily provide accessible documents to students with disabilities.
description: Educational institutions continually face the challenge of providing students with timely access to high-quality instructional materials in accessible formats. More so, there remains a distinct and troublesome trade-off between speed and quality. These trade-offs result in negative impacts on students' education and their futures. But how can this be solved?

name: Anatomy of an Accessible PDF
abstract: This session focuses on understanding the PDF environment, the important tools you will need and what to look for when evaluating a PDF for accessibility.
description:
This session focuses on understanding the parts and pieces of an accessible PDF and the platform in which it is read. We will cover the user interface for Acrobat Pro DC in a way that clearly explains what tools are available to creators, evaluators and remediators. We will discuss the importance of the Content Panel, the Tags Tree and the Read Order panel and what each one has to offer and why you should review them all. We will discuss basic tag structure and what to look out for when reviewing documents for accessibility. We will learn several key tools for fixing common errors. Attendees will leave with a firm understanding of the PDF environment and what specifically makes one document accessible and another not.

Handouts include:
• Adobe Acrobat Accessibility Checklist
• 10 Tips for writing with accessibility in mind
• Tips for writing Effective Alt-Text

name: The “Win-Win” of Accessible Tech for Government and Industry
abstract: The US Federal Government is required to implement accessible technology. This presentation promotes the “Win-Win” situation achieved when Industry develops tech with accessibility in mind, stimulating an ecosystem of accessible tech benefitting all.
description:
Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act requires the US Government to buy, build, and implement Information and Communication Technology (ICT) that is accessible to all its employees and members of the public. Since the US Federal Government buys more Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) technology than it builds in-house, it relies on Industry to understand and implement the Section 508 standards into the products they build. This presentation provides an overview of the Section 508 Technical Standards, discusses the importance of accessibility, and shares information about the Federal acquisition lifecycle.

The Federal CIO Council established an Accessibility Community of Practice (ACoP) to promote the adoption of Section 508 across the Federal Government. As leaders of the ACoP Industry Outreach Subcommittee, we will share our stories of Industry engagement. We will define and explain the importance of Accessibility Conformance Reports and roles that Industry and Government customers play in the acquisition of accessible technology. In order to guide Industry towards addressing the Section 508 standards and developing reports on the accessibility of its products, NASA developed a guide to “Demystify Section 508” that will be reviewed.

The presentation will conclude with best practices for the development of accessible technology, Accessibility Conformance Reports, and reiterates why building accessible ICT is a “Win-Win” proposal for both Industry and Government.

name: WCAG 3 Update
abstract: Get the latest information on WCAG 3
description:
The Accessibility Guidelines Working Group is working on the W3C Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 3, the next generation of these web accessibility standards. This presentation will:
1. Review the goals for WCAG 3,
2. Discuss the current status of the work,
3. Provide an opportunity for immediate feedback, and
4. Review ways to keep up to date and provide ongoing feedback.

name: Braille Brain UEB and Nemeth Code Training Program
abstract: Join us to learn about an online UEB and Nemeth code training program. The curriculum includes over 40 carefully sequenced modules promoting braille mastery. Development research will be shared, along with a sneak peak at APH’s new website.
description:
Braille Brain is an online UEB and Nemeth code training program supported by the U.S. Department of Education (H235E190002). Designed for professional development, Braille Brain includes over 40 literary and Nemeth training modules, which are carefully sequenced to promote mastery of the braille code. Each module has a focus area for learning specific braille symbols, followed by several practice activities. The training materials are designed to be incorporated into personnel preparation programs and used in braille courses as supplemental materials. Although modules are carefully sequenced and build upon one another, users also may select specific lessons on demand, providing just in time delivery of the resources. 
The literary UEB modules (n = 66) and Nemeth modules (n = 49) have been pilot tested by pre-service teachers and paraprofessionals. Ratings from user surveys showed overall, 100% of users strongly agreed or agreed on each of six different quality indicators, with more than 75% of users rating their training positively as strongly agree on four of six indicators. 
The project, now in its fourth year has partnered with the American Printing House for the Blind to offer fully accessible online resources which will be available on their website in 2023. Presenters will provide attendees with a sneak preview of the website, explain the scope and sequence of the training materials, and demonstrate Braille Brain activities.

name: How to Solve MS Word Challenges in a Large Organization
abstract: Document accessibility can be challenging, however MS Word users can now easily create accessible Word and PDF documents without being experts. We’ll discuss options for making Word Documents accessible and how to build a culture of inclusion.
description:
This session is aimed at individuals, organizations, and enterprises who need to create accessible documents from inception, with basic knowledge of Microsoft Word and document accessibility.

With thousands of internal and public-facing documents produced daily within many organizations, a strategic approach is needed to comply with regulatory requirements in the US and worldwide. So why not make it easy and start at the beginning, at the document creation phase?

Organizations must guarantee compliance with various accessibility standards or face severe and expensive consequences. Millions of users face the challenge of creating accessible and compliant documents. Historically, making Word documents accessible has required a thorough knowledge of Word functionality, as well as an in-depth understanding of document accessibility. However, most content authors are unfamiliar with accessibility standards and are equally unprepared for the additional time required to make each document compliant. Furthermore, it would cost tremendous amounts of time and money to make every document author an expert in Microsoft Word and accessibility standards. This would seem an incredibly overwhelming and expensive task, but it doesn’t have to be. We will discuss solutions that make the process much easier and more cost-effective.

name: WCAG 2.2 - What It Means for You as Designers
abstract: Most of the new WCAG 2.2 criteria have implications for designers – visual, focus states, words and interaction. The new success criteria will be discussed, the appropriate role identified, and the design implications identified.
description:
The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.2 (WCAG 2.2) is currently in CR but due to be released in December 2022. WCAG 2.2 builds on WCAG 2.1 by adding 9 new success criteria addressing issues for:
• users with low vision
• users with cognitive impairments
• users with mobility issues
Several of the new success criteria are considered to just be formalising what many accessibility experts consider best practice and hence advised their teams or clients to do anyway. For example, sufficient touch target size was always considered good advice – why would you want to design an interactive element that is difficult to activate? Having a requirement that focus indication not only be present but defining what constitutes clearly visible is also a welcome addition to assist low vision users. 
There is lots of work around categorising WCAG success criteria by what role in a development team should be taking responsibility for which criteria. The three design roles often considered when discussing who should take primary responsibility for accessibility are:
• visual design
• interaction or UX design
• content design and preparation
Other roles with implementation responsibility include the developer which we will briefly discuss in this presentation in terms of how the success criteria could be implemented once designers have addressed the criteria.

name: Wait. I Thought Alexa Was Just a Voice AI?
abstract: Learn how the Alexa for Everyone team at Amazon is collaborating with people with disabilities to build new assistive technologies. We’ll cover new features that are making Alexa smarter and able to better understand customers every day.
description: Join us in this session where we bust common myths about who exactly Alexa is designed for. Spoiler alert: Alexa is for everyone.  Juliana will take you through a journey of how Alexa has evolved to become more accessible for customers with speech, cognitive, and mobility disabilities. With the Disability community’s, “Nothing about us without us” guiding principle, she’ll share Amazon’s vision for accessibility, how the company works with customers throughout the feature development process, and how new features and expanded functionality are helping Alexa support new customer groups. For example, attendees, like you, will see how non-verbal customers are using touch to interact with Alexa, through Tap to Alexa on Fire tablet, helping them use other devices, play entertainment, and communicate with others.

name: Leverage Accessibility to Improve Your Business
abstract: Join TPGi's Charlie Pike, and Mark Miller, as they discuss the return on accessibility and how organizations can improve their UX by improving the usability of their digital products.
description: Join TPGi's Charlie Pike, and Mark Miller, as they discuss the return on accessibility and how organizations can improve their UX by improving the usability of their digital products.

name: Does It Comply? To “Can I Use It?” – Task-Focused Accessibility
abstract: This talk will cover some techniques that apply a task-oriented focus to accessibility efforts and will help teams identify ways to prioritize barrier identification and removal that has the most positive impact on people with disabilities.
description: Accessibility standards help us test whether accessibility barriers are present in a digital product and indicate how we might fix them. But ultimately, our goal should be to ensure that people with disabilities can use the product for its intended purpose. With limited resources, how can we ensure that efforts are focused on ensuring successful task completion? This talk will cover some techniques that apply a task-oriented focus to accessibility efforts and will help teams identify ways to prioritize barrier identification and removal that has the most positive impact on people with disabilities.

name: Evaluation of Anonymized Sign Language Videos With MediaPipe
description: We present results of a study evaluating two filters that use Google MediaPipe to aim to automatically anonymize sign language videos, while maintaining understandability.

name: UsableNet AQA: Find & Fix Web Component Accessibility Issues
abstract: How UsableNet’s AQA Platform can be used to facilitate quality communication between teams involved in an organization’s accessibility remediation and maintenance program. Specifically, we’ll look at streamlining work through the use of components.
description: Demonstration of UsableNet’s AQA Platform to isolate components on a web page to better focus the remediation process and reduce the duplication of errors for recurring components across the site. The demonstration will show how to associate every issue’s instructions for the remediation team and how to resolve it. Then, with the AQA Chrome Extension, the review information can be accessed. The team can also test the remediation in the local environment before the code is promoted to staging or production.

name: How to Teach Compassion With Assistive Technology
abstract: This session will show how three different activities, legal cases for service dog access denial, a therapeutic board game for mental health facilities, and programs for students inventing assistive technology are all vehicles to teach compassion.
description:
Compassion is a basis for assistive technology. It is the desire to relieve someone else’s distress, create greater independence and better quality of life for the user. Assistive technology can also be used to create and promote compassion in others.
Examples of this are: 1. Three legal cases of service dog access denial in two hospitals in the San Francisco Bay Area. One case, a landmark decision, is the precedent for future service dog access denial cases. The cases created awareness and understanding of service dogs, the tasks they perform, with implications to ensure the rights of service dog recipients. 2. The invention of a therapeutic board game for psychiatric inpatients presents therapists with a tool to increase mental health. The game has interventions to help patients learn about themselves and others. Greater awareness and understanding of each other and their problems creates greater empathy and compassion. 3. Three educational programs teaching students design thinking while inventing something to meet the needs of an individual with a disability are Project Invent, Design the Future, and Stanford University’s, “Perspectives in Assistive Technology.” The students learn about the challenges of an individual with a disability. Creativity of the the community partner present opportunities to teach compassion. From personally experiencing aspects of the life of an individual with a disability, students gain a greater understanding and compassion for other people.

name: AT to Support the Education to Workplace Transitions
abstract: Transitions occur when students move from K12 to higher ed and then to the workplace. Join us as we explore the tool Read&Write through a lens of supporting students in K12, as they transition through higher ed, and ultimately into the workplace.
description:
Transition is defined as the process of moving from one condition or state to another. Two major transitions occur in one’s life when it comes to education and work: the transition from K12 education to higher ed and from higher ed to the workplace. Technology made available to a learner in the classroom can help facilitate not only access to the curriculum but also necessary support to persist and move through one’s educational career. This technology has been found to be just as critical when individuals move into the workplace. A single tool used continuously throughout all segments of one’s education and work career can be key to more seamless transitions and success. 

This session will explore the literacy support tool, Read&Write from a lens of use throughout the education and workplace continuum. Attendees will understand the tool as a student begins use in the K12 setting, giving them access to course content and supporting them as they work toward graduation. As students move into higher education, this same tool can be used as they gain skills for the workplace and learn in this more advanced and intensive setting. Finally, within the workplace, students will already have mastery of the tool given the long standing use. Individuals can continue to use Read&Write when making their mark on the working world. By having continuity throughout the lifespan, individuals can be more confident, more successful and spend more time excelling in their programs or work.

name: Learning Accessible Design through Gamification
abstract: Can people learn about accessibility through a simple game? Come discover the answer yourself. Take part in this group exercise where we try out a real time prototype, and seek input from the audience on how to grow the concept accessibly.
description:
It takes significant experience and time to become well-informed on the breadth of accessibility considerations for good Web design. This is the case even for those with one or more disabilities. Yet to make products and pages accessible, we need a critical mass of trained designers and developers.
Although involving users with disabilities in research and testing helps inform and confirm decisions, to the degree we want to make experiences delightful, we need development teams to have the basics down, so that the focus can turn to innovating towards better designs, not struggling for basic accessibility.
To date, training and education has focused on text-heavy guidance and implementation examples.
Initial testing with a small set of sample questions suggests that through side-by-side comparisons of designs, we can more rapidly engage users, and make learning accelerated and fun.
This presentation will expand on initial work done in this field at IBM. Attendees will be offered a chance to participate in real-time polling, and then comment on the results.

We will then provide a forum for users to contribute towards an open-source online game for learning accessibility. We will address considerations around how to make a gaming interface accessible. We will also explore some of the challenges of constructing examples of inaccessible design which can yet remain explorable, and seek audience input on how to construct a question bank that welcomes involvement from all users.

name: AI and Mobility: Making Complicated Technology Simple
abstract: Through demonstration and discussion, the presenters will cover the high potential for AI in the visual impairment world.
description:
When you hear Artificial Intelligence (AI), your mind goes one of two ways: either Sci-Fi, or really complicated technology. We don’t realize it, but AI already plays a big role in our everyday lives. AI influences our lives, sometimes for the better (getting good recommendations on Netflix based on our viewing history, for example) and sometimes, the worse (targeted ads when navigating the Internet).

At Humanware, we saw the potential for AI to help in the world of Orientation & Mobility and asked ourselves, how can we use technology to makes the lives easier for our users? The final forty feet was an easy answer. We all know that GPS and maps are never 100% accurate. Sometimes, the GPS will make you stop a door short, or too far from your intended destination. A sighted person can easily confirm if they’re in the right place. But for a blind person, it can lead to knocking on the wrong door.

HumanWare StellarTrek is the perfect example of AI technology at its best, assisting the user to confirm he or she is at the correct destination by detecting doors and addresses.  GPS coordinates, cameras, Wi-Fi connections are all used in conjunction to return the most accurate information, from confirming the address and doors to OCR results, back to the user.    

And it’s only the beginning! With AI, it opens up the door to a slew of potential features, such as crosswalk detection, currency recognition, and beyond!

name: PDF/UA-2: What’s New?
abstract: The release of PDF/UA-2 is anticipated in 2023. This presentation will discuss the upcoming changes to the accessibility standard and how to prepare for it.
description:
As digital transformation initiatives continue to transform the world around us—people's overall digital experiences also evolve. As such, the software millions of people use daily to create documents for work and personal consumption must keep pace with all technologies and standards for output—and consistently account for all aspects of accessibility. This evolution continues to drive change in accessible digital documents and ensure that all people have equitable access to information, regardless of circumstance. In this session, Allyant's world-leading accessibility experts will explore the technical details of the PDF/UA-2 standard and its impacts on document accessibility.

name: What's New in JAWS, ZoomText, and Fusion
abstract: Live demonstration along with question and answer time for the latest and greatest features of JAWS, ZoomText, and Fusion. We will also look ahead to what is coming next.
description: Join us to learn about new features, including Smart Glance, Notifications Manager, Tethered View, and more. We will also discuss upcoming new features and enhancements.

name: Retinal Projection Digital Camera for Better Accessibility
abstract: This session will provide some stories of how people with low vision can improve their quality of life with the help of retinal projection technology. Variations of retinal projection devices will be introduced, including the combination of a camera
description:
We will explain the technology behind the devices we have developed and present a documentary featuring low-vision patients and how their lives have been changed by these devices.
RETISSA NEOVIEWER is an accessory viewfinder for a digital camera that features retinal projection technology, which we at QDLaser have been developing for more than a decade. When looking through the camera's viewfinder, a weak laser beam passes through the pupil and projects images that are picked up by the camera directly onto the retina. The projected image is always focus-free, independent of the focusing ability of the eyes. The projected image is clear even in the peripheral area of the retina, which is better than natural vision. Moreover, the optical zooming function of the attached digital camera can provide great magnification to the users.
By using this device, some people with low vision can dramatically improve their quality of life, since they can watch things better with retinal projection than with their own impaired vision. We will introduce several stories named “With My Eyes” in the session.

name: You Described, We Archived: A Rich Audio Description Dataset
description: Explore the You Described, We Archived dataset, a set of volunteer audio description data. Learn what the data says about our volunteers, the quality of crowd sourced audio description and how funny cat videos can have a huge impact on AI and ML.

name: Creating a University Brand-Aligned and Accessible Website
abstract: Learn how Washington University in St. Louis uses a ‘self-service’ model multi-site WordPress installation to provide its students, staff, and faculty with a brand-aligned and fully accessible websites in a decentralized environment.
description:
Washington University in St. Louis wanted to provide its diverse community of students, staff, and faculty with web support in a decentralized environment. The challenge was to provide a university brand-aligned site to all eight schools that was not only accessible but could be maintained with limited support.
 
A ‘self-service’ solution was selected using a WordPress multi-site installation. WordPress is a popular open-source CMS (content management system). In the WordPress world a theme is what determines a website’s look and style. A WordPress theme was created to ensure use of brand-aligned colors, fonts, and logos. Accessible features were developed and tested to include sufficient contrast, link styles, and other features which allow site owners to start with an ‘out of the box’ accessible web site.
 
Accessibility features not implemented in the theme can be covered via instructional events and tutorial websites.
 
Since inception, over 3,000 websites have been created. Any university member can create their own website, all that’s needs it a valid digital login id (WUSTL key).

name: ARIA 1.1/1.2 - A Practical Perspective
abstract: In this session we'll review the checks you must go through before deciding whether to use an ARIA role or attribute, reveal our favorites, discuss the ones that need more user agent support, and show you how you can help us make it happen.
description:
We will start our presentation by covering what developers need to verify before they add an ARIA role or attribute to their code;
in particular the importance of making sure there is sufficient user agent support for that attribute to actually provide a solution.

Then we will briefly review our most and least useful attributes from ARIA 1.1, explain where there are significant support gaps, and present a list of browser and screen reader defects that have been filed in order to encourage the people in the audience to help promote those defects and close those gaps.

Time permitting, we will demonstrate 1 or 2 of those issues live during our presentation.

Finally we will reveal our short list of most exciting proposed attributes for ARIA 1.2 and beyond.

name: Tips for Getting Senior Executives On Board
abstract: In summary, both management and Accessibility SMEs within an organization will be on the same page and will want to collaborate to deploy an accessible, compliant, and usable solution.
description:
Many companies have the right intentions when approaching accessibility for their enterprises. They have done ample amounts of research on compliance, litigation, and ultimate fines that have been imposed on companies for non-compliance. Unfortunately, they have not provided a compelling enough message to senior management to decide to move forward or even to put together a strategy for compliance down the road.
Crawford Technologies has worked with the highest levels of management. We have provided consultative measures that accessibility departments can employ to deliver a compelling message to their management or sponsorship and support.
In the end, the audience will have a clear understanding of a strategy, message, and ultimate comfort level to present an accessibility message to their senior management.

name: Meet Glean: Simple, Effective Note Taking for Everyone
abstract: Learn all about Glean, the note taking tool that helps students take better notes. You’ll see how students can record class, take notes, generate a transcript, and more using Glean, creating a complete set of multimedia notes in the process.
description:
Meet Glean: a note taking tool that helps students capture and use spoken information effectively. Through interactive audio recording, students add labels, text notes, lecture slides, definitions, images and more to their workspace, creating a complete set of multimedia notes in the process. 

In this session, you will see a demo of Glean in action, and learn how your students could benefit from Glean. You’ll learn how:
- students can use Glean to record both in-person and online classes
- to take quick notes using labels and lightning mode
- to add context to notes with slides, images, and definitions into notes

name: Advances in Accessible Reading with Kindle
abstract: Kindle’s intentional focus on accessible reading experiences has led to features that can support positive reading outcomes for users with disabilities. Understand how to use available Kindle features to create personalized reading experience.
description: Terra Masiel, Sr. Product Manager with Books and Retail Accessibility, explains the unique considerations made when thinking about the accessibility of reading experiences and how Kindle features are designed to address the varied needs of users with disabilities as they engage with books. She will touch on features designed for customers who are blind, have low vision, or are second language learners. There will be a particular focus on those with learning disabilities or cognitive challenges and how Kindle can support their reading journeys. For example, if someone struggles with focus and concentration, what can we do to ease the burden of required reading? How are we addressing the needs of customers with light sensitivities? How do we support customers with dyslexia or who have ADHD? Terra will discuss how taking an intentional focus on the needs of customers with disabilities has created a better, more personalized reading experience for all.

name: Annotating Accessibility During Design- A Figma A11y Plugin
abstract: Learn how eBay designers are crafting a more accessible experience and catching more bugs before production by using efficient tooling for accessibility annotations inside their Figma design platform.
description:
Often, accessibility issues that could be resolved in the design stage end up in front of users. Designers do have an inclusive mindset but struggle with knowing how to start, what exactly they should be considering, or how to communicate the accessibility intent to engineers.

We created a Figma annotation tool for hand-off to engineers. It makes it easy to check if designs are accessible and helps designers to communicate through accessibility annotations. The plugin gives easy to follow steps that focus designers on considering the experience and increase their confidence about what is expected from a design accessibility spec. At the same time, the output annotations provide engineers the guidance they need for implementation.

The session will go through the context of how this project came about and why we chose to build a Figma plugin. There will be a detailed demonstration of how the tool works, outlining its benefits and how it fits into the design process.

name: Absentee Voting + Blind and Low Vision Voters
abstract: Absentee voting has boomed since the advent of COVID, yet it remains fundamentally inaccessible. This presentation synthesizes interviews with 12 blind and low vision voters and proposes user-focused design solutions to improve voting independence.
description:
To vote, bank or even grocery shop, blind and low vision people are often forced to disclose personal information to sighted intermediaries. This information could easily be weaponized, turning essential activities into high-risk scenarios.
Voting is a prime example of a high-risk scenario. In-person experiences generally require some amount of sighted assistance with a paper ballot. During the 2020 presidential election a surge in absentee voting, motivated by COVID-19, exposed a further gap in accessibility. Not a single state offers a fully independent absentee ballot for blind and low vision voters. I conducted interviews with 12 blind and low vision voters to better understand their experiences and their approach to the need for human assistance where options for independence are limited. This presentation puts the results in context and proposes user-focused design solutions for absentee voting and similar high-risk privacy scenarios.

name: The Future of Accessible Communications
abstract: Implementing Accessible Communications requires a strategy and an understanding of numerous accessible formats. We will discuss the best approach for success and how modern technology is changing the way we communicate in the future.
description:
Many organizations are beginning to realize that providing inclusivity and accessibility in communications is the right thing to do and should be considered for every mode of communication.

Many individuals are blind, have low vision, are deaf, hard of hearing, or have cognitive disabilities, and making information and communication inclusive is not only important but necessary and essential. Many organizations want a clear understanding of how accessibility can be handled, from awareness programs to complete remediation, accessibility training, and implementation. But how can this be accomplished, and how can it be done in a way that will continue to improve and evolve? It’s simple to establish a process that is flexible enough to handle whatever type of accessible communication is needed.

This session is aimed at individuals, organizations, and practitioners looking at accessibility at the beginner level. We will discuss how to get started, what channels of communication to consider, how to make them inclusive, and how to maintain a culture of inclusion for everyone.
We will discuss the following:
•What is Accommodation?
•What are the digital formats?
•What are the physical accommodation formats, and how do I generate accommodation formats?
•What do I require to implement this in my organization?
•How does planning accommodation now look like in the future?
•Why is it important to make all my enterprise communication accessible?

name: Beyond the Blockers: Making Online Course Content Accessible
abstract: Join accessibility consultants from Penn State World Campus as we explore new and emerging recommendations for making websites and online courses accessible for people with cognitive and learning disabilities.
description:
As accessibility consultants for Penn State’s online campus, we’ve found that with increased awareness around how to meet current WCAG requirements it’s time to challenge ourselves and our peers to look beyond the “blockers” and dive deeper into some of the less technical aspects of web accessibility. Our talk will focus on recommendations that can improve the web and online learning for people with a wide range of cognitive and learning disabilities.

name: Evolving the Design Process with Accessibility Annotations
abstract: Accessibility annotations enable teams to think deeper about user experiences in the design process. Learn how CVS Health is using annotations to change our culture and create a new wave of more accessible, inclusive, and usable digital products.
description:
CVS Health has started to adopt accessibility annotations in the digital design process. Doing so has had innumerable benefits on the enterprise and customer experiences. Thinking about annotations in the design process influenced the design philosophy, and teams made design decisions that were rarely considered prior. This has improved the experiences of our customers by making digital products more accessible, inclusive, and usable.

Join accessibility designers Daniel and Kevin in traversing CVS’s journey from relying solely on visual designs, to early adoption of annotations, all the way through to using annotations kits built for individual platforms.

See how documenting design intent at earlier stages improves the experiences of real people by encouraging deeper design thinking and reducing overall prevalence of defects caused by design and through bad designer-developer communication.

Learn how eventually tailoring accessibility annotations to each platform (Web, iOS, and Android), adds even more value and potential for evaluation to this toolset. By embracing the culture of platform-first design and development, teams are enabled to create products designed for the capabilities and assistive technologies of that platform, as well as the expectations of all the users who leverage them.

Ultimately come away with some general steps to follow within your own product organization, whatever stage of maturity it may be at or the size of your teams.

name: Baking Accessibility into Your Software Development Process
abstract: Developing software with accessibility in mind reduces accessibility bugs and ensures a highly accessible product. Whether you are an experienced software professional or a novice, this session will provide you with actionable steps on how to do so.
description:
Whether you are an experienced software professional or a student just learning how to code, it is important to know how to incorporate accessibility into your development process so that you can ensure your end product is accessible. By embedding good accessibility practices from the start in your development process, you can ensure a highly usable and accessible product to the one billion disabled people on this planet. Making accessibility a part of your development process does not guarantee zero accessibility bugs later in your product. However, it greatly reduces that number, improves your business and most importantly will make your diverse customers feel valued. 

This session will go over the importance of baking accessibility in your development process and provide steps on how to accomplish this. Attendees will learn about the importance of shifting accessibility testing early in the development process, and topics such as how to use and integrate accessibility code linters and automated accessibility tools in your code, some common web accessibility bugs, how to use browser’s accessibility tree for finding and fixing bugs, and how to perform basic manual accessibility testing. The presenter will also share some major do’s and don’ts when it comes to accessibility. Attendees will leave with a clear understanding of how to ensure maximum accessibility of their software product.

name: Accessible PDFs:  Creating Effective Training
abstract: Creating accessible PDF documents is essential to most organizations’ digital accessibility process. This presentation will review lessons learned from creating effective PDF accessibility training and how to implement a training program.
description:
Creating accessible PDF documents is an essential component of most organizations’ digital accessibility process. However, organizations often struggle to get their staff trained and efficient at creating accessible PDFs. This presentation will review lessons learned from creating effective PDF accessibility training and how these can be applied to other organizations. Identifying document creators within the organization and the types of documents being developed is the first step. Depending on the findings, both standard and advanced PDF remediation training may be required. 
Standard PDF accessibility training elements need to include:  
•	Understanding the WCAG requirements and how these impacts users of assistive technology. Demonstration of “before” and “after” remediation with a screen reader. 
•	Training on how PDF accessibility impacts an organization’s documents.
•	Creating accessible templates for the organization and training staff on the use of these templates. 
• How to structure documents for accessibility – starting with the source document. 
• How to convert to PDF. 
• How to test documents for accessibility. 
Advanced PDF accessibility training elements should be provided for key staff creating a wide variety of documents as well as digital accessibility champions. Advanced training may need to include: 
• Creating complex PDF tables.
• Creating fillable PDF forms. 
• Creating complex alternate text. 
• Advanced training on how to test documents.

name: Android Kiosk Accessibility & Usability
abstract: Learn how to configure JAWS Kiosk screen reader on your Android kiosk: welcome messages, gestures, key assignments, labeling elements, & language support, plus how to deploy across all kiosks in the enterprise.
description: When your kiosk is built on an Android Operating System, accessible kiosk application development is a critical step toward an accessible deployment. What can you do to make sure your Android Kiosk is built with accessibility and usability in mind? Learn about the latest in Android screen reading technology and how to use it for your new or existing Android kiosk project.

name: What Every Beginner Should Know About Document Accessibility
abstract: We will discuss the most common questions we get as people enter the field of document accessibility. Be sure to tune in to learn what Chad and Dax recommend to keep from being overwhelmed and you won’t want to miss them talk about their go-to tools that help speed up their workflow.

name: Accessible Shopping via Voice with Amazon Alexa
abstract: In this session we will give an overview of new   Alexa functionalities that can enable customers with disabilities to shop independently: asking product questions, ordering groceries and other everyday items, and collaborating with family members.
description:
Alexa is changing the way people shop, whether it’s providing reminders to reorder frequently purchased items, sharing product information that enables customers to ask questions, capturing needs for everyone in the household on a Shopping List by voice (or text), checking prices and more.

Voice makes shopping accessible for many customers with disabilities and especially for aging customers who can more easily complete tasks independently or seek help from a family caregiver.

In this session we will give an overview and demonstrate new Alexa functionalities that customers with disabilities can use: from asking product questions, ordering groceries and other everyday items, and collaborating with friends or family members. This is a non-technical talk designed to appeal to a broad audience. We will discuss both in-store shopping experiences   as well as shopping from home.

This presentation will include a discussion of shopping through Echo devices, the Alexa App, and the Amazon App.

name: Imagining the Future of Assistive Tech Investments at OSEP
abstract: This session explores trends in the Office of Special Education Programs’ previous discretionary grant funding. Participants will have the opportunity to provide feedback and insights to inform considerations for future funding and policy priorities.
description:
The U.S. Department of Education’s Office of Special Education Programs (OSEP), Research to Practice Division (RTP), coordinates discretionary grant programs under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). Program Specialists from RTP are content area experts who serve as project officers for a range of federal investments.
Specialists will begin the session by discussing trends and influences in OSEP's projects, focusing on the work of Educational Technology Media and Materials Program (ETechM2). This program is the primary source of support for accessible technology and media-related activities under IDEA. The ETechM2 improves results for learners with disabilities by promoting the development, demonstration, and use of technology with learners and in personnel preparation; supporting activities designed to be of educational value in the classroom; providing support for captioning/description; and providing accessible educational materials.
The session will highlight ways in which the Department has responded to the needs of the field in its technology investments. Following the updates from OSEP, participants will be engaged in a discussion of needs/concerns regarding future funding and policy priorities. This information will support specialists in aligning their work with needs in the field.
Specialists will conclude with recommendations and resources for the audience to continue engagement which will inform OSEP and other local, state, and federal offices.

name: National Coding Symposium: TVIs and Students with BLVI
abstract: Coding is inherently accessible for students of every age and ability. Join us to learn about the National Coding Symposium and Day of Code. Discover ways to increase students’ success in programming related fields. Resources: lesson plans/activities
description:
In May 2020, the American Printing House (APH) in partnership with California School f/t Blind (CSB) hosted the first ever virtual National Coding Symposium for students who are blind or visually impaired. The continued success led to the creation of an annual event. 
Building on that success, APH and CSB, along with Center for Cybersecurity Research & Education (CCRE) and the Center for Assistive Technology Training (CATT), are planning a Day of Code to be combined with the annual National Coding Symposium.
Coding is fun, challenging, and inherently accessible across platforms and skill levels. Students of every age benefit from learning to code. This symposium aims to inspire students to become leaders in careers inclusive of and related to programming and software development and to provide teachers with the resources and support they need to teach coding concepts with ease.
During this session, we will discuss and share: 
*Successes and lessons learned from previous Coding Symposiums
*Benefits of learning to code for students who are blind or visually impaired
*Challenges facing students and teachers
*Resources from previous symposiums including lesson plans, activities, and recorded videos for use by teachers and students
*Advantages of making connections with blind programmers and others in careers associated with coding at companies such as Apple, Amazon, Google, Yahoo, etc.
*The plan for Day of Code to be a national event 
No knowledge of coding is needed to benefit.

name: An Animal Sound Onomatopoeia System That is Fun to Watch
description: We will introduce an application system of animal sound onomatopoeia, which allows users to view animal images linked to creative onomatopoeia. We will present an evaluation of the prototype by hearing-impaired university students and future issues.

name: Virtual Reality for NeuroRehabilitation
abstract: This course provides an introductory education on VR terminology and technology with a further breakdown of the fundamental principles and intervention strategies currently being utilized with virtual reality in neurorehabilitation.
description: This session will overview virtual reality as a whole from it's earliest use in research to today. The speakers will discuss key terms used to describe VR with definitions provided. The speakers will provide research-based concepts for key development of virtual reality technology for neurorehabilitation. The efficacy of VR in neurorehabilitation will be discussed. Lastly, the speakers will elaborate on their experience with using VR in practice for patient-specific treatments along with documentation examples.

name: American Printing House for the Blind Low Vision Roadmap
abstract: Low vision technology that is customizable and anticipates a person’s needs is important for lifelong success. Learn how APH’s long-term technology plan incorporates intuitive solutions that develop transferable skills for persons with low vision.
description:
APH continually seeks to develop and improve upon its roadmap for high-tech low vision devices. Innovations in technology, changes to tools and processes in education, and evolving needs of students necessitate long-term planning. Through research, surveys, and strategic partnerships, APH aims to ensure that students with low vision have the necessary technology to be successful.  

Attend this session to identify which current and future APH products can help to optimize sensory efficiency and align with instructional activities. Participants will learn about our innovative approach to ensure that our technology builds transferable technical skills while providing access to the curriculum and independent living tasks. Discover what innovations APH will incorporate in technology in the next five years.  

The presenters will demonstrate how to complete educational and independent living tasks with current high-tech low vision devices built by APH. They will also detail processes used to develop technology through informational instruction. Finally, they will provide a preview of a desktop tablet and handheld magnifier that are in development.

name: Learning Through Play with LEGO Braille Bricks
abstract: Through interactive brick-based activities, participants will play and have fun whilst learning about Learning through Play approach using LEGO Braille Bricks. Participants will explore and experience first-hand what is so special about play.
description:
LEGO Braille Bricks is a playful tool to teach braille to blind and visually impaired children. It allows children with blindness not only learn braille and acquire academic skills through play, but also be able to play with peers who do not have a visual impairment.
The pedagogical concept, based on National Education, Expanded Core Curricula and built on Learning Through Play principles ensures an optimal teaching and learning experience that empowers children to become creative, engaged,
lifelong learners. By unlocking the power of play, children can develop the broad set of skills they need to thrive and succeed in the 21st century.
Learning braille is crucial for blind and visually impaired children as it allows them to develop a variety of essential life skills ensuring they experience intellectual freedom, independence and equal access to education and work. The concept presents a groundbreaking and inclusive opportunity to teach blind, visually impaired and sighted children alongside each other by offering a fun and playful way to engage, interact and learn together.
With this practical workshop - PRE BRAILLE and SCHOOL AGED - participants will get a good overview of this new concept and will be ready to try it with their visually impaired students. It will be based on different activities, adapted to the two school levels.
This hands-on session will illustrate Learning through Play in practice using LEGO Braille Bricks.

name: PDF Remediation the Easy Way
abstract: There is a misconception that providing accessible documents is expensive and time-consuming. However, when done properly, it is the opposite and can provide organizations with an edge.
description:
Document accessibility isn’t a new concept, but there’s something that has been changing, especially within the last decade, it is becoming more and more the standard and less and less the exception, and the cost for being non-compliant has reached substantial amounts. Organizations realize how important it is to make customer-facing information accessible, compliant, and usable, and because of this, they are learning to incorporate document accessibility into their daily routines. For many, this is still a new concept, and therefore need help understanding the importance of having a document accessibility workflow in place.
This session will describe the various methods used to remediate documents and make them accessible, usable, and compliant. This includes:
•AccessibilityNOW Transactional – This Crawford Technologies solution set component allows clients to automatically tag their documents using AccessibilityNOW Designer and provides an automated way to make high-volume, statement-like applications accessible, compliant, and usable.
•AccessibilityNOW Publisher – This component automates the PDF tagging process for a high volume of static PDF files. It can be run automated under a workflow or RPA system or called through an API. It can achieve completion rates of up to 90%, significantly reducing the time required to make documents accessible.
•AccessibilityNOW Remediate – This offers users a fast and easy way of tagging PDF

name: Indoor Navigation for All
abstract: Learn how emerging indoor navigation technologies can make buildings and public venues accessible for everyone.
description: GoodMaps is a digital mapping company that uses LiDAR (3D laser scanning), image recognition and positioning technology for precise turn-by-turn navigation indoors, which is especially challenging for people who are blind or visually impaired with no access to print signs. Learn how emerging indoor navigation technologies can make buildings and public venues accessible for everyone. From basic orientation to step-by-step directions, the GoodMaps’ application enables all users to discover and navigate the built environment independently.

name: Deploying Managers as Advocates of Accessible Content
abstract: Maximize your enterprise’s digital content compliance by turning managers into accessibility advocates. Steady, strategic relationships with team managers produce team-tailored accessibility efforts, reducing drain on accessibility specialists.
description: Digital accessibility teams in large enterprises often struggle with how to deploy their limited resources. How can such teams improve the accessibility of all enterprise content when it seems impossible to even identify everyone who is creating content? Rather than focus at the individual employee level, The Digital Accessibility Team at Kent State University chose to methodically interview the supervisors of content-creating teams to understand their workflows and develop curated but low-maintenance training and new standard operating procedures. When managers become the key point of contact to the Digital Accessibility team, it extends the principle of accessibility being every employee’s responsibility and frees accessibility specialists to focus on higher quality training of fewer people. Through the manager’s involvement, the accessibility information and best practices become team-specific and have immediate application, increasing employee engagement. This process establishes mid-level managers as accessibility advocates, modeling and expecting the inclusion of accessibility practices in all stages of content creation. Kent State’s Digital Accessibility team will show how they provided pre-recorded trainings then coached managers on practice sessions and team standards. This process is universally effective with webmasters, marketers, social media creators, educational/library resource material curators, and digital graphic designers.

name: Leveraging Technology and Universal Design for Learning
abstract: Creating a culture for inclusive learning is challenging! Ally is a technology tool that improves the accessibility of teaching and learning artifacts. Learn about how we scaled our support across campus as part of this change management project.
description:
Implementing an effective inclusive learning initiative might be a new or unfamiliar process. Creating buy-in from campus leadership, creating faculty awareness, redesigning courses, and tracking progress are just a few of the steps necessary to help drive a cultural shift in how faculty approach accessibility and universal design. How do institutions prioritize their efforts for universal design for learning? What impact does professional development for faculty have on accessible course materials? It is critical for universities to shift to meet the needs of a variety of students. This includes race, social class, ethnicity, cognitive differences, gender, families, and many more. At the university level we should embrace these changes and take steps toward believing that diversity makes us stronger. If we believe that working to make changes, to create pathways for all students to be successful, and to provide rigorous content is important then we must take that step.  UDL is a platform for building that step; for raising people up, expanding opportunity, and creating an environment for divergent thinking. And at its core, this is what a university should be providing its students. For many universities, implementing an effective inclusive learning initiative may be a new or unfamiliar process. Creating buy-in from campus leadership, creating faculty awareness, and tracking progress are just a few of the steps necessary to help drive a cultural shift.

name: Using JAWS Inspect and JAWS Connect for Testing
abstract: Creating inclusive experiences for JAWS screen reader users can be challenging. This talk will provide an overview of how to include JAWS users in your accessibility program.
description: End users and their assistive technologies are often excluded from accessibility testing. This demonstration will walk you through how to integrate JAWS testing and JAWS user feedback into your accessibility program using tools developed for this purpose.

name: Digital Accessibility in Directed Labor Applications
abstract: Increase nonoffice job opportunities for people with disabilities by cohesively evaluating warehouse devices and applications for accessibility. Investigate how structure and typical best practices become the barriers they were designed to prevent.
description:
Most digital accessibility conversations cover web experiences where a user is navigating through an interface to complete a goal, such as an online shopping experience, email client or a project management tool. Landmarks, headings, and structure guidance from best practices support the discretionary use of these web tools. However, in a nonoffice work setting, like an inventory picker, or packaging orders into boxes, a user follows directions and prompts from the application to execute the manual work. In these cases, the workers performance is often measured on how many items they can pick, or orders they can box. The nature of the human-application interaction is foundationally different than one which is user directed. To make a computer driven application accessible requires extra evaluation on the application and all contributing factors to the overall task begin completed. The surroundings may not be a quiet space and the primary input devices may not be a keyboard or keyboard alternative. 

What is possible when accessibility means all workers can perform at the same efficiency?  Changing your team’s implementation of accessibility best practices when the application is not a user directed experience can increase nonoffice work opportunities for people with disabilities. 

Investigate how structure and typical best practices can become the barriers they were designed to prevent and why devices and applications demand cohesion to make warehouse technology accessible.

name: Technology Use by Hearing Impaired for Social Inclusion
abstract: The session will enable you to understand the real situation of hearing impaired persons in Pakistan regarding digital technology and social inclusion. Attendee will get comparative view of technology skills of hearing impaired persons in Pakistan.
description: Presently hearing-impaired adolescents are not alien to the world. The limitation in hearing reflects in their communication ability that impacts their personality including social skills. There are various methods to help them in developing their social skills. The use of ICT is one of the methods used for social inclusion. The central purpose of the study was to explore the use of various digital technological aids for the social inclusion of adolescents with hearing impairment in general society.  A cross-section survey design was followed to gather data from a sample of 85 SWHI (both male and female) from graduate and post-graduate levels and their 50 teachers. Two structured questionnaires were developed; one for SWHI and the other for their teachers. Experts validated the instrument concerning content and construct validity. Cronbach alpha reliability of the instruments was .85. The collected data were analyzed using descriptive and inferential statistics. The study revealed that the use of digital devices has added great value in integrating SWHI in general society. However, the lack of availability of the latest technology has slowed down their inclusion. No significant difference has been found in the use of technology based on gender and academic grade of students. The study recommended the provision of the latest technology and teachers' training to use digital devices for teaching hearing-impaired students.

name: Access Denied:  Implications of Unequal Access to Technology
abstract: According to the Center for Disease Control there are more than 61 million people living with disabilities in the United States. Access to assistive technology for people with disabilities can be the difference between dependence verses independence.
description: Access to assistive technology plays a key role in allowing individuals with disabilities to work, live, and play in their community. Therefore, Center for independent living and university staff play a vital role in overcoming attitudinal barriers, identifying the correct assistive technology, finding funding, and advocating for needed training. When people with disabilities are denied access to assistive technology, it leads to increased outcomes of unemployment, not pursuing education, isolation, and reliance on others to perform tasks. The Assistive Technology Affordability Act, expanding existing assistive technology programs, and introducing assistive technology at an earlier age are just a few of the tools needed to turn the tide towards granting access for individuals with disabilities.

name: Aira Everywhere for Every Workplace
abstract: The need for access to visual information is an essential part of many jobs. Aira, the visual interpreting service, has expanded its availability over the past year on a number of devices. This session explores how visual interpreting fits into the workplace.
description:
Aira is committed to helping organizations build a more inclusive workplace. As we continue to innovate and collaborate with both mainstream and assistive technology partners, one thing drives us, and that is access to visual information is a right and as a right, access should be within reach of everyone.

 In July 2022 we introduced Aira Everywhere, addressing the needs of our customers to have access to our professional visual interpreters on a range of devices. The effort began internally with the public beta of our Aira for Desktop solution. Next we released Aira for the Envision  Glasses, returning a hands-free wearable to the market. And then we brought Aira to the Blind Shell Classic 2 phone, providing access for people who prefer tactile buttons rather than a touch screen experience. Our tool is designed for broad applicability, supporting a range of skills, regardless of someone’s  competence with technology.  

With access to professional visual interpreters on a range of devices, how do you know what will work for your employees? In this workshop we will highlight use cases from a variety of industries to demonstrate that the answer is fluid and depends on the individual employee. You will learn how Aira is a ‘ready for work’ productivity tool.

By offering Aira’s visual interpreting service, your organization can create a continuum of accessibility, and support the employment lifecycle from job seeking to job accommodation to career advancement.

name: Do-It-Yourself AT: 3D Printing and Other Maker Solutions
abstract: Learn to 3D print! With repositories of freely available assistive technology that can be 3D printed, learn where to find files, how to print them yourself, and where you can find support in making your own 3D printed assistive devices.
description:
The emergence of affordable fabrication technology (3D printers) enables low cost and custom solutions to be made to address the particular needs of people with disabilities.

Integrating 3D design and other maker technologies, such as micro controllers or hardware store supplies, can enable many solutions to be quickly and affordably made.

The session will explore repositories of 3D printed solutions and communities of practice that support 3D printing to address health, medical, and occupational therapy issues. Attendees will be able to consider possible innovations, opportunities, and risks when bringing 3D printed assistive technologies into occupational therapy practices.

In the session, participants will be walked through how to download a 3D printing file, how to prepare it for printing, and how to load it onto a 3D printer. Assuming the session is face-to-face, a 3D printer will be in the session so participants can see how it works and “demystify” the technology. At the session, there will be numerous 3D printed aids on hand, that participants will be able to look through to raise their awareness of available solutions that can be affordably made.

AT Professionals will be aware of repositories of openly available accommodations, best practices when considering 3D printed accommodations, as well as how to contribute and apply their professional knowledge to provide informed input into the development of these emerging technologies.

name: Triangulate Stakeholder Perceptions of Disability Services
