name: Enabling Effective Learning Online for Screen Reader Users
abstract: Making online learning accessible involves inclusive design of technology, content, pedagogy and community. In this session, I will share my perspectives as a screen reader user about designing online learning that works well for screen reader users.
description:
Enabling effective learning online involves the inclusive use of educational technology, learning experiences and teaching practices, together with a connected community. This is especially important when you have learners using assistive technologies, especially screen readers. 

As a native screen reader user, I will share points in this session that are critical to designing online learning for screen reader users. I will also highlight how such design provides a “curb-cut” advantage to all learners. 

To begin with, learning technologies must work with screen readers. For that to happen those technologies must align with accessibility standards. This could also make these learning technologies more usable with other assistive technologies. 

Next, the learning materials must be created keeping non-visual access in mind. This requires that content creators are aware of the needs of screen reader users. If not, they would be introducing barriers to learning. 

Further, the teaching practices must be inclusive. This involves making the curriculum, instruction, and assessment usable by learners with diverse needs. 

Finally, it will be easier for everyone if they work together as a community and learn from one another.

In summary, inclusive design of technology, content, pedagogy, and community is critical to making online learning accessible. Even if one of these components is not accessible, the learning experience will not be accessible.

name: Co-Designing Accessible Insulin Pumps
abstract: Co-design approach was used to identify and refine the design features of an accessible insulin pump.
description:
Diabetic retinopathy is the leading cause of blindness in Canada with the risk of blindness being 25 times greater for individuals with diabetic retinopathy. Vision problems and blindness associated with diabetic retinopathy can be prevented or mitigated with the proper control of blood sugar and blood pressure, yet, established methods for measuring and mediating such physiological states have proved inaccessible for the visually impaired community. 
Insulin pump therapy is a type of diabetes treatment offering insulin infusions rather than multiple daily insulin injections. However, for individuals who are partially sighted, deafblind, or blind and live with diabetes, the features of an insulin pump have not been designed as universally accessible.Using an online survey, we next examined the accessibility barriers experienced by Canadians with sight loss and diabetes in use of insulin pump devices. Insulin pumps currently offered on the Canadian market are not accessible for those who are visually impaired. The majority of pump users require the assistance of sighted individuals to safely and adequately use their devices. This research identified many accessibility problems with current pumps such as a lack of haptic feedback (i.e. vibrations), a lack of tactile feedback (i.e. buttons designed for accessibility), and a lack of sufficient audio feedback and visual feedback. Our findings clearly highlight distress due to inaccessibility of these devices.

name: Collaboration and Productivity: Google Workspace and JAWS
abstract: Are you using Google Docs to collaborate in real-time? Want to learn how to write and edit documents in this Google Workspace application with JAWS? We’ll show you how to turn on accessibility settings in Docs, plus create, open, and share documents.
description:
"Are you using Google Workspace apps? Have you seen the Google applications work in real-time with a Powerful screen reader like JAWS? Want to learn more about how you can write, edit, and collaborate on documents from anywhere?
In this session, we introduce you to Google Docs, describe its layout, demonstrate its features, and provide useful shortcuts to improve your user experience.
Whether you use it at home, at school, or at work, you’ll benefit from this task-based training highlighting important editing and formatting tools that make document creation and collaboration possible with this popular application.
we will show you how to:

•	Turn on the Screen reader and Braille Support using keyboard commands
•	Create and open documents
•	Collaborate with other users
•	Get help in Google Docs and access a list of keyboard commands
•	Share a Google Doc using JAWS

name: Video Accessibility - Captions, ASL and Descriptive Audio
abstract: People communicate in different ways, in other languages, and with unique abilities. Everyone has something to say, needs to be understood, and your organization wants to listen, help, and understand. Learn how you can easily do this.
description:
As our world advances in making documents and websites accessible, other areas are also starting to pick up speed in terms of accessible and inclusive communication, such as video, ASL, and descriptive audio. However, some organizations and enterprises are not familiar with implementing these channels. They have difficulty developing a functioning and sustainable process to deliver information in whatever accessible format an end user requests.

Waiting for captioning or descriptive audio to be added to an existing video, waiting for verification of said captioning and audio to make sure the interpretation is correct, or waiting for someone who knows ASL to interpret a conversation, all of which could take hours, days, or longer is not acceptable and can result in severe repercussions. To avoid this, measures must be implemented to ensure communication flows freely, accurately, and promptly.

In this session, we will discuss how it is possible to build a cost-effective, successful, and viable system, delivering immediately accessible communication to whoever requests it on demand. For those familiar with science fiction, think of Star Trek’s universal translator, but going even further, a translator that provides language interpretations and can deliver accessible and accurate forms of communication.

name: Sharing Android Util Class for Improving Accessibility
abstract: Compared to other platforms, Android view systems are more cumbersome to implement element role and state information accessibility. To solve this problem, we introduce the util class we created.
description:
Screen reader users could not visually check the layout of the screen, the style of each element, and rely solely on the information that the screen reader reads. Therefore, the text of each element the screen reader reads, as well as the element role and state information, are essential to understanding the context of each element.
 We recommend developers to use native controls instead of custom controls to implement accessibility. Nevertheless, custom controls are used for many reasons, and each platform provides its own API for implementing accessibility to these custom controls.
 In the case of web/iOS/flutter/react-native/android jetpack compose, changing or adding proper role or state is very easy and need just little code.
However, with the android view system, changing accessibility role or state is not easy, because each custom controls need to implement AccessibilityDelegate, and we should override onInitializeAccessibilityNodeInfo to set or change role or state.
 So we created useful util class for android view system accessibility. Inside this class, there are most short code that change or set accessibility role, state with just one line.
  Also we added some useful methods such as accessibilityValue, more short code for detecting TalkBack, and send accessibility focus with some delay.
  Applying this will util class will significantly reduce development time for accessibility issues.
So I want to share this class and explain how to apply.

description: An overview of NVDA, the free and open-source screen reader for Windows.  Details of recent improvements to NVDA, and a sneak peek at upcoming feature improvements. name: Accessibility for PDF Documents
abstract: Do you encounter PDF documents frequently in your work? Attendees will see a demonstration of document remediation, including adding metadata, adding and editing tags, reviewing reading and tab order and completing a final accessibility review.
description:
In this presentation, we will teach attendees how to produce accessible PDF documents. We will begin by discussing how to optimize accessibility in a variety of source document formats and then convert the document to PDF to preserve accessibility features.  Once in the PDF format, we will review accessibility features found in Adobe Acrobat Pro. Attendees will see a demonstration of document remediation, including adding metadata, adding and editing tags, reviewing reading and tab order and completing a final accessibility review. By the end of the session, attendees will be able to produce their own accessible PDF documents.

name: Building an Accessibility Program from the Ground Up
abstract: Based on our own experience, we will cover the essential steps for starting, developing, and maintaining an in-house digital/software/web accessibility program to remediate, maintain, and improve the accessibility of digital products in ICT fields.
description:
Historically, accessibility remediation of digital products (software, websites) has been an afterthought for companies operating in the information and communications technology (ICT) fields. As a result, such companies have mostly relied on third parties (consultants) for accessibility audits and remediation of their products, often treating accessibility issues as one-time problems that can be solved once and forgotten.

However, accessibility remediation and maintenance of digital products is a process and a long-term endeavor. Therefore, it is more beneficial (and often more economical) for companies to develop in-house resources and talent to be able to continuously maintain and improve the accessibility of their digital products.

An Accessibility Program, consisting of representatives of key stakeholders, including product development and support groups, can act as a hub of activity for providing accessibility audits, advocacy, training, remediation support, and progress reporting to internal and external stakeholders.

The Accessibility Program at MathWorks, over its five years of existence, progressed from being an accessibility audit group to providing technical support for software development teams, and to promoting accessibility innovations applicable to our MATLAB product family.

We will present the evolution of the Accessibility Program at MathWorks and how its basic steps, policies, and procedures can be applied in similar corporate settings in ICT fields.

name: Taptilo K: Braille Learning Keyboard with Educational App
abstract: Teachers and officials will get to know Taptilo K an affordable and efficient braille Bluetooth keyboard. Taptilo K's efficiency in braille learning also will be introduced by the data gathered from students who joined the pilot project with the app.
description:
The presentation will introduce Taptilo K and its efficiency through a pilot project's result to teachers and organization officials. Taptilo K is a Perkins-styled keyboard that is affordable and efficient for the blind and visually impaired. OHFA Tech investigated a big gap in braille writing: the traditional writing method, and the braille notetaker. Students need to stick to the traditional braille writing method before getting the braille notetakers. To fill the gap, Taptilo K has been developed.
The Taptilo app could be connected with Taptilo K via Bluetooth. When the students or the teachers tap the content on the screen, the Taptilo app will read the word. The students can type it and check the answer by themselves. The app provides customized lessons so anyone can create a list so that personalized learning is available. 
Taptilo K will be developed as a braille keyboard so anyone can type braille and create a digital document. The documents made by Taptilo K will be able to be printed, shared through the app, or translated into printed letters.  
Taptilo K is now on the pilot project that has proceeded in Jakarta, Indonesia with the public school for the blind. The project is provided by KOICA (Korea International Cooperation Agency). Students proceed with braille learning with Taptilo K and the app. After the class, the assignments are given via the app so the learning progress will be checked every month. The result gathered through 12 weeks also will be shown.

name: DeafBlind Technology Myths
abstract: Can DeafBlind use technology? How can technology support DeafBlind? This session will debunk some of the common misconceptions about DeafBlind and their ability to access and use technology. We will share challenges and successes.
description: This session will focus on debunking some common misconceptions of DeafBlind peoples and the use of technology. We’ll look at common routines performed by DeafBlind and the technology needed to successfully perform these tasks. Some of these tasks consist of morning routines such as waking up, making breakfast, etc., using technology to perform tasks at work, basic communication, traveling, and overall access to technology. Discussion will also include resources to obtain these items. Moreover, we will look at companies that have designed hardware and software specifically for DeafBlind. We’ll also look at mainstream tech companies making their devices accessible to all. In addition, share personal narratives and technology challenges by DeafBlind folks. Ultimately, answering how can technology support DeafBlind?

name: The Inclusive Closed Captions Iceberg
abstract: Closed caption can be easily created, but do your users have a good experience? This presentation will discuss how inclusion is different from compliance, common mistakes to avoid when creating closed caption, and proposed solutions for inclusion.
description:
Creating closed caption might seem like a straightforward task. In practice, you need to be more intentional to create the best experience for users using closed caption. We will reflect this sentiment through the discussion on compliance versus inclusion (the iceberg metaphor); we will discuss how inclusive closed caption can benefit all users, not just users with disabilities. Then, we will highlight common mistakes that can worsen the user enjoyment of closed caption through sample videos. At the same time, we will propose recommended solution to overcome these common mistakes. 

After the presentation, attendees should feel confident in preventing potential barriers for users consuming your closed caption. This presentation is useful for content creators who want the same experience for all people when viewing video content, while seasoned accessibility pros will get good reminders as well. 

Long has delivered over 200 technical trainings for Fortune 500 clients. He is also the creator of the current Design training curriculum at Level, which has an average rating of 4.7 out of 5 and covers closed caption in Multimedia Accessibility. Owen is the video accessibility Subject Matter Expert at Level Access. He is the go-to expert for consultation on video player, platform, and content accessibility. He is a core contributor to the video.js open-source web video player framework, helping to make it one of the most accessible, broadly used HTML video players online.

name: Align WCAG to Organizational Roles to Achieve Accessibility
abstract: Accessibility is a team effort. Accessible content is often left to a few people and possibly just a single individual! Learn the steps to create an effective organizational policy and how to align all team members toward the same accessibility goal.
description:
Accessibility policies help document and align an organization’s commitment to accessible content and helps all team members understand the company’s accessibility goals and milestones. However, organizations commonly face a few problems. First, the W3C’s Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) can be vague and complex. Second, WCAG is primarily developer focused and doesn’t provide enough details for designers and QA teams. Therefore, solving these problems involves two steps: 

1) Creating a common set of objective requirements for each WCAG Success Criteria.
2) Identify the unique roles that wireframe designers, copy authors, programmers, and testers within the organization each play to accomplish those requirements.

This presentation will review some compelling benefits to this approach. Knowing what is required for each role that is part of the web content lifecycle also allows for organizations to provide more effective and targeted training…at less cost! Each team member in the lifecycle is now also accountable for their piece of the puzzle and if a piece is missing, team members will know where to look to obtain those details instead of making assumptions or even worse…doing nothing!

name: Accessible Smart SVGs for the Digitally-Inclusive Age
abstract: Make websites, marketing materials, and digital graphics more accessible with smart SVGs and human-crafted alt text. Smart SVGs are WCAG AAA shape-shifting files that change in size, layout, and color to help users tailor their digital experience.
description:
Part 1: SVGs and the Future of Digital Graphics (Heather)

SVGs are responsive and adaptive designs. For internet users with low vision or other impairments who rely on WCAG SC 1.4.8, SVGs offer a superior experience over JPEGs and PNGs. Part 1 of this session introduces how SVGs work with assistive technologies and scale beautifully, responding to dark mode, contrast themes, and screen sizes. SVGs are made from code, work in EPUB/native apps, load instantly (saving energy), and include descriptions, metadata, animation, and interactive features such as audio. 

Part 2: How to Write Artistic Alt Text for SVGs (Caroline)

We hear the same alt text tips again and again - keep it short, be specific, don’t interpret. Many of these tips don’t fit with describing works of art. Crafting artistic “text alternatives” often means breaking rules. Part 2 explores how to write for the ears and imagination and deliver alt text users can feel and experience. Learn to take SVG alt text from basic to beautiful with a humanistic approach that breaks down the visual barriers to digital art.

Part 3: Advantages of Accessible SVGs (Paul)

An SVG placed directly in a webpage’s HTML code has more accessibility options than raster images which only have alt-text. SVGs have title and description elements and screen reader-friendly semantic HTML embedded directly in the file. Part 3 explains how to combine these elements with ARIA roles and attributes to expand the accessibility of smart SVGs.

name: Company Culture and Digital Accessibility
abstract: Building momentum for an organization’s digital accessibility program can come from Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion efforts. When everyone understands the importance and the impact they can make, true progress can happen.
description: Digital Accessibility is important to ensure an organization effectively reaches its existing audience and potential audience. However, if digital accessibility isn’t understood across an organization, it can result in difficult discussions around prioritizing remediation and ongoing activities that are required. However, if digital accessibility, and at a broader level accessibility in general, is understood and part of an organization’s DNA and part of its overall Diversity, Equity and Inclusion efforts, the work required around digital accessibility will be understood and embraced by all, rather than being something that might be easily deprioritized.

name: The Knowledge and How to Get It
abstract: TPGi established a Knowledge Center with a team dedicated to building and maintaining the KnowledgeBase of digital accessibility information their auditors, testers, engineers, designers, developers, and clients rely on.
description:
When TPGi set up a team of people dedicated to collecting and disseminating information about digital accessibility, we looked at many models. 

One of the most interesting had nothing to do with the digital world and even less to do with accessibility for people with disabilities.
For 150 years, London taxi drivers have had to learn The Knowledge, the only way to get licensed to drive the city's famous Black Cabs. 
After several years familiarizing themselves with 25,000 streets, they must pass “the hardest test in the world”, verbally describing fiendish routes from memory. 
Today, GPS is used by the mini-cabs that compete with the Black Cabs. Yet the Black Cabs persist with The Knowledge and they continue to thrive. Why? Because there's more to knowledge than just data.
TPGi has established a Knowledge Center with a team dedicated to building and maintaining the digital accessibility knowledge that auditors, testers, engineers, designers, developers, and clients rely on.
We produce and constantly review articles, design patterns, recommendations for automated and manual testing results, training modules, technical solutions, best practices and contextual guidance related to digital accessibility. 
  
Our team of highly experienced digital accessibility professionals puts the focus not just on data, or even information - we share knowledge about digital accessibility that is practical, reliable and usable in the real world.

This talk will tell you how.

name: Establishing a Digital Accessibility Program at a Large Enterprise
abstract: Monica Goel discusses understanding a business’s risks and compliance requirements, establishing an accessibility policy, inclusive design program, accessibility design system, and engineering practice, the importance of ensuring the accessibility team is diverse and inclusive, as well as building out accessibility test standards and methodology, accessibility conformance reporting, and customer and colleague support.
description:
Monica Goel, Executive Director of Digital Accessibility at CVS Health, will discuss understanding a business’s risks and compliance requirements, establishing an accessibility policy, inclusive design program, accessibility design system, and engineering practice, the importance of ensuring the accessibility team is diverse and inclusive, as well as building out accessibility test standards and methodology, accessibility conformance reporting, and customer and colleague support. 
 
Monica Goel is an executive with 30+ years in information technology. Today she leads the CVS Health Accessibility Program, responsible for ensuring digital assets, products, and services are accessible to colleagues and customers with disabilities.

name: Hamilton CapTel Solutions for Connecting
abstract: Since 2003, Hamilton® CapTel® has made more than 250 million captioned telephone conversations possible for people with hearing loss. With options for at home, work or while on the go - Hamilton CapTel has a solution to keep you connected!

name: Person Centered Access for the Deaf & Hard of Hearing
abstract: Deaf, Deaf-Blind, and Hard of Hearing people, like any other population, are diverse in ethnicity, education, and backgrounds. Sharing best practices helps to bridge the gap in how we communicate and support those individuals.
description: Too many times in accessibility the needs of the person are assessed without considering the scope, environment, and variables required to deliver an accommodation. Interpreting certifications and requirements vary from state to state. Captioning technology (human/speech recognition/AI) is evolving and changing. How can decision-makers be expected to evaluate the qualifications of an interpreter or measure the accuracy of a captioner? It’s an impossible task for so many professionals in a disabilities support role. With increased workloads and limited staffing, the challenges continue to grow. Being a subject matter expert in dozens of disabilities is almost impossible. Recognition is the first step! Sharing best practices for the Deaf and Hearing community will build a foundation for understanding how to best communicate. Sign language users often will nod their heads to indicate understanding of what is being said. This does not indicate they agree with what is being said. While this may seem basic, hearing people often make assumptions and are simply not equipped. Deaf people have their own culture that is different from the majority culture — that is, the hearing/speaking culture. Like other communities, differences in cultures can influence interactions and communication. Deaf, Deaf-Blind, and Hard of Hearing people, like any other population, are diverse in ethnicity, education, and backgrounds. There is not one-size-fits-all approach.

name: Rethink Image Descriptions for a Better Learning Experience
abstract: When your audience needs to learn, not just be informed, text alternatives must be written with extra considerations in mind. Apply this session's approach to increase the value of your descriptions for your learners.
description:
In this session we will discuss how standard guidelines for writing text alternatives to media need to be adjusted for use in materials for education to consider cognitive load, informational density, an increased understanding of “context and purpose,” and more.  
Images (& videos) are of critical importance in digital learning materials. Media can add variety & engagement, provide an example without needing an explanation, present massive amounts of information while making it easy to process, & more. But this is only true for those who can perceive the media. It is often difficult to determine which of an image's "thousand words" are what a learner needs to be on equal footing with their peers.
Unfortunately, most a11y guidelines focus on images in informational online materials such as newspaper articles & standard websites or videos for entertainment. While the underlying principles defining good alt text & video descriptions are the same in an informational context & an educational one, there are also fundamental differences. What students get out of our media is critical. Informational density is higher. Cognitive load is a factor. Unpredictable questions come up in a classroom. A description can't give away an answer on a test… 
This session will provide a refined set of guidelines to better meet the specific needs of learners.

name: Disability and Telehealth: Healthcare Access and Motivations
description: Examination of telehealth use, healthcare access, and motivations for using telehealth across disability types: learning, anxiety, difficulty speaking, upper extremity limitations, walking, fatigue and limited stamina, blind, and deaf.

name: State of Play: The Intersection of Video Games & People with Disabilities
description: AbleGamers will give an overview of the state of gaming. This talk will present why gaming is important for people with disabilities, the state of the industry in making accessible player experiences, and an overview of the technology available to people with disabilities, including examples of typical setups.

name: Envisioning an AI for Your Eye
abstract: Wearables & AI are the platform of the future. It has the potential to improve independence of blind & people with low vision across the world. This talk will give you a peek of this exciting future and our experience building the Envision Glasses.
description:
Today we live in the mobile era. Smartphones have reached the near-peak of what they're capable of, much like desktop computers in the early 2000s. Wearables are a natural next step in this evolutionary process. Coupled with the present revolution in AI they can help interpret the visual world around us in a much more unobtrusive, intuitive way. 

This talk will focus on the AI plus wearables revolution that is currently underway and one that is poised to go mainstream in the coming decade. We'll explore how an wearable-based AI tool can significantly improve independence for blind and low vision people across the world -- at home, at work and all other facets of life. 

AI today has gone from doing the basics like OCR, object detection or face recognition to Document Understanding, image captioning and beyond. This talk will walk listeners through these developments and how they can effectively help blind and low vision users today and in the coming years.
secondary_topics: Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), & Cross/Mixed Reality (XR)

name: Bricks, Braille, and Learning Through Creative Play
abstract: Overview of key components of creative play and usage of braille bricks for individual, group, and classroom applications. Facilitators discuss their experiences creating workshops for teaching pre-braille and braille in a fun, hands-on way.
description:
Children have a remarkable inherent potential to learn about the world through play from the very beginning of infancy. Regardless of circumstances, we believe that learning via play is essential for children's healthy growth.

Fewer young people are learning braille as a result of the multitude of audiobooks and computer applications that are already available. This is especially important given that blind people worldwide rely on braille to work, study, and live their lives to the fullest every day.

Braille Bricks provide a ground-breaking and inclusive opportunity to teach and aid in the development of skills in both sighted and blind youngsters.

The purpose of the course is to assist you as a practitioner working with visually impaired kids in using a special and entertaining hands-on tool to teach pre-braille and braille; applying a play-based approach to develop the all-around skills needed to succeed, and working with peers to further develop how Braille Bricks can be used to support visually impaired kids in an inclusive setting.

We will give you practical knowledge during this course that will help you fully grasp the concept of learning through play and how to instruct braille in a fun and interesting manner. The use of Braille Bricks to help children with vision impairments develop their academic and specialty abilities will also be covered in detail.

We are prepared to play and hope you will join us.

name: JAWS & ZoomText Enterprise Deployment, What You Need to Know
abstract: Learn about best practices and techniques for deploying, maintaining, and licensing of JAWS and ZoomText on an Enterprise scale.
description: Join us for a session covering frequently asked questions asked by enterprise technology specialists. Administrators confront many challenges when installing accessibility technology in the workplace. Over the years, we have crafted many solutions to make deployment, management, and licensing of JAWS and ZoomText easier. Topics will include exploring and configuring JAWS, and ZoomText connected features like Picture Smart and Voice Assistant, configuring antivirus software, performing automated software installations, and utilizing remote access and virtualization features. In addition, we will cover the types of software licenses available and how they can be managed.

name: Task Aware Browsing: AI Assisted Web Access for Blind Users
abstract: AI can provide blind users with a command line interface to perform tasks on many web sites. This solves the common problem these users experience in navigating the web. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility of this approach.
description:
A completely new approach for blind users to access web pages is presented. It uses machine learning and artificial intelligence to overcome the problems encountered by these users with conventional browsers and screen readers, particularly on an unfamiliar web site. Finding the location of key features, when accessing Internet web sites, is difficult and time consuming. This approach provides a method for finding active controls, and tracking and managing the results from invoking these controls. The new approach is called TAB: Task Aware Browsing, For a given vertical domain, e.g. shopping, travel, banking, etc., a set of keyboard commands is created that allow the user to perform the essential functions in that domain. The browser then uses a model generated from machine learning to convert each command into the appropriate actions for a learned web site. It filters the results of page updates to present the screen reader with only the essential portion of rendered page that is responsive to the command, eliminating excess clutter. Work performed to date indicates that machine learning techniques will allow this approach to work on a significant number of web sites. User testing demonstrates that it provides an appreciable improvement in the speed with which blind users can accomplish desired tasks.

name: Make MS Word Remediation Simple
abstract: We use MS Word daily in business, school, and at home. Billions of documents are generated daily but are they inclusive? We’ll discuss options to make Word Documents accessible and how to build a culture of inclusion.
description: Millions to Billions of documents are created daily and monthly. Many are housed on websites, and many exist in business enterprises. Documents communicate critical information that must be inclusive. As organizations plan to implement accessibility, this should not be a retrofit but a way to implement accessibility as a culture from authoring to publishing. Documents for staff and clients as well as websites should be in scope.

name: Accessible Setup Experience for Sony BRAVIA With Google TV
abstract: In this joint session, Sony and Google will discuss the importance of empowering independence for all users, and how they collaborated to make the setup experience of Google TV devices more accessible to screen reader users.
description:
In this joint session, Sony and Google will discuss the importance of empowering independence for all users, and how they collaborated to make the setup experience of Google TV devices more accessible to screen reader users.  
Being able to perform tasks independently is important to many people with disabilities. Sony TV team has been conducting user research with blind and low vision users since 2017, and one of the most frequently requested features is the ability to turn on the screen reader from the beginning, supporting independent TV setup.  
We will introduce the new method of enabling TalkBack screen reader at the beginning and the research that went into the design.

name: Accessibility Analytics – Being Data Driven With VPATs
abstract: Elsevier will share our approach to managing VPAT data and analytics across dozens of products. We will share our ranking and graphing capabilities, which can help drive accessibility remediation efforts.
description:
Historically, VPATs or (Accessibility Conformance Reports) have been the way in which to measure and document compliance with a number of standards including (WCAG, US 508, and EN 301 549). Companies which produce many products often produce many VPATs to help meet the needs of customers and internal stakeholders. 

Within VPATs, there is a wealth of data generated that, if fully leveraged, can provide insights into a company’s accessibility estate. Data can be derived from VPATs such as the distribution of checkpoints that are fully, partially, and not supported. This data can be mined, aggregated, and sliced in ways to help provide larger insights.

Elsevier has a large number of products, and we used this data analytics approach to compare and rank using data from dozens of accessibility evaluations.

We will share the story of why this became necessary for us, and the eventual decisions that led to our current iteration. We will also go over the benefits of ranking products against each other and how it breeds competitiveness, especially in an organization that takes accessibility seriously. We will also share the success stories of how this comparison has driven accessibility remediation efforts across numerous products.

We will also go over the limitations of these analytics and any current issues they still have.

name: Designing ASL-Friendly Interfaces and Video Components
abstract: How does current UI design obstruct or facilitate the online user experiences of ASL-signing people? Let's explore how interactive video components can effectively deliver signed language content and increase connection with deaf signing audiences.
description:
As the world's sign languages (SLs) are visual rather than spoken or written, video is the best and only medium for sharing signed content online. User interface designs for video components in signed languages are often built around - and limited by - text and audio conventions. Although there have been minor innovations in video-based interface designs, these efforts are hampered by the fact that existing video paradigms have not been developed for signed language-related usage nor the specific needs and shared conventions of the Deaf American Sign Language (ASL) signing community. When video-based components are built to deliver main content, navigation cues, and other UI elements in a visual language, many more possibilities need to be prototyped and explored. 

In this session, we will discuss previously unexplored possibilities for making video components more accessible, effective, and deliverable to Deaf ASL-signing people. We will demonstrate design options for key features of interfaces with video components. We will shed light on areas that have not been widely explored or considered in UX/UI accessibility, design, and development practices, and discuss how to create tools that facilitate authentic and meaningful interactions with Deaf SL users. 

Our goal is to broaden and shift attendee perspectives and offer new insights on novel signed language-centric video-based UX/UI designs that include and engage deaf signing communities in the world of online information.

name: Designing with Accessibility in Mind
abstract: Content creators have a responsibility to ensure content reaches the widest audience possible. This class focuses on identifying accessibility barriers and overcoming them with inclusive design decisions that minimize project impact.
description:
This session covers accessibility guidelines for designing more accessible content. We review specific graphic examples of real-world content. We break down accessibility guidelines in easy-to-understand terms for a variety of digital content. Attendees will learn proper color contrast, colorblind design best practices, how to generate effective alternate descriptions and additional design methods beyond the use of color alone to reduce cognitive barriers. Students will also learn basic best-practices for designing for social media.

Students will receive the following handouts:
• 10 Tips for writing with accessibility in mind.
• Accessible Social Media Best Practices
• Top 10 Accessible Table Tips
• Tips for writing Effective Alt-Text

name: Re-inventing the Invention Process
abstract: Join Feeldom’s product designer and engage in the invention process! Learn how to develop an adaptive product that celebrates the individual by taking a “whole-person” approach to invention. Includes new product demos and audio-visual presentation.
description:
Inventing adaptive gear should not only consider “What you need” but must also ask, “What do you want?” and “How do you want to feel?” We introduce our method through an interactive visual presentation that shows adaptive product trends over past decades.

The philosophy behind our invention method is called “3-F”.  This unique concept simultaneously considers three main factors of equal importance. We view our inventions as a continual process rather than a finished product, and we want to lead viewers through this process so they can apply it to their own products.

1. Function:  observing the needs of an individual lets us decide features necessary for an invention to be beneficial. We show working closely with wheelchair-users to design a wheelchair bag with customizable 8-strap system.

2. Fashion:   considering aesthetics, a person’s self-image, lifestyle and how they desire to be perceived by others is important. We show how development in mobility devices, fashion trends, and social perceptions challenged us to design our adaptable low-vison cross-body bag.

3. Feedback-based research:   engaging with people who use the product in their daily lives informs us before, during and after the design process.  We use an “open-ended” design model that constantly improves. We show how to apply feedback to improve a product through a step-by-step of how we developed our low-vision backpack system.

We conclude by challenging viewers to apply 3-F for better product development.

name: Funding Assistive Tech Through the Department of Education
abstract: The Department of Education’s Office of Special Education and Rehabilitative Services funds federal grants and national centers to support innovative technologies and systems. Presenters will lead a discussion on application processes and strategies.
description:
The U.S. Department of Education’s Office of Special Education and Rehabilitative Services (OSERS) coordinates discretionary grant programs funded under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and other federal initiatives. OSERS Program Specialists are content area experts who serve as project officers for a range of federal investments supporting children, students, and adults with disabilities. This session will be facilitated by project officers for OSERS-funded grants.
The session will begin with updates regarding the Department’s and Office’s work including the work of currently funded projects in the Office of Special Education, the Rehabilitative Services Administration, and other offices and agencies. Specialists will discuss the Department of Education’s discretionary grant award process and will share updated information with implications for the field of technology as it relates to disability. Following the updates, specialists will facilitate a discussion encouraging participants to share ideas, concerns, and questions about grant making process along with ways in which OSERS and/or other national leaders can support stakeholders. 
Participants’ feedback will provide valuable insights to inform future funding and policy priorities and grant award processes. The session will conclude with strategies for the audience to continue engagement which will inform OSERS and other local, state, and federal offices.

name: Ceiling-Mounted Cameras to Enhance Low Vision Accessibility
abstract: Suspend the MagniLink AIR video magnification system from the ceiling. Learn about ML AIR components and how they are deployed in cooperation with existing MagniLink products to suit a low vision user’s need in the classroom, boardroom, or kitchen.
description:
This presentation will showcase the new MagniLink AIR system and provide tips on integrating existing MagniLink products into an AIR system. 

The AIR system is built on the AIR Uno, AIR Duo, and AIR Distance, while the foundation of the AIR system is our Viewer software for Chrome, Mac, PC and iPad.

The remote-controlled cameras in the AIR Uno and AIR Duo offer the user 30x optical zoom. These ceiling mounted, wireless, motorized cameras leave the user’s work area free for a computer, books, or papers. 

The AIR Uno’s single camera can be used alternately as a document and distance camera, while the AIR Duo’s dual cameras are dedicated to either document or distance viewing.

The AIR Distance (also 30x optical zoom) is wired and can be mounted on a table or wall. This single camera product, built for distance, is often combined with another LVI camera for documents. 

Use the MagniLink AIR products as building blocks to create a unique MagniLink AIR system. The AIR cameras can be used individually or grouped. Use existing LVI products, MagniLink PRO, MLS, or Zip, to complete the system. 

Accessorize the system with TTS/OCR capability and/or a Frame Grabber which wirelessly transmits images from a projector or smartboard to a computer. 

With the information provided, attendees will understand the value and breadth of the MagniLink AIR products, allowing them to design a system for their environment.

name: Making LMS Documents Accessible
abstract: Learn the challenges of making LMS documents accessible. Students and employees must understand training and course content. Their grade or job depends on it. Making it accessible for all is a legal responsibility and leads to a great reputation.
description:
During this session, we will explore the challenges and opportunities around making the documents within an organization’s Learning Management System (LMS) accessible. We will review some potential consequences when documents do not meet ADA or Section 508 compliance guidelines. We will discuss the legal reasons and why it’s good for business when learners can consume lessons in ways they can best understand.
Currently, there are more than 800 options of LMS platforms ranging from open source to proprietary. There are LMS platforms for both corporate and education users. In the corporate world, LMS platforms manage, track, and distribute employee training, including compliance training and customer education. In education, coursework is shared and managed using LMS platforms.
Making documents compliant with ADA and Section 508 is important within LMS platforms. Content must be equally accessible by people with all abilities and the assistive devices they may use (including PCs, MACs, tablets, and smartphones). It is critically important to provide a level playing field when it comes to enabling excellent job performance or understanding course materials in a way that is equitable compared to other students and learners.

name: A Web of Anxiety: Towards a Less Stressful User Experience
abstract: Awareness of accessibility for people with anxiety disorders has grown in recent years. High-pressure sales tactics and deceptive patterns have caught lawmakers’ attention. But has it made a difference? Is the web any less stressful? Let’s find out!
description:
Awareness of the impact of online accessibility for people with anxiety and panic disorders has grown in recent years. High-pressure sales tactics and deceptive patterns have caught the attention of lawmakers, regulators, and researchers. Banks have introduced new measures to support vulnerable customers. Social media companies have recognized the impact of their services on users’ mental health. But has this made any difference?

This presentation will provide an update on developments in understanding this often-overlooked aspect of web accessibility. It will explore aspects of user interface and user experience design that contribute to feelings of anxiety and panic. It will also examine whether the web is still as anxiety-inducing as ever, and highlight recent initiatives aimed at addressing anxiety-related issues. 

This presentation will also share recommendations on what we can do to improve the user experience for people with anxiety and panic disorders. These include raising awareness through education and training (and occasional naming-and-shaming), promoting conformance to existing and upcoming accessibility guidelines, as well as developing technological solutions to the most egregious examples of deceptive design. Acknowledging the difficulties in legislating against ever-evolving deceptive design patterns, this presentation will consider ways to encourage more ethical behavior from big businesses and promote a less stressful user experience on the web.

name: Making Accessibility Part of Product Development
abstract: In this session we will review two methods developed by the Alexa Shopping  team  to ensure an entire organization can build products and services, which are “born accessible”  for customers with disabilities. This is a non-technical talk.
description:
In this session we will review two methods developed in Alexa Shopping to ensure an entire organization can build products and services, which are “born accessible”  for customers with disabilities. 

In the first approach, we will present an organizational mechanism that can lead any feature teams to test for accessibility requirements in the product development cycle, and raise the bar over time by setting incremental targets to ensure requirements are met. 

In the second approach, we will present a model aimed at inventing new products that are universally accessible (i.e., “curb-cut” solutions), by working backwards from the needs of customers with disabilities. 

This is a non-technical talk designed to appeal to a broad audience.

name: Scoring the Accessibility of Major Sporting Events
abstract: Coming off the heels of the World Cup, World Series, and into March Madness, we dive into a matchup of major sporting events with an accessibility lens: from tickets, watching live and streaming, scores and standings, merchandise and more.
description:
Our presentation will embark on a typical fan’s online experience with emphasis on four major events: the World Cup, the World Series, the Super Bowl, and March Madness. There are many players on our roster, as this presentation will focus on: game information and articles, scores and standings, ticketing, merchandising, and of course, how to watch the games. 
The event-specific website, whether it’s FIFA, MLB, NCAA, or the NFL, is the first stop to learn more but how accessible are they? With games moving quickly and played simultaneously, what does the typical user experience look like for someone following on-the-go? Then, to watch the games—there’s television and streaming.  What do these channels have in their playbook for accessibility with respect to captions, audio descriptions, and beyond?
These events bring in billions of dollars in revenue. We will discuss more on where fan dollars are spent, specifically with ticketing and merchandise, and if the entire checkout process is one with accessibility in mind. The presentation will focus on fans with disabilities and how their assistive technology interacts with the various experiences denoted above. How do the global rules and regulations of accessibility, like the WCAG and country-specific legislation, play out? Our presentation will focus on how each of these areas impact accessibility, and vice versa. For events of this size, the stakes can be high. With the world watching, just what is the final score?

name: Braille Reader Characteristics: Keys to Tech & Media Access
abstract: Are you building tech for people with visual impairments? Our session looks at the average braille reader and considers characteristics that may help tech developers make more inclusive, more accessible products for braille readers.
description:
What do tech developers and accessible media creators need to know about braille readers to make their products accessible? Our session reviews current literature on braille literacy with technology, accessibility, and advocacy in mind.
 
Through a systematic literature review of published claims about numbers of braille readers in the U.S. (Sheffield et al., 2022), we documented the current lack of reliable methods to determine – or even define – braille literacy rates. Our investigation covered a century of publications, and we continue this line of inquiry by looking more closely at the motivations and questions through which researchers have sought to better understand the population of braille readers. People who use technology to access braille and who use braille to access technology have diverse preferences, needs, experiences, and skills. How do developers of technology, producers of accessible media, and advocates for braille provision go beyond asking “Do you read braille?” in order provide real access to education, employment, and community? We will share our research along with the first-hand experiences of braille readers, opening a discussion of what else needs to be asked and learned to provide effective, inclusive tech and media.

name: Designing with Mental Health in Mind
abstract: Since the pandemic, mental health diagnoses are on the rise. An eye-opening peek into the lives of professionals with mental health diagnoses. Describe common symptoms across an extremely diverse disability group and share design solutions.
description:
Two accessibility professionals with primary mental health disabilities will share insights to the challenges posed by mental health disabilities and how to create accessible designs with these issues in mind. 
Some challenges stemming from mental health disabilities include organization, time keeping, panic or anxiety triggers and cognitive overload. Keeping designs simple and intuitive reduce issues with cognitive overload and anxiety triggers. When requiring a user to complete an action with a specific time limit provide easily accessible extensions. If at all possible, remove the time requirements as this benefits multiple groups of users. Provide multiple reminders for scheduled events. Providing these reminders makes it less likely a user will get distracted and miss important scheduled events. 
How can we design to avoid common panic and anxiety triggers while providing meaningful access to the same information? Graphics and text descriptions of a graphic and disturbing nature are often integral to sharing the news of today and historical accounts. People with strong adverse reactions to certain topics should be given simple warnings of the content within so as to not accidentally trigger panic, anxiety or depressive symptoms. Providing general descriptors such as Trigger Warning *Suicide, *Sexual Assault *Serious Injuries etc. can help the user quickly and safely navigate away from or around the triggering content.

name: Create, Learn, Code! – Introduce Coding with Tangible Result
abstract: Attendees will learn several accessible tools for blind students that can be used to learn, teach and code.  In addition, the audience will have the opportunity to encounter the first Braille-centric coding application with tangible results.
description:
Learning to code is one of the most common curricula that have found its way into standard offerings throughout today’s educational landscape.  Often these curricula are very visual in nature and students who are blind are unable to participate in this instruction.  From start to finish, this process can pose significant challenges to a blind student at all stages, from the initial concept learning phase, through the creation and reading of one’s code, to the result being something that the student can meaningfully experience.
With the ever-growing technology space, the world of computing programming is in high demand with a shortage of programmers.  Having the right tools to assist the engagement level in the early stages of coding is essential in continuing the journey with what can become a successful career path and serve as a means to deplete the high unemployment rate for the visually impaired. 
This presentation will demonstrate how one can use accessible tools to introduce a blind student to coding concepts through tactile pods and introduce methods by which students can easily transition to writing and editing code using a refreshable braille device.  This natural progression in the learning process will enable a student to create code whilst receiving both speech and braille feedback independently.

name: Paving the Holy Braille Highway through Dynamic and Digital
abstract: The future of braille literacy is dynamic and digital. New technology brings opportunities to make braille and tactile graphics more available, affordable, and interactive. Join us to discuss the work required to ensure this future is a reality.
description:
The future of tactile literacy, much like print literacy, is dynamic and digital. This move means major changes for how braille and tactile graphics are created, delivered, and interacted with by users. This presentation will cover the work that needs to be done now to prepare for the future of digital tactile literacy. 

Part of this presentation will cover the efforts being undertaken to create a new electronic braille file standard currently called the eBRF. This international effort seeks to create a dynamic braille file standard that allows braille layouts to be manipulated, navigated, read, and shared across braille regions. It will also be configurable based on a user's needs and preferences. 

Additionally, we will discuss the need for a new dynamic tactile graphics standard. Current standards that exist for tactile graphics are based on a static medium, and while they should serve as the basis for standards for the digital age, more clarification is needed. The tactile graphics of the future will be interactive, dynamic, and offer multimodal methods of learning. We need standards so that students are prepared to interact with the graphics regardless of the hardware that they are using. 

Finally, this presentation will cover other challenges and opportunities that face the future of digital tactile literacy. We will also discuss new ways of distributing braille and tactile graphics and how these distribution methods will lead to decreased costs and delivery times.

name: Accessibility in Enterprise Gamification
abstract: Enterprise gamification poses unique accessibility challenges. Learn how we included accessibility throughout the game development process, how we mapped the relevant WCAG criteria, and which specific HTML, CSS, and ARIA techniques we used.
description: We developed a 90-minute interactive web-based multiplayer game for all our 350,000+ people across 150+ countries. The game required teams to travel by a virtual elevator and complete interactive quizzes, participate in discussions, and score points for the leader board. By deploying a shift-left strategy, accessibility was factored as a non-negotiable requirement into all stages of the game development process including planning, concepting, design, front end development, testing, and release. WCAG criteria were mapped against the scope of the game play and of particular importance were requirements related to keyboard access, semantics, color contrast, captioning, audio descriptions, timed events, forms, and page titles. The developers evaluated the technology stack for optimal accessibility including accessibility API mappings, user agent behavior, and assistive technologies adaptation. Iterative game design sessions were conducted with the UX design team and developers utilized specific HTML, CSS, and ARIA elements to optimize accessibility. They also ensured the usage of accessible media players, and provided easy access to closed captions, audio descriptions, and microphone hints. We used an enhanced Trusted Tester methodology to test and report accessibility bugs, and leveraged the report for remediation tracking. By fully embedding accessibility we were able to successfully deliver an inclusive enterprise gaming experience.

name: Smarthome for the Independent Living of Senior Citizens
abstract: Smart homes are expected to support the independent living of senior citizens. In this study, the authors interviewed 39 senior citizens. The authors will report the results and propose smart home models for the independent living of senior citizens.
description:
Introduction:
Smart homes utilizing ICT have recently attracted much attention. However, most studies focus only on the technological aspects and lack users' perspectives [Jung Woo et al. (2018), and B.K.Sovacool, et al.(2020)]. In Japan, people over 65 years old are about 30% of the population. Life support for senior citizens is urgent, and smart homes are expected as one way to support their independent living. In this study, the authors propose new models of smart homes for senior citizens based on the user survey.

Survey:
The authors have individually interviewed 39 senior citizens so far. The highest scoring feature was an automatic emergency notification, rated positively by 33 respondents. Telemedicine and home appliance hazard notifications followed. Respondents cited concerns about their future physical or mental changes. In contrast, features related to crime prevention scored lower, and they cited the community's security and the fact that those features are already installed in apartments. On the other hand, positive and negative responses were evenly split on health management systems and life monitoring sensors. Those who approve seek a more convenient life and peace of mind, and hostile voters tend to resist automation and monitoring.

Presentation:
The interview survey is ongoing. At CSUN2023, the authors will report the details, including the results, and propose smart home models to help the independent living of senior citizens.

name: Conceptual Integrity and the Value of Mobile Accessibility
abstract: Mobile devices dominate our engagement time. Is your business ready to leverage this opportunity? Come learn about Conceptual Integrity, Mobile Accessibility, and how the simplicity of an Inclusive Mobile Application can benefit your business.
description:
Native Mobile Operating Systems are gradually taking over in terms of dominating users’ digital engagement time. As this trend continues there is a growing relationship between the following concepts:

-	The promise of the business opportunity mobile applications present.
-	Mobile devices finding their way to late adopters, particularly older generations.
-	Users with cognitive conditions finding comfort in the Simplicity of Native.
-	Developing applications that respect platform Accessibility Configurations.

It is in the overlap of these concepts that truly successful Native Applications reside. How do we leverage these concepts to make our users, and in turn our business, more successful? The answer comes down to one thing Native Mobile Applications must have to be successful:

-	Conceptual Integrity.

In this presentation I will walk attendees through the various breakdowns that a lack of conceptual integrity leads to within Native Mobile Design including structural issues, user confusion, and basic misuse of platform APIs. We will discuss the concept of the limited space of Native Mobile devices and how it forces us to design more simply. Relating it back to how a lack of Conceptual Integrity prevents us from leveraging the simplicity of Mobile Design and therefore failing to leverage the business value of Mobile.

name: Making Look and Gaze Detection Data Meaningful
abstract: CViConnect PRO captures 64 unique points along the human face, providing educational teams with valuable data points. Together we will analyze the data provided to gain insight to a learner with CVI’s functional vision.
description:
CViConnect utilizes the iPad’s forward-facing camera to capture 64 unique points along the human face. The innovative technology provides educational teams with valuable data points regarding the learner’s functional vision. This data is crucial for IEP teams supporting learners with CVI, if teams know what to do with it. Throughout this breakout session, participants will review examples of the data recorded and reported within CViConnect PRO.

First, we will review the numbers provided to educational teams within their intervention list. This chart provides team members with the date, timestamp, Activity title, teacher comments, duration of Activity session, total time looking, touches, and number of looks. We will guide participants to be able to answer the following questions about the learner’s data samples. 

Team members can also click on a specific session to take a closer look at how the student performed during that Activity. The ‘Detail’ tab provides team members with length of the longest look, time not looking, and more. When looking at the ‘Detail’ session data, we will look at the implications of the data. 

Next, we will move into the ‘Session Events timeline.’  The data from the ‘Detail’ tab is used to create a bar graph of the session. During the session we will now review how this data can answer questions. 
To conclude, participants will be asked to share additional opportunities to utilize this data.

name: Optimizing Access to iDevices for Blind and Low Vision
abstract: Zoom, VoiceOver, Siri, external keyboards, Braille displays..bringing it together to optimize your student's access and independence with using an iDevice.
description:
Presenter will review the fantastic accessibility settings built into iOS (including Siri, Zoom, Voiceover, Magnifier, accessibility shortcuts, switch access and voice typing). However, optimizing access to these devices involves more than turning on these features based on an area of need: low vision = zoom, blind = voiceover, fine motor challenges = switch access.
Will explore feature matching: determining optimal access to iDevices incorporating visual, physical access, personal preferences and language needs. Will look at how to utilize a variety of features and access options within iOS to optimize access. Use of Assistive Touch, external standard keyboards, braille displays and third party keyboard apps will also be explored and demonstrated. This will include use of Siri, keyboard shortcuts and custom Apple Shortcuts to control accessibility features. Will also touch on other third party apps such as apps for working with PDF files and OCR tools. Case studies will be shared, including how the access needs of students with low vision and multiple exceptionalities were more optimally met; less accidental selections and greater independence.

name: Collaboration and Productivity: Microsoft Teams and JAWS
abstract: Many employees around the United States use Microsoft Teams every day for work projects. In this task-based demonstration, will show how the power of JAWS screen reader performs with the features of Microsoft Teams.
description: In this session, Liz Whitaker and Rachel Buchanan go beyond the basics and demonstrate the power of JAWS screen reader with JAWS 2023 and Microsoft Teams. We’ll provide an overview of the Teams interface and talk about navigation improvements in JAWS 2023. Thousands of people use Microsoft Teams every day for work. This demonstration will show how the functionality of JAWS combines with the powerful features of Teams. From collaboration on files to chatting and calendar management, Teams and JAWS can work together with users for enormous productivity. We’ll demonstrate how to utilize Microsoft Teams for collaboration and productivity as a screen reader user, as well as how you can support your team members who may be using assistive tech.

name: Accessible Scheduling Interface for the Visually Impaired
description: We aim to clarify accessibility issues of various scheduling interface for visually impaired persons, and propose measures to deal with these issues.

name: How Document Accessibility Fits into Digital Accessibility
abstract: Digital accessibility is being pushed with electronic presentment and PDF documents on websites. How do you manage and present both transactional and website documents? What is the best practice?
description: Website accessibility has been at the forefront of inclusive access, but often we forget about the number of formatted documents on websites. Documents such as PDFs, Word files, or PowerPoint also must be made accessible. Millions to Billions of documents are created daily and monthly. Transactional documents like invoices, statements, letters, and reports are personalized and contain personal and confidential information that may have timely payment or action are hosted. This information and other “document” related PDFs and Word files are housed on websites, and many exist in business enterprises. Documents communicate critical information that must be inclusive. As organizations plan to implement accessibility, this should not be a retrofit but a way to implement accessibility as a culture from authoring to publishing. Documents for staff and clients, as well as websites, should be in scope. Digital accessibility for documents should not be an afterthought.

name: So You've Automated Accessibility Testing... Now What?
abstract: Adoption of automated accessibility testing is a good first step, but its impact is limited if we don't take action on the results. Quality gates and simple tool use can lead to a more accessible product downstream while keeping development moving.
description:
This session will be a guide and practicum covering how development organizations can make effective and efficient use of test results that are generated via automated testing.  The initial supposition is that within the digital accessibility space over the last several years there has been a non-trivial growth in adoption and awareness relating to "shifting left" with accessibility.  This has led to a dramatic increase in the adoption of automated accessibility testing during CI/CD processes, however that increase in adoption doesn't fully translate to a proportional increase in overall accessibility because there is as of yet not enough enablement supporting how teams can use those test results to govern quality and drive improvements.

This session will be a combination of presentation through slides, as well as a practical demonstration of the suggested methods for utilizing automated test results to actually improve the digital accessibility of an application or product.

name: 7 Ways to Make Content Digitally Accessible
abstract: Come join us in understanding our role in promoting diversity and inclusion and helping organizations make their information accessible to anyone, anywhere, regardless of language, location, or ability, in an increasingly digital world.
description: At Natively Fluent we believe that information should be accessible to anyone, anywhere, regardless of language, location, or ability. Natively Fluent's presentation will elaborate, in detail, the seven ways in which to make any information digitally accessible and how Natively Fluent serves this purpose. With the use of real life examples of content that was previously inaccessible, we intend to demonstrate how the following can be added: Translations, Voiceovers, Video Dubbing, Audio Description, Transcriptions, Captions, Subtitles, and ASL (VRI). We will show the content before and after adding these and show how each of these make content more accessible and who benefits.

name: The Future Vision of the Visionaries
abstract: Accessibility visionaries envision global, pervasive and inclusive accessibility where every interface results in a successful human interaction. This morning, we will meet three renowned visionaries who will introduce us to our future…today!
description: Visionaries by definition are creative futurists. They look beyond the limitations that exist in the present and visualize themselves in a future without barriers, without limits. Accessibility visionaries take visualization one step further - they envision global, pervasive and inclusive accessibility where every interface results in a successful human interaction. This morning, we will meet three renowned visionaries who will introduce us to our future…today!

name: Solving Accessibility Problems in Virtual Lab Environments
abstract: We examine challenges and solutions to making a highly visual and dynamic web app accessible. Topics include building accessible “drag and drop” functionality, providing color information beyond the pixels, and communicating with a skeptical audience.
description:
In 2018 a collaborative team of content experts, educators, accessibility experts, and software developers began a project to build a web-based environment for chemistry and biology lab simulations. Macmillan Learning and its partners incorporated accessibility principles and approaches into the development from the beginning to ensure all students can utilize the tool and complete virtual experiments. The first version of the software was released in 2020, and has been used in high school and higher education courses to familiarize learners with a lab environment, lab procedures, tools, experiments, and outcomes. Continued development has aimed to expand the content and improve the user experience and accessibility of the software, with version 2.0 going live in the fall of 22.
We will examine challenges in making a highly visual and dynamic web environment accessible, and demonstrate solutions that were employed. We will focus on specific accessibility features and enhancements that have been added over the past two years, including enhancements to “drag and drop” functionality and the dissemination of color information to users in situations where dynamic color changes are possible . We will also address methods used to communicate the existence and extent of accessibility features to potential users, and challenges that arise when they assume this type of software is inaccessible.

name: Impact of 3D Printing Assistive Tech in a Healthcare Setting
abstract: How 3D printing has impacted individuals with disabilities at Rancho Los Amigos National Rehabilitation Center.Success stories and lessons learned will be shared, including the overall collaborative design process involving clinical & technical staff
description: To present on how 3D printing has been implemented as a central core service within Rancho Los Amigos National Rehabilitation Center. Best practices for collaboration between clinical staff and design/engineering team. Examples of successful 3D printed equipment and the process behind the design and evolution. How custom 3D printing has allowed individuals with disabilities to return to meaningful activities such as playing video games, hiking, and cooking.

presenters.name: Andy Lin
presenters.organization: Emerging Tech Lab at Rancho Los Amigos National Rehabilitation Center

presenters.name: Hanalynn Hunt, OTD, OTR/L, CBIS
presenters.organization: Center for Applied Rehabilitation Technology at Rancho Los Amigos National Rehabilitation Center

name: Accessible Systems: Shipping Software that Enables
abstract: Shipping accessible software doesn't have to be complicated. This session will introduce the systems thinking approach to thinking about accessibility, spreading accountability, and actions across the whole product team.
description:
Say "goodbye" to audit, remediate, and repeat. Your users deserve better. In this session, we'll discuss how we've stopped thinking about accessibility in this reactive way at REI and how you, too, can start building a better system to deliver software to your users. An "accessible system" that ships inclusive software by default.

We'll demonstrate how we are using systems thinking to reframe the accessibility conversation at our company — from something extra our developers do to a model that enables every product team member to contribute. 

The result? Accessibility isn't something different to prioritize, but rather how we do our existing jobs more inclusively.

name: T-Mobile Accessibility: Past, Present and Future
abstract: T-Mobile Accessibility is focused on bridging the communication gap for people who are Deaf, DeafBlind, Hard of Hearing, and those with speech disabilities. We will review the evolution of accessible communication solutions and the future!
description:
T-Mobile’s Accessibility delivers services designed to bridge the communications gap for people who are Deaf, hard of hearing, DeafBlind, and those with speech disabilities.  
In this session, attendees will learn about the history of accessible communication services with emphasis on the critical role communications accessibility plays in areas such as the school system, the federal government, rural communities, and emergency/911 services.
The audience will experience real-time demonstrations of several T-Mobile Accessibility products, which include IP Relay, Relay Conference Captioning (RCC), Speech-to-Speech services, as well as state and Federal relay services.
The presentation concludes with audience dialog covering specific solutions for attendees, their families, and friends.

name: Enjoy Fire TV and Tablet with New Low Vision Tools
abstract: Customers now have additional ways to access Amazon devices, such as Speak Selection and Display Size on Fire tablet and an innovative feature, Text Banner, on Fire TV that enhances the navigation experience for people who experience tunnel vision.
description: Customers now have additional ways to access Amazon devices, such as Speak Selection and Display Size on Fire tablet and an innovative feature, Text Banner, on Fire TV that enhances the navigation experience for people who experience tunnel vision.

name: A-B-C’s, 1-2-3’s for Learners with Low Vision
abstract: Through demonstration and discussion, the presenters will cover interface customization, reading/writing/math tools, and how to support inclusive in-person and distance learning for individuals with low vision using HumanWare’s Connect 12.
description:
Join this presentation to learn how to accommodate, support, and include students with low vision to ensure their academic success across all educational subject areas using the Connect 12 portable magnifier from HumanWare. In this session, through demonstration and discussion, the presenters will start from the ground up with a discussion about customization of the user interface (and experience) based on a user’s age, academic skill, technical capability, and level of disability. From this basis, the discussion will evolve to tools that can support the learner across the curriculum, from basic reading, writing, and math to higher levels of STEM and research. In addition, attention will be given to specific low vision supports delivered by Connect 12’s Prodigi software and online productivity tools like the Google Suite, Microsoft Teams, and other applications that can help learners of all ages. Throughout, participants will engage in a discussion of how the available features and tools can be used flexibly to meet a variety of learner needs, in addition to supporting remote or distance learning. While supporting individuals holistically with any assistive device will never be as easy as A-B-C or 1-2-3,  this presentation will highlight how it is possible to support learning wherever it needs to happen and to include everyone in a manner that respects their individual needs.
