name: VoiceOver on Mac: Tips to Improve Efficiency & Productivity
abstract: Learn advanced tips to improve your speed, efficiency, and productivity with VoiceOver on Mac. Discover tools like advanced heading navigation, Keyboard Commander, Activities, navigation hot spots, and using automation to speed up repetitive tasks.
description:
Learn advanced tips for using your favorite apps and web pages. Improve your speed, efficiency, and productivity with VoiceOver on Mac.

In this session, we'll go beyond the VoiceOver Quick Start tutorial, introducing some powerful yet less well known VoiceOver features. The knowledge you gain will boost your efficiency and productivity using your Mac for personal and professional tasks. Learn about tools such as advanced heading navigation, Keyboard Commander, Activities, navigation hot spots, and using automation to speed up repetitive tasks. 

This session is intended for anyone who wants to learn advanced VoiceOver tips on Mac. Teachers of users with vision disabilities will want to attend to become more proficient at using VoiceOver on Mac. The session will focus on demos and how-to descriptions, so the audience can take away specific tips and begin applying them immediately. 

At Apple, we consider community feedback to be an essential part of developing the most accessible software. This session will include a brief description of the most useful ways to share feedback, including steps on how to write a great bug report.

name: Lessons Learned for Effective Accessibility Hackathons
abstract: For the past five years, Amazon's accessibility hackathons have substantially grown. Learn about how Amazon has structured its hackathon events with checks and balances to spur innovation while always focusing on customers with disabilities.
description: Hackathons that centralize disability inclusion and leadership are tremendous opportunities to build accessibility and disability awareness while spurring innovation, building team camaraderie, and solving real customer problems. Amazon's Device Accessibility team has organized companywide accessibility hackathons annually for the past five years . Each year, the event has substantially grown and we have learned many lessons, including how to foster and support meaningful disability participation. In this session, we will share how to creatively and effectively organize your own accessibility hackathon with practical tips on the rules, roles, and responsibilities. This includes checks and balances to ensure projects are delivering meaningful solutions for your customers with disabilities. Additionally, we will share how participants can create a hackathon project, with tips on how to find innovative ideas, develop a prototype, and create an accessible presentation.

name: Understand the Accessibility of Content Before You Buy
abstract: Today accessibility metadata is available for much of the published content used in Higher Education. Learn about where to find this essential metadata and how to determine if the publication will work for students with disabilities.
description:
The “User Experience Guide for Accessibility Metadata” is a best practice report by the W3C Publishing Community Group. Today, distributors of digital publications such as Vital Source and RedShelf are displaying the accessibility metadata in their catalogues. Good publishers, but not all, are providing accessibility information for their publications. It is essential in Higher Education for professors and for DSO professionals to look for the accessibility metadata and to effectively use this accessibility information.

This session will take a comprehensive look at how publishers can include Schema.org and ONIX accessibility metadata and how these get mapped into MARC records for library systems. The European Accessibility Act requires that publishers disclose the accessibility of their products, and this is now a best practice for all publishers around the world. We will then review the published recommendations for the interpretation and presentation of the accessibility metadata by content distributors such as Vital Source, RedShelf, and for libraries.

We will dive into specific metadata fields to show how this can be used to determine if a publication will meet the needs of students with a wide range of disabilities. We will review best practices in the selection of content, and how a DSO office can easily use the accessibility metadata to determine if a publication will require remediation or if it should be appropriate for the students without additional work.

name: ICT Testing Baseline Portfolio and Alignment Framework
abstract: How well does your accessibility conformance test process address Section 508 requirements? Are your test results complete, accurate, and trusted by others? The Section 508 ICT Testing Baseline Portfolio can help you answer these questions.
description:
This presentation will review the development of the ICT Testing Baseline for Web, its supporting framework to assess alignment of methodologies, and other related activities which are all intended to improve testing for Section 508 conformance of other types of ICT. Section 508 conformance testing of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) is currently subjective, and test results are dependent on who (or what) is doing the conformance testing. While the standards are defined, interpretation of the standards vary. There are many tools, but each tool maker has their own interpretation of the standards and what it means to meet requirements. Federal agencies use a wide range of disparate testing methods to validate conformance to IT accessibility requirements. This difference in testing leads to:
- Duplication of effort across agencies,
- Inability to share and rely on validation testing results from other agencies
- Confusion among IT product vendors when test results, methodologies, and requirements from agencies conflict with one another.

Section 508 applies to ICT developed, procured, maintained, or used by federal agencies. Inconsistent conformance testing by agencies and industry affect procurement decisions and internal product release decisions. The goal of the ICT Testing Baselines is to ensure consistent and accurate Section 508 conformance testing by establishing standard requirements of testing methodologies used by federal agencies.

name: Make Course Content Accessible at Scale with AI
abstract: Learners need educational course content in accessible formats. Since content creation isn't centralized, we can't embed accessibility practices at point of origin. So, you need a way to make existing content accessible.
description:
Learners need access to educational course content in accessible formats. This becomes difficult with so many creators generating content. Since content creation is not centralized, we can't embed accessibility practices at point of origin. So, educational institutions need a way to make existing content accessible. 

This session will show a workflow process that solves this problem. Attendees will see a tool automatically route MS Office or PDF content to an AI Engine to:
•	Pre-tag files to approximately 80% completion,
•	Preserve key accessibility elements already created by authors, and
•	Ready content to be made 100% accessible by a workstation product. 
The solution drastically reduces time to market for course materials. What would have taken 5 hours, now takes less than 1 hour. This translates directly to improved student success. Plus, it reduces reputational risk while enabling content platforms to capture market share.

name: Solutions for Complex Table Headings in PDF Files
abstract: In this session, learn why complex table headers can be challenging for PDF accessibility and why they create more complexity and work for the PDF remediator. Learn alternative options for complex table headers as well as things to avoid.
description: In order for tables in a PDF file to be fully accessible, certain requirements need to be met and certain design practices are discouraged to avoid extra work that is required to make a PDF file accessible. Often times, users will design tables visually but when it comes to making those tables accessible, it can be a challenge. In this session we talk about the challenges that some table designs can present, and offer solutions to create a more accessible table for users of assistive technology. Learn how to work with complex tables to make them accessible but also learn how slight adjustments to table designs can make a huge difference.

name: Case Study: Creating Accessible Cultural Experiences
abstract: This case study discusses a partnership with Bloomberg Philanthropies to improve the accessibility of a mobile app featuring guides to cultural institutions around the world, thereby enhancing the app’s user experience for people with disabilities.
description:
Museums, art galleries, and cultural spaces increasingly rely on digital technologies to engage visitors with their collections. It is vital that such experiences are accessible to people with disabilities. This presentation describes how accessibility was integrated into the design and development of a free mobile app featuring digital guides to cultural institutions around the world. 

TPGi partnered with Bloomberg Connects to improve accessibility features of the app, which now provides the means for people with disabilities to engage with cultural institutions and experience their content in an accessible and inclusive way. The presentation will cover the way key accessibility barriers were identified and addressed, reflect on how the results of usability testing with people with disabilities helped verify the quality of the app’s user experience, and consider future developments.

name: Native Mobile - Leading Through Complexity and Confusion
abstract: Learn how CVS is leveraging the empathy and accessibility knowledge of its Inclusive Design team to push for Native First design thinking. How a focus on fundamentals and Accessibility and is driving a push towards more modern usable apps for all.
description:
As CVS matures its digital mindset we have found that Mobile is viewed as a complex daunting challenge. From designers, stakeholders, to engineers there is collective confusion around evolving from Mobile as a companion to web, to designing for Mobile First. Native mobile is just complicated and different enough to create genuine confusion, while not different enough to force stakeholders to see the importance of dedicated Native Mobile experience in these categories, let alone the time and resources it takes to acquire that expertise.

How does an Accessibility Organization lead through this complexity? How do we turn a team of Humble Accessibility Designers into thought leaders speaking out for Native Mobile Accessibility First design thought?

Our answer: 

- A focus on a deeper understanding of the fundamentals.
- Correlating AT issues to usability and design issues.
- Finishing it off with a focus on user empathy.

More simply: Accessibility and Usability are the same! By focusing on the truth of this statement we are able to utilize the strengths of our Accessibility Experts and their knowledge of users with disabilities to teach other disciplines about how their choices effect all users!

name: Digital Graphicacy: Exploring Charts and Graphs with Haptics
abstract: Touchscreens, capable of touch, sound, hand movement, and visuals, have great potential to help close the gap in accessible, digital, educational graphics. We will review our work and encourage the audience to explore our graphics and share thoughts.
description:
As digital tools and technology evolves, so does access to timely information. A growing concern is the accessibility of digital graphics, especially in education, for individuals with blindness and low vision. As education continues to shift further into the digital space, many students are struggling with learning how to parse and understand the rich, information-dense graphical landscape, such as charts and diagrams, when they are presented digitally.

Touchscreens, which utilize haptic, audio, visual, and kinesthetic feedback, have great potential to help close the gap in accessible, digital graphics. The ability to render graphics with tones, description, vibration, and magnified visuals makes the touchscreen an incredibly inclusive and versatile tool to leverage in education. In our work, we have investigated the presentation of digital STEM graphics rendered in this multimodal way, highlighting the promise of haptic feedback as a means to facilitate and scaffold deeper understanding of charts and diagrams.

In this session, we will review our research and findings, which have been used to create a set of design guidelines for generating basic elements of touchscreen-based multimodal graphics. We will then demonstrate how to render graphics using these guidelines. After demonstrating how the graphics were made and how they work, we will encourage the audience to explore the graphics, share their thoughts, and offer feedback for guiding future development.

name: Accommodating Mental Health in the Workplace
abstract: Over 20% of Americans experienced a mental health condition in 2020. A hidden disability can be the most difficult to accommodate—we share actionable suggestions from professionals and our own experience to increase the inclusivity of your workplace.
description:
As workplaces are shifting from in-person to hybrid and remote, the need for stability is tantamount. The best way to increase employee productivity and retention of those with mental illness is through acceptance by accommodations, all under the lens of accessibility. There are many difficulties to accommodate a hidden disability. Perhaps the most apparent is unpredictable attendance. Alternatively, there is also the danger of inspiration of the employee with a mental health disability in the workplace. We will discuss how inspirational employees serves as a disincentive by demeaning the disability and creating a false sense of accomplishment. 
We will share suggestions to advertise your commitment to inclusive hiring and how to remove unintentional barriers. Our presentation will include a diverse collection of accommodations for employees with mental health disabilities. Some of these will be technology-focused and others will be human-centric, but all will accommodate a mental illness.

name: Systems Change in Higher Ed Digital Accessibility
abstract: The National AEM Center offers Quality Indicators and related resources for higher ed institutions to develop roadmaps for implementing and sustaining timely and high-quality digital accessibility for all students.
description:
A range of complex societal and institutional factors contribute to persistent disparities in higher ed outcomes for students with and without disabilities. Based on the volume of related civil rights complaints brought forth by disabled students and disability advocates over the past decade, inaccessible course content and instructional technologies are undeniably among them. Clearly, institutions need to improve accessibility if they are to retain and effectively serve the increasing numbers of students with disabilities coming to their campuses and online programs. Vetted by experts in higher ed technology accessibility, the National AEM Center’s Quality Indicators assist institutions with planning, implementing, and evaluating systems for providing timely and high-quality accessible materials and technologies.
In this session, participants will be led through activities that demonstrate how the Quality Indicators can be implemented within their institutions. Strategies will be introduced for developing cross-functional leadership; identifying roles and responsibilities of administrators, faculty, and staff; improving policies and guidelines; providing training and technical assistance; collecting and using data for continuous improvement; and allocating resources. Freely available AEM Center resources, funded by the U.S. Department of Education, will be used throughout the session.

name: Pushing the Boundaries: Accessibility in Virtual Spaces
abstract: Join us for a lively discussion as we challenge what accessibility and inclusion mean in the future.
description: What do we control in a space that doesn’t exist? Explore the past, present, and future challenges of the Metaverse, XR, and interfaces that haven’t yet been conceived. Join us for a lively discussion as we challenge what accessibility and inclusion mean in the future. Our panelists bring a wealth of knowledge and experience from various fields, including research, XR design, assistive technology, and inclusive design.

name: Next-Gen Tactile Symbols – 3D-Printed Blissymbolics
abstract: Come see a new generation of free  tactile symbols that are perfect for use with non-speaking individuals who are blind, deaf/blind, or visually impaired – including students with cognitive disabilities.  They leverage 3D-printing and Blissymbolics.
description: In this session we'll introduce you to a new generation of tactile symbols that are perfect for use with non-speaking individuals who are blind, deaf/blind, or visually impaired – including students with cognitive disabilities. The symbols benefit from two different technologies: 3D-printing and Blissymbolics. 3D-printing makes it inexpensive to create these tactile symbols. Blissymbolics provides a rich, conceptual language to develop communication skills with low cognitive requirements. The presentation will highlight the experiences shared by several teachers of students with visual impairments (TVIs) and speech language pathologists (SLPs) – how they collaborate and use these tactile symbols with their students. The session will include how educators can get free access to these tactile symbols and supporting materials.

name: Unlock the Power of Speech Synthesis on iOS
abstract: Learn how to incorporate speech into your digital life by mastering Spoken Content features on iPhone and iPad. Speech synthesis has a wide range of applications and built-in features native to iOS, and can benefit users in education and business.
description: A comprehensive discussion of the state of speech synthesis and spoken content on iPhone and iPad, both from a user perspective as well as the developer. We discuss how and why to use features like Speak Screen and Speak Selection, exploring settings both specific and general. We discuss how to make the most of features like Zoom, Magnifier by using speech. We share user scenarios and perspectives to teach how to get the most out of iPhone and iPad. Recent advancements in iOS 16 and iPadOS 16 are demonstrated to show new voices, language support, and options that are now available. Finally, we demonstrate new developer tools to show how using SSML and Speech Synthesis Extensions can enable new voices for the first time on iOS and iPadOS.

name: Online Learning with JAWS - Tips on 3 Platforms
abstract: Join the Freedom Scientific training team as we give an overview of the 3 most widely used Learning Management Systems, and how they perform for JAWS users.
description: We will discuss the challenges, impacts, and possibilities of including users with disabilities in the development process. We will share with you our learning of two different Vispero companies: Freedom Scientific, which builds software for people with disabilities, and TPGi, which provides support for other organizations that want to create accessible digital products.

name: Can Note Taking Support Boost Student Success & Retention?
abstract: 40% of undergrad college students drop out each year, and the graduation rate for students with disabilities is 17.5% lower than the rate for all students. 28% of students drop out due to academic disqualification: how can disability services help?
description:
40% of undergraduate college students drop out each year - and the graduation rate for students with disabilities is 17.5% lower than the rate for all students. Given that 28% of students drop out due to academic disqualification, what can disability services do to help improve student success and boost retention?

It’s incredibly important that students are given access to an independent note taking process. The act of taking notes is critical to the learning process and retention of knowledge. This is because it involves ‘encoding’ (which is the processing information as you put it in note form) and the ‘storage’ of information (where you categorise and store information when reviewing notes). 

In Fall 2021, we surveyed over 400 students to see how taking notes independently affecting their learning and grades. The results are undeniable: 90% of students saw their grades improve as they took notes independently. 

In this session we’ll share the results of our research into how independent note taking can help students with disabilities improve their grades.

name: 2022 State of Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR)
abstract: This session will cover a 2022 study of the 8 leading ASR engines to understand where speech AI stands for the task of captioning & transcription.
description:
What is the current state of speech technology? Is automatic speech recognition (ASR) sufficient for closed captioning or live captioning? Do we still need humans to achieve accuracy standards for accessibility?	

Speech recognition is widely used to streamline the process of creating closed captions, audio descriptions, and other media accessibility accommodations. This session will discuss the findings from a 2022 research study of leading ASR engines to understand how speech AI measures up to the task of captioning and transcription without the intervention of a human editor. The study tested 501 files across 8 industries, testing approximately 68 hours of content with a total of around 600,000 words. 
 
This is the only report of its kind focused on the application of speech recognition technology for captioning vs. for other technologies.

name: Web Survey Findings From Communities With Visual Impairments
abstract: Come and dive deep into the results of an extensive and nuanced survey of online visually impared user communities. Utilizing reddit /r/blind and more, we will cover a large data set across many demographics to determine how we can improve the web.
description:
In the past decade the internet has come up with new and exciting improvements for the accessibility community. Norbert Rum setup and built out one of the largest blind communities on the internet using reddit called /r/blind, which has over 18,000 users and over 400,000 impressions a month. The community provides many examples of what the visually impaired have to deal with on a daily basis. 

When WebAIM started providing surveys from screen-reader communities covering web use and technology, it helped build awareness to the advocates and developers trying to improve accessibility. During the last couple years, the reddit community noticed that the reports have a smaller sample size, which creates potential result biases towards advanced users and select geolocations. This is not to diminish the work done, because it still provides light to a generally unrecognized population.
 
After discussion with the reddit community and various leaders in the accessibility space, we are expanding surveys to a larger audience with a wider level of visual impairments. We are tapping into the expansive reddit user base and further connections into other digital communities. The survey’s flow paths help better account for the different scenarios and combinations of users and impairments, such as levels of magnification and devices used. This session will cover the survey findings that can better help specialists and developers account for wider ranges of web users.

name: Accessibility Checklist for Product Managers
abstract: Practical approaches to embedding Accessibility as part of the product manager’s role to deliver inclusive digital products.
description:
Product managers are responsible for the success of a product. In this session, we will take a closer look at the general responsibilities of a product manager to make the software inclusive for everyone, regardless of their disabilities. 
Awareness: 
A product manager should have the ability to understand the impact of the product on a wide range of people’s needs, especially people with disabilities. To gain this knowledge, if the product exists, test with people with disabilities to understand their challenges. If the product is brand new, plan to include guidelines and best practices. WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines). 
Make time:
It’s important to reserve time in each sprint to design, develop and test for the accessibility requirements. The early process helps to reduce the cost of fixing bugs after the deployment. Include accessibility requirements in the sprint planning to account for the requirements. Include accessibility as part of the user stories or write a separate user story for accessibility. 
Skill up the team:
Enable the team members to gain knowledge of accessibility guidelines and the needs of people with disabilities. Encourage certifications.
Definition of Done:
Accessibility should be part of the testing and deployment process. The automated test covers 30 to 40% of WCAG. Plan for manual test and usability test. 
Continuous focus:
Accessibility is not a one-time implementation or afterthought. It’s a continuous process.

name: Remediate 5x faster than Adobe Acrobat DC
abstract: There is often confusion about what tools to use for remediating fully composed documents, especially PDFs. In this session, we will discuss, and demonstrate, two of these tools showing that using the right tool can make the process easy.
description:
When organizations realize they need to make information and documents accessible, they often feel out of their depth. They have difficulty determining the best route for making their content accessible. They are dealing with meeting compliance requirements with which they are unfamiliar, and it is difficult for them to ascertain what tools to use, especially when they have different types of documents that could be coming from other sources. Taking this on can be daunting for any organization, but it can be incredibly intimidating if they are not experts at document accessibility. However, it doesn’t have to be, especially when using the right tools.

This session will explore and compare two tools for manual remediation, both GUI based and one using AI/Computer learning for effective auto-tagging. We will show how these two tools work, demonstrating the two approaches and how there can be instances where a combination of automation and manual processing could be the most effective.

During this session, there will be a demonstration of the two tools being used for remediation. There will also be a comparison of both tools, using the same document to determine the easiest and most efficient in creating not only accessible PDF but also compliant and usable.

After remediation is complete, the last step will be testing the output to ensure the final PDF is WCAG, PDF/UA, and HHS compliant.

name: Hear What Your Camera Sees With Blink Cameras and Doorbells
abstract: Learn how to make your Blink security camera describe what it sees through the Blink iOS app with Apple’s VoiceOver and scene image recognition. There will be demonstrations of camera setup, use, and placement to get the best recognition results.
description: A video doorbell has a story to tell. The customer-obsessed team at a Blink hackathon led to the use of the Blink iOS app with Apple’s VoiceOver scene image recognition to hear what the Blink camera sees. In this session, see, hear, and learn the customer benefits to hearing what a camera sees, and how Blink and Amazon promote accessibility across the company through their dedication to customer obsession. By combining the latest technologies for people to hear what Blink cameras and video doorbells see, Blink and Amazon continue to promote and ensure accessibility for customers. This one brought joy! Try it out for yourself too.

name: Shifting Further Left – Digital Accessibility Education
abstract: Integrating accessibility in design-related university courses presents a huge opportunity to address barriers across the web today. This session will outline how we are shifting accessibility left to design education and the benefits it presents.
description:
Within a digital product’s lifecycle, one of our aims as digital accessibility engineers is to shift the process left and have accessibility considered as early as possible, rather than at the end for testing, as is often the case. While the ultimate “shift-left” within this lifecycle would be to the project manager or product owner, design is where accessibility can become more heavily involved, in providing feedback, guidance, and education.

However, there is a significant opportunity to “shift-left” on another trajectory – design education itself. In our experience, designers’ knowledge of accessibility varies substantially, and ranges from those with some knowledge – to those who, for the most part, would consider themselves very unfamiliar.

As the European digital accessibility landscape begins to take shape from a legal perspective, with the EU Web Directive now live and EU Accessibility Act coming, the Optum Accessibility Center of Excellence team based in Ireland felt it presented an opportunity to reach out and connect with universities here that offer design and user experience-related courses. 

This presentation will outline the journey we are taking in Ireland as we aim to “shift-left” from an accessibility perspective within the discipline of design education, highlight the outreach work we are doing with universities, discuss why now is the perfect time to do this from a European perspective, as well as show how this model could be scalable in any country.

name: CSUN's MS in Assistive Technology Engineering
abstract: This presentation provides a description of CSUN's Master of Science in Assistive Technology Engineering program, including curriculum, admission requirements, support services, and professional opportunities.
description:
The Master of Science in Assistive Technology Engineering (ATE) program is designed for those who are moving ahead with their careers in this interdisciplinary field or are changing careers who see their future in biomedical engineering and assistive technology.  This degree program is a joint effort among three colleges: the College of Engineering and Computer Science, the College of Health and Human Development, and CSUN’s Tseng College: Graduate, International, and Midcareer Education. 

Among the distinctive features of this program is the collaborative effort of the design and delivery of the curriculum, drawing upon the academic strength of a number of departments and at CSUN as well as the professional expertise or selected practitioners in the field.  The program’s core curriculum covers the essentials of anatomy, human factors, and innovative solutions.  The program is firmly rooted engineering design and development including applied biomechanics, robotic applications and control interfaces, augmentative and alternative communication, software development, project management and, increasingly, the potentials of AI and autonomy research. 

The ATE master’s degree program is unique in the nation, and it is gaining interest from the greater Los Angeles area and beyond.  It is fully online, so it can engage students from an increasingly broad geographical area.

name: Social Media and Accessibility
abstract: Social media accessibility is an very important tool in modern society and there have been great improvements in its accessibility, but how accessible is it really? Find out how Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Pinterest, Instagram and LinkedIn score.
description:
Social media accessibility is an incredibly important tool in modern society. It is not just the young who access social media, with 40% of people over the age of 65 interacting on social networking sites and almost 70% of people aged 50 to 64. As the percentage of recruiters who use LinkedIn is now 95%, social media is becoming an essential part of negotiating the current working environment.
The main reason why social media is not accessible is that social networking sites and apps are almost continually refreshed. Facebook sometimes changes twice a day. This, coupled with the lack of a formal testing process, means that what may be accessible today may be literally gone tomorrow.
I'll go through the accessibility issues of each of the six main social media sites (Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Pinterest, Instagram and LinkedIn) and discusses ways that you can make sure your social media content is accessible.

name: Web Accessibility: Finding Sharable A-Ha Moments for Buy-in
abstract: Whether you’re a web accessibility expert or just starting out, this non-technical talk will cover lots of angles for how to find that ‘oh I get it now’ moment.  This presentation is fast-paced and a bit different.
description:
How do you convince people that web accessibility matters? 
Getting buy-in from budget owners, developers, designers, and writers can seem like an impossible task. But it doesn’t have to be. 
Jessica has over a decade of experience working with large corporate and government organizations around the world that struggle with this problem.
This non-technical talk will help you explain to your peers why the work you do is so important.  You’ll learn how to unlock that 'ah-ha' moment to help you get the buy-in you need to make accessibility matter to your organization.

name: What Grade Did Your Screen Reader Get in Arithmetic
abstract: Technologies exist for accessible math content for the blind. Come learn where they work & the surprising places they do not. Together we will take a math quiz using a screen reader, hear student feedback, & discuss building a better STEM future.
description:
Technologies, media formats and corresponding workflows exist for creating accessible electronic mathematical content. It is widely stated that eText with math expressions encoded in MathML can be accessed independently by readers with blindness by using speech from a screen reading program. However, it is not widely known that most screen reading software lacks the capability to speak even basic algebraic expressions accurately and unambiguously.

Many say that to study math successfully a student who is blind must first learn braille. However, not everyone that is blind reads braille. If a student needs to complete only one math course to complete their degree requirements, they should not have to learn the UEB and Nemeth braille codes just to complete it. Expensive refreshable braille displays should not be required to access the wealth of accessible math content across the internet.

Together we will use a screen reader to take a short auditory quiz, learn why speech access to math content is important, learn where the technologies work and the surprising places where they do not and finally, hear feedback from students that use screen readers to access math.

We will make the case that the accessibility community should pool our efforts to determine an effective path forward. Vendors should work with math accessibility experts, so their AT tools rise to the promise of speaking math content accurately, unambiguously, and consistently with established math speech grammars.

name: Can WCAG Alone Ensure Accessibility of LMS
abstract: The purpose of this session is to discuss, based on data from the U.S. and Japan, whether WCAG is a sufficient requirement to ensure LMS accessibility. We will look into the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on students with disabilities in Japan.
description:
A growing number of studies conducted in various countries shed light on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on students with disabilities. In this session, we shall attempt to add some insight to the issue based on the situation in Japan.
 We have conducted a number of studies on students and teachers with disabilities in Japan to see how they are affected by the pandemic. Firstly, we evaluated the accessibility of four different Leaning Management Systems used in the country and demonstrated that the systems made in Japan are not made to ensure accessibility at all. Also, neither teachers nor students with disabilities consult the Disability Resource Offices regarding assistive technology. Nevertheless, skilled users of assistive technology who are well accustomed to the existence of barriers were able to use the Japanese-made, inaccessible Leaning Management Systems. We have also found that some Japanese universities customized accessible open-source Learning Management Systems in a way that hindered their accessibility. An interesting point we stumbled upon is that the opinion on Leaning Management Systems varied depending on the age and the position of the persons surveyed.
 To see these points in perspective, we reviewed the nationwide surveys conducted in Japan and compared them to the surveys done in the U.S. during the same period. From the Japan-U.S. comparison, we derived that digital accessibility is truly an enormous problem in Japan.

name: Changing Faculty Mindsets on Accessibility in Courses
abstract: Faculty often wait until they receive a request for accommodation to consider accessibility in their courses. In this session we will discuss the successes, challenges, and impact of our training program on digital equity and e-inclusion in courses.
description:
Faculty often wait until they receive a request for accommodation to consider accessibility in their courses. The majority of our faculty at the University of Maine lack training, awareness and time to design accessible courses. In fall 2021 and fall 2022 we ran a faculty development program around digital equity and e-inclusion to change faculty mindsets on accessibility in courses. In this presentation, I will introduce the two iterations of the program and discuss its impact on the participants' mindsets and on their courses. I will also discuss the changes we made to our program based on feedback we received from participating faculty and I will share the current version of our program with the audience.

name: Finally – Your AT Can Follow You to Any Computer, Anywhere
abstract: “Assistive Technology on Demand” is a new service from non-profit RtF that works with the *free* Morphic program and allows AT users to have their AT show up on any computers they need to use, at home, libraries, school labs, etc.
description:
Up until now, (1) if you did not own your own computer, you could not have AT that you could use at school, at home (for homework), at the tutor’s, at the library or anywhere else.   (2) Even if you had your own computer, there are times when you need to use other computers – at school, in labs, at testing centers, at work – and your assistive technologies are not on the computers you need to use – and/or (3) the AT are not set up for you.  Kind of like being provided with glasses that are not your prescription and having to study, or work, or take a test with those.
With Assistive Technology on Demand – a new service being introduced by non-profit Raising the Floor which works in conjunction with the *free* Morphic program – AT users can now have their assistive technologies show up on any computers they need to use – and have the AT configured just as they need it.  This can be computers at school, libraries, community centers, testing centers, or family members (grandma, cousins etc.), any computer that has the free Morphic program installed on it.  Currently Morphic is being installed on shared computers at major universities, library systems, disability organizations, clinical and rehabilitation programs across the country.  Our program is looking for additional sites and systems to help further deploy, explore, and continually improve the service. We will present and demonstrate it here as well as seek feedback during session. Then invite them to exhibit hall to try.

name: Deaf and Hearing Small Group Inclusive Communication
description: Deaf and Hard-of-hearing individuals face challenges in small group communication with hearing individuals. In a mixed methods proof-of-concept study, researchers explored the relative participation and turn-taking levels using CollabAll.

name: Teach Access: Bridging the Accessibility & Education Gap
abstract: Teach Access unites industry, academia, and disability advocacy groups to introduce students to accessible design and development principles. Learn about our recent achievements, programs and future plans to ensure products are “born accessible”.
description: Teach Access is a non-profit organization collaborating with education, industry, and disability advocacy organizations to address the critical need to enhance students’ understanding of digital accessibility as they learn to design, develop, and build new technologies with the needs of people with disabilities in mind. During this presentation, Teach Access will share updates on existing programs and how they have evolved over the last few years, and also discuss new programs that are part of ongoing growth and scaling to reach 1 million students by 2030. Programs continue to evolve and expand and now include the Virtual Study Away program, Faculty Grants program, and Accessibility Skills Hiring Toolkit. New programs rolling out during Academic Year 2022-23 include the Student Career Development Series, Student Ambassador Program, Faculty Fellowship Program, and the Accessibility Curricular Materials Repository. Preliminary data from the updated Accessibility Skills Gap Survey launching in October 2022 will also be shared. Attendees will learn how they can get involved with Teach Access, either individually or by recruiting their organization/institution to join.

name: Accessibility of Digital Learning for Students in Canada
abstract: We assess students’ accessibility experiences with online learning from K-12 and post-secondary institutions with mixed-methods during COVID-19. We can connection educational policy landscape in Canada to classroom experiences in Canada.
description:
Through two related projects, we assessed the difficulties that blind and partially sighted students face when taking online classes in K-12 education and at a post-secondary institutions during COVID-19. Using a mixed methodology including: a literature review, a policy scan, survey analysis and key informant interviews identify three key issues. These are that course content and designers need to understand accessibility needs of learners, rigid evaluation frameworks and lack of instructor training with OLMS can create barriers for students with disabilities. 
In a national survey of student experiences note the lack adequate support, with course materials arriving 2 to 3 weeks late. Many students' responses also explain the general inaccessibility of their coursework, including textbooks, online articles, and classroom. At the K-12 level, every school board has an accessibility policy regarding the goals and guidelines they have in place for ensuring equal access to education for all their students. Many school board policies discuss accessible materials and formats but not specifically in an online learning framework. In summary, the online learning environments in Canadian K-12 and postsecondary education during COVID-19 were sometimes difficult to navigate. Integrated approaches to improve accessibility of online learning will improve the “future state” for students with disabilities.

name: Automated Accessibility Checking Open-Sourced by IBM
abstract: Delve deep into the IBM Equal Access Accessibility Checker. This open-source tool will help you get your web application from inaccessible to accessible with easy-to-understand tools making developers and auditors become accessibility experts.
description:
IBM’s accessibility team has opened-sourced and completely redesigned its accessibility checking software. This talk will not be a product sales pitch. Our tools are now freely available to designers, developers, and accessibility auditors on the Chrome store GitHub. Lessons learned and innovations in this talk come from IBM’s own journey over the last several years to have accessibility issues fixed earlier in the product’s life cycle and from moving accessibility into the design phase. By leveraging IBM Design Thinking, open-sourcing its software tools, expanding the frameworks and browser coverage, improving automation, increasing comprehensive rules, and by focusing on the end user, we have done exactly that. 

The open-source code hosted on GitHub was used to re-develop the entire suite of accessibility software tools. With support for both Chrome and Firefox, development operations with Karma and NodeJS modules, and expanding to include Cypress, and testing frameworks such as Selenium and Jest. We have been successful in seeing adoption of these tools with over 13,000 active users in the Chrome and Firefox stores.

Our users are now more efficiently able to design (prevent issues), quickly identify accessibility issues, more effectively tackle accessibility problems, and more easily report to stakeholders. User feedback over the last couple years from the freely available tools has led to improvements that will be highlighted in this talk.

name: Moving Accessibility Upstream: A TV Platform Case Study
abstract: How did a major streaming service move the dial on accessibility? We share strategic, tactical, and technical challenges and how we overcame them together, building organizational maturity and improving the return on accessibility.
description:
TPGi worked with a major video streaming service on accessibility. After initial in-house accessibility efforts had made some progress, they were ready to scale up all of their target platforms: smart TVs, mobile apps, and web. They recognized the need for an accessibility journey and kicked off the collaboration. Accessibility audits and training were expected from the start, but the project also had built-in flexibility to deploy any of TPGi’s expert services. 
 
We describe our solutions to questions and challenges from a year-long collaboration: 
•	Choosing the scope of initial audits: platforms and functional breadth  
•	Lessons learned from collaborations with designers  
•	Setting the tempo of accessibility role-based training  
•	Applying accessibility best practices to a smart TV app: research, iteration, and emerging norms  
•	Defining a partnership between in-house and outside accessibility experts  
•	Innovating the format of accessibility design artifacts and reference guides  
•	Measures of success for the digital products and for the organization

name: Accessible Tech for Everyone/Everywhere: College & Workplace
abstract: Accessible technology maximizes inclusion. Presenters from Vanderbilt University and NASA will share their unique perspectives on implementing accessible technology within college and the workplace.
description:
This session features representatives from Vanderbilt University (VU) and the National Aeronautics Space Administration (NASA). The organizations will share their unique perspectives on how accessible technology impacts all facets of the user experience within college and the workplace.

Discussion topics will include: 
•	Ways that VU and NASA currently addresses accessibility
•	Challenges faced by organizations with implementing accessible technology
•	Best practices for how schools and workplaces can improve accessibility
•	How to raise awareness around accessibility 
•	Strategies to prepare college students to enter the workforce

name: Breaking the Exclusion Cycle in the Metaverse
abstract: Preventing digital exclusion as the Metaverse takes shape is a must. But how? Learn how inclusively designed immersive spaces can create impactful learning experiences and bring people together in meaningful ways across industries.
description: Preventing digital exclusion as the Metaverse takes shape is a must. So how can we do that? By listening to people with disabilities, creating inclusive technology, and using new tools without barriers. While it might not be simple, the goal of digital inclusion in immersive technologies within the Metaverse can change many lives. Attendees will learn how inclusive immersive digital spaces can create impactful learning experiences and bring people together in meaningful ways. They will also learn how to identify and help resolve inaccessible digital immersive experiences in everyday life.

name: Virtual Reality as a Modality From a Sales and Therapist Perspective
abstract: This talk will go over the logistics of VR in the rehab setting and what treating and using the device in patient treatment looks like.
description: VR in rehab continues to grow and become more accessible. Despite this accessibility, what does it actually look like and translate to within the rehab setting? This talk, hosted by Arik Yates and Megan Christiana, will go over the logistics of VR in the rehab setting and what treating and using the device in patient treatment looks like.

name: Bridging the Access Gap in SAT Preparation
abstract: BVI students have challenges in preparing for SAT as resources are often inaccessible. We present a new system to quickly convert online SAT samples into multiple accessible version that best fits BVI students’ need and desired output format.
description: Significant progress has been made in ensuring blind and visually impaired (BVI) students get the necessary accommodations for taking SAT. However very little work has been done towards making critical preparation materials accessible. BVI students do not get enough preparation materials as their sighted peers (e.g., free SAT samples, apps), which puts them at a significant disadvantage in preparing for these competitive exams. To bridge this access gap, we have developed a novel AI-powered system, Yebi, that converts visual SAT samples into accessible output formats for: (1) Braille and tactile graphics, (2) screenreaders, (3) multisensory digital access on Yebi app, (4) Braille readers, and (5) audio devices. This first-of-its-kind system not only dynamically creates accessible version of SATs but do so in an intuitive way such that: (1) the graphics are optimized based on BANA guidelines for tactile rendering via embossers, (2) the graphics on the Yebi app support interactivity via audio-tactile feedback on smartphones, (3) the math expressions on audio output are delivered as spoken math as it would be read by an experienced narrator, (4) math via tactile output is supported for both Nemeth and UEB. Furthermore, the system also provides tools and mechanisms for editing, modifying, and previewing the contents prior to downloading them. Initial evaluations with expert transcribers indicated significant time savings and efficiency in authoring accessible SAT samples.

name: When Assistive Technology Meets Mainstream
abstract: Are you a blind technology user, a parent of a blind child, or a professional VI teacher? Come to hear a unique view on assistive technology that will assist you in choosing the right tools for equality and success.
description:
The presentation will cover several topics:
1. Introduction - who I am, a little background about myself, and how I became an assistive technology developer.
2. My experience of being educated as a blind person in Israel using only mainstream technologies, without relying on modern blindness specific equipment, such as dedicated notetakers, in comparison to many English speaking countries. I will emphasize the advantages and challenges of such approach.
3. What happens when a mainstream tech company decides to become an assistive technology provider? Examples of advantages and problems to that approach, a specially when it comes to minor markets.
4. My vision on developing dedicated assistive technology devices for blind people that will only be mainstream based, while providing all dedicated blindness functionality. First hand experience.

name: Bringing Everyone Together Whether You Feel It or See It
abstract: Even if there is a blind person in your family, you can make precious memories reading books together. SENSEE's solutions make it possible for everyone to enjoy it.
description:
The word, SENSEE, is a combination of “SENSE” and “SEE.”
There are so many options for books. We can purchase printed books, e-books and audiobooks wherever and whenever we want. But what about the visually impaired?
The core of SENSEE's technology is to convert the original data into a format for the visually impaired. We have our own server and software that make it possible, and we can convert the data into formats such as braille files, texts, daisy files, and others.
Our ultimate goal is to provide everyone with an e-book and audiobook experience through technology.
SENSEE’s braille books show letters and braille at the same time. Let’s imagine visually impaired parents with non-disabled children.
It’s a precious memory for a family to read books to their children.
Our books make it possible. SENSEE’s philosophy for books is “communication” and “together.”

name: Conquer A11y Challenges During Software Design & Development
abstract: Including the user in the earliest design and development steps is vital. In this session, we will provide insights into our Software development practices and learning regarding designing and developing, focusing on Accessibility and Usability.
description: Including the user in the earliest design and development steps is vital. In this session, we will provide insights into our Software development practices and learning regarding designing and developing, focusing on Accessibility and Usability.

name: From Accessibility Checks to Design Partnership
abstract: In this session, University of Washington accessibility experts will share the accessibility journeys of Workday, Zoom, Mural, and ServiceNow and how they incorporated accessibility throughout their development processes.
description:
The University of Washington has collaborated with many software companies to help them to incorporate accessibility in their development process. In this session, UW accessibility experts will share their journeys to accessibility of Workday, ServiceNow, Zoom and how they incorporated accessibility throughout their development processes.

Many companies are trying hard to make more accessible software, however their designers and developers rarely have formal education and training in accessibility principles. Companies typically have well-established processes for software design and development, but lack a cohesive approach to ensuring accessibility for their products essential workflows.

Incorporating non-familiar accessibility concepts in the software development process can be a challenge for companies that lack this experience. While all companies have their own software development processes, they are unique in their approaches and these can’t be easily copied from one company to another. There are, however, commonalities that can be used to help companies develop their own recipe for accessibility success. Most of these companies have separate design, developer and QA/QE teams and while there is often some communication between these teams, we often observe that there is no effective communication between them regarding accessibility. This can produce islands of accessibility but neglects to provide a homogenous functional accessibility throughout the product.

name: Beyond Websites: NCAM and Media Accessibility
abstract: Each day brings intriguing challenges to GBH’s NCAM. Presenters will discuss accessibility challenges and solutions to complex health information and how they developed a universally designed, audio described tour of the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center.
description:
After 50 years of research and solutions in accessible media, GBH’s NCAM continues to innovate with new partners – providing accessibility consulting beyond Web site audits and WCAG training. This presentation will explore two of NCAM’s recent collaborations.

NCAM and NextGen Healthcare are working to bring accessible UI to NextGen's patient and staff healthcare tools. With a wide range of software in their portfolio, NextGen is prioritizing frequent user experiences and adding accessibility review to their development process as product are refreshed. Health information is complex and patients need accurate supports. This collaboration is aiming to provide excellent access. A demonstration will be provided.

The U.S. Capitol Visitor Center re-opened this year after an extensive redesign, complete with an audio-described tour developed by NCAM and GBH’s Media Access Group. NCAM collaborated with The Office of Congressional Accessibility Services to describe the architecture, furniture, documents, photos, and history presented in the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center, in an audio tour intended for visitors who are blind or have low vision, and universally designed to be enjoyed by everyone.

NCAM anticipates that these partnerships will lead to more opportunities for accessibility in these and other fields.  Additional collaborations and accessibility projects will be mentioned during the presentation.

name: Impact of COVID-19 on Workers with Sight Loss
abstract: Examining longitudinal employment trends in a post-pandemic work world for blind or partially sighted adults.
description: The COVID-19 pandemic had significant impacts on the employment rate and employment experiences of people with disabilities. Through a series of studies during the pandemic, CNIB Research undertook an analysis of the impact of the pandemic on the lived experiences of people who are blind and partially sighted in Canada. From these studies, we identified that the employment rates of working age Canadians with sight loss had decreased significantly during the early months of the pandemic. While these rates have since rebounded, we became interested in understanding the current employment experiences of working-age adults with sight loss in Canada, as compared to our previous studies conducted in 2018 and 2019. While a number of metrics of employment had not significantly changed during the pandemic, when we compared the results of the 2018, 2019 and 2021 studies, we identified that there were decreases in the proportion of people working full-time; increases in the number of people working from home; increased reliance on technology and accessible technology training; and, qualitative changes to the work experience. The ongoing integration between technology and the workplace is a trend that must be continually monitored in a post-pandemic work world, and will play an important role in the future of work for blind or partially sighted adults.

name: Accessibility and Universal Design (UD) Connection with DEI
abstract: Organizations across industries are grappling with the intersection of accessibility and UD with diversity, equity and inclusion. This session will share examples and factors of common application of inclusive design and inclusionary practices.
description:
As diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) is prioritized by organizations, what is the connection with accessibility and universal design (UD)? What is a possible new paradigm approach for an organization to integrate these concepts?

These questions will be explored in a mixed presentation and discussion format to address session objectives:
•	Understand accessibility and universal design (UD) definitions
•	Identify action steps to facilitate a paradigm shift in accessibility and universal design in connection with diversity equity and inclusion (DEI)
•	Application of inclusive design and Inclusionary practices

Presenters will share definitions and how to develop common understanding around accessibility, UD and DEI within their organization. Content will include accessibility and UD efforts that include DEI integration and reduction of exclusionary accessibility-related practices. Presenters will share examples of strategies across industries (higher education, publishing, eCommerce, etc.) which work to unify UD, A11Y and DEI. 

Presenters are subject matter experts in accessibility, universal design, strategic planning, and training facilitation with organizations in the private and educational sectors.

name: An Accessible BLE Beacon Based Indoor Wayfinding System
description: Our work discusses: i) practical lessons learned from designing, deploying and testing a BLE beacon-based indoor wayfinding system in a multi-floor indoor environment, and ii) ways to improve end-user experience and make the system accessible to all.

name: I Never Knew a Website Could Hurt Someone
abstract: Can a website cause pain? Yes!
description:
"When you’re new to accessibility, it is easy to think it is only about blind people who use screen readers. After all, blind people have a really hard time on the web. They can’t see the screen. They can’t see the mouse pointer, so they can’t use a mouse. They rely on screen readers for access. But can a website cause a user pain? Yes. I’ve seen it happen.

During this talk, Karl Groves will talk about users who are rarely considered and how designers and developers can help each of them through understanding the Web itself."

name: FED Talk: Accessibility with the Access Board and GSA
description:
The U.S. Access Board and the General Services Administration (GSA) will provide guidance on the interpretation and implementation of the revised Section 508 Standards and address recurring issues. The presentation will address using the standards to evaluate and acquire 508-conformant information technology.
The presenters will review the 508 Standards and address questions about specific provisions and definitions. Topics include Government-wide implementation and testing and implementing Section 508 across an IT product's lifecycle, including procurement, design and development, testing, and operations and maintenance.

name: Disability Bias & New Frontiers in Artificial Intelligence
description: Learn about bias in artificial intelligence which can discriminate against marginalized groups.  When built accessibly, AI systems can promote fairness and enhance the lives of everyone, in amazing and unprecedented ways.

name: Audio Describer As Cast Member: AD At Every Performance
abstract: Learn how ALL performances of a theatrical run can be made accessible with high-quality audio description.
description:
Most audio description services in the United States for performing arts are based on a volunteer, limited preview/two-described-performances model.

The Audio Description Project of the American Council of the Blind proposed a more expansive audio description arrangement for two productions again at Washington, DC’s Arena Stage. An audio describer attended rehearsals for each production, met with the stage director, actors, the designers (scenic, costumes, lighting, sound) and developed an audio description script throughout the three-week rehearsal period. The script was then available for that same describer to voice at every performance beginning with opening night and with, of course, an eye on stage action as minor changes in action could occur from performance to performance. The arrangement had two benefits: more time was available to carefully observe the theatrical process and construct descriptive language that was more thorough and considered; and people desiring the service could attend any performance with no advance notice and be assured of access to the visual aspects of the production. Other innovations included Braille and large-print programs, models of the set and props in the lobby, and a tactile “scrapbook” of costume pieces. The arrangement resulted in a tripling in attendance by people using audio description.

name: Changing Daily Lives of Children and Adults Battling With Dyslexia
abstract: Learn more about a free app that helps people with dyslexia.
description: MYdys by FACIL’iti is a free app that helps people with dyslexia better understand what they read, creating a more inclusive opportunity for the millions who live with this disorder. According to the WHO, nearly 800M people worldwide have dyslexia, including 40M Americans. MYdys aims to improve the lives of millions of dyslexic people struggling with basic day-to-day reading tasks. Imagine not being able to make out a simple label, read a price or clothing size, or understand a school or work assignment MYdys, configured in a few seconds, adapts to the needs of the user by simply taking a photo of a text with a smartphone. This app helps people with dyslexia find employment, provides them more autonomy in accessing general information or completing online transactions, and enjoy culture.

name: Accessibility Guidelines for Mobile App Development
abstract: Our presentation shares guidelines that mobile apps can follow to make their apps accessible and how accessibility can be incorporated into the software development lifecycle. We will focus on how we use these principles for the development.
description:
Guideline 1: Designing user experiences - The first guideline should be incorporated early on in the design process. When designing an app, care must be taken to ensure that any previous user feedback is incorporated and also the design must be simple to understand and should be easily accessible to the users.

Guideline 2: Development process - The second guideline is to be followed when developing the app. The app must work well with screen readers (e.g. TalkBack or VoiceOver) and should have full keyboard support.

Guideline 3: Quality assurance and beta testing - The best way to test the accessibility of a feature is to test it in-house before releasing it to external users. Teams can set up Quality Assurance (QA) processes in place for carrying out this task.

Guideline 4: User research - Even after testing it thoroughly in-house and making sure the app is accessible, gathering user feedback in a smaller group testing can help polish the product even further. When a user uses the app in real-time, you can clearly see how easy or hard it is for the user to access the app and the feature.

Guideline 5: Addressing defects and user feedback - Once we gather enough feedback from the users to act on, the team must work on addressing those issues and release new app updates with the fixes for the user. This continuous process of fixing accessibility bugs and addressing user feedback helps make the product better accessible and usable.

name: Experience Study - Make Your Digital Products Successful
abstract: If you are puzzled about how to make your digital products successful for all users, join this session and see how you can peel the different layers of “digital accessibility compliance” easily to make your products insightful and successful.
description:
Technology has evolved to a point that societies are depended on the digital products and services it provides in all aspects of our lives. The lack of digital accessibility is also exasperated by the aging population that is increasing rapidly in so many countries. Assistive technologies are readily advancing and are available to everyone. As the need for building digital accessibility is highlighted in various ways, for many there is still a myth and a fear of how it can or should be incorporated in a product’s design and development life cycle (DLC). In addition, the current Usability Testing methods and approaches have not evolved to meet the needs, or satisfy all users. 
The management of many organizations still refer to accessibility testing as optional requirements and not necessary for the success of their products. Thus, contributing to the rapid increase of their own technical debts, and failure of their products.
When the objectives of usability testing and accessibility testing are compared, they are not separate entities. In fact, they are one and the same. Without the digital accessibility requirements, the usability testers are not mindful of the needs and are not testing for all aspects of a product, with all types of test subjects. This is often based on lack of knowledge and empathy, as well as organizational mandates. So, the testing is incomplete.
Experience Study offers a wholistic evaluation and testing approach throughout the product DLC.

name: Achieving Digital Bliss for Screen Reader Users
abstract: This talk is all about celebrating websites, that make screen reader browsing experience digital bliss!
description:
Many low vision and blind users use screen readers, as do some users with learning disabilities. While screen readers have been around for decades, using a screen reader on the web has not always been easy.

In the very early days of the Internet, before the proliferation of the graphical user interface, it was easy for screen readers to relay text to users. However, with the inception of the graphical user interface, meaningful use of the screen reader became problematic.

Fortunately, screen readers advanced, and the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines were developed. With these guidelines in place, and with the continual improvement of screen readers interfacing with the graphical world, screen reader use became easier.

Now it is possible for a screen reader user to browse the web with digital bliss. This means that the screen reader user will have no problem comprehending, and interacting with, content on web pages that are designed with accessibility guidelines in mind. 

In this presentation, presenters will demonstrate and discuss several web pages that result in digital bliss. While one presenter uses the screen reader on each page, the other presenter will talk about key elements on the page that make it a pleasure to browse.

name: Equal Access to Phone Calls for Deaf/HH/DeafBlind by Nagish
abstract: Join us to learn how people with hearing loss can communicate privately, accurately, and efficiently using the Nagish mobile app for iOS and Android devices.
description:
During the session, we will explain what Nagish is and how it creates equal access to communications for people who are Deaf/HoH/DeafBlind or to people with speech impediments. 

Following the explanation, we will provide a demo of Nagish, followed by a live testimonial of a DeafBlind individual who uses Nagish to communicate.

name: Finding Assistive Technology Solutions for College Students
abstract: Develop a Student-Centered Strategy using Assistive Technologies that is right sized for the student, and the Accessibility Center that meets their immediate, short term and long term needs. The right sized accommodation is the one that works.
description: Learn how to develop and implement a Student-Centered Strategy of Assistive Technology for college students seeking accommodations for their classes. By taking a student through a planned course of action to determine their Technology Readiness and ability to adapt new strategies of learning using Assistive Technologies, you will determine the right size and fit to meet their needs. Understanding when and how to elevate the accommodation intervention for the student to meet their specific needs for the immediate, short-term and long-term solutions, while also aligning with the college’s resources can increase the chances of an effective solution that won’t overwhelm the student or strap the Accessibility Centers ability to serve them effectively. The right sized accommodation is the one that works for the student and is deliverable by the Accessibility Center. Learn about some common solutions for low level accommodations needs and explore innovated answers to more complex student access needs using the latest in Assistive Technology.

name: JAWS Scripting: The Ultimate Workplace Accommodation
abstract: JAWS Scripting has helped countless numbers of people gain, and maintain employment over the years. Learn what it is, and how it can benefit employees and employers alike.
description: The JAWS Scripting language is a powerful tool that can be used to bridge the gap between JAWS and software tools that are not built to be accessible. Think of it as a way to reprogram JAWS to deal with inaccessible applications or websites. Since the early days of JAWS, scripting has been the mechanism that has helped countless people gain and maintain successful employment. This session will demonstrate the effectiveness of scripting and how it helps companies and employees succeed.

name: Accessibility Q&A with the Access Board and GSA
abstract: Accessibility experts address questions about the 508 Standards in areas including procurements, validating accessibility conformance, and analyzing ICT.  Focus is on issues and resource most applicable to users, developers, and content creators.
description:
The U.S. Access Board and the General Services Administration (GSA) will provide guidance on the interpretation and implementation of the revised Section 508 Standards and address recurring issues. The session will address using the standards to evaluate and acquire 508-conformant information technology.   It is intended for entry level to intermediate audience. 
Presenters Kathy Eng and Timothy Creagan of the U.S. Access Board and Michael Horton and Andrew Nielson of GSA will review the 508 Standards and address questions about specific provisions and definitions.  Topics include Government-wide implementation and testing, and implementing Section 508 across an IT product’s lifecycle, including procurement, design and development, testing, and operations and maintenance.
Finally, they will describe resources and technical support available at www.Section508.gov.  These resources include procurement tools for acquiring officials, and best practices in creating Accessibility Conformance Reports (ACR) for market research and selection during acquisition of IT.

name: Introducing Tech First Policy Into a Tech First State
abstract: History will be provided of Technology First in Ohio including tech related Medicaid waiver services & the Executive Order declaring Ohio a Technology First state. We will discuss Ohio’s Technology First rule, how it was implemented, and next steps.
description:
This session will provide a brief history of the Technology First movement in the state of Ohio, the first Technology First state in the nation.  This history will start with an overview of the Home & Community based waiver services that focus on technology as well as our Executive Order declaring Ohio a Technology First state.  Then we will move into a discussion regarding Ohio’s Technology First rule. 
 
This rule went into effect on April 21, 2022 and applies to all people in our developmental disabilities service system regardless of age, residence, or enrollment on a Medicaid waiver.  This rule was developed at the recommendation of our Technology First Advisory Committee and Technology First Task Force.  The key components of our policy will be detailed to the audience.  These key components consist of:  

Definitions – A new definition was created for Technology Solutions

Agency Policy – All County Boards of Developmental Disabilities as well as Intermediate Care Facilities must develop a Technology First Policy

Planning – Teams should work together to explore and discuss how technology can meet the needs of the people supported in our system as a first option

Collaboration – We must partner with other technology first agencies and systems in our state to move technology first forward 

How this policy was implemented across the state will also be discussed as well as next steps for Technology First in the state of Ohio.

name: What’s New on APH’s Road to Code
abstract: Get ready to choose your own adventure with your fellow participants in this interactive presentation with CJ Puzzles. Explore the new sights along APH’s Road to Code with the CJ Coding module and learn about exciting careers in technology.
description:
Today’s students are starting to learn computer coding concepts as early as pre-school. With the ubiquitous availability of mobile devices and tablets, tools for younger students to begin playing with coding concepts have become easier to acquire. Whether a student downloads a mobile app, accesses a web coding game, or participates in an online simulation, there are options available for any level of coding. 

However, for students who are blind or have low vision, such coding tools are less available. Often the apps used by their sighted classmates are inaccessible or concepts are challenging to understand. 

This session will discuss new features, including the CJ Puzzles and coding module. It will also demonstrate how APH has made coding tools accessible. We will also discuss careers in technology and the importance of teaching coding concepts from an early age.  

Over the past several years, the American Printing House for The Blind (APH) has been developing a roadmap of accessible coding tools meant to mirror the tools used by sighted students. If the tools used by the rest of the class could not be made accessible, APH has also created complementary tools which often use physical objects to solidify coding concepts for the student with visual impairments. From accessible apps to physical engineering and robotics kits, APH’s goal is to provide tools to enable students of all ages with visual impairments to obtain necessary coding skills alongside their sighted classmate

name: VR Training to Facilitate Blind Photography for Navigation
description: This session describes how blind people use a camera in smartphone-based navigation apps, and the challenges they face using a camera for this purpose. It also describes a novel virtual reality-based training environment to address these challenges.

name: How to Create Your Very Own A11y Training Program
abstract: Learn how you can build an enterprise training program from the ground up, the lessons we learned along the way in building one at Navy Federal and how you can raise awareness about digital accessibility at your organization!
description: Navy Federal created and launched a comprehensive enterprise digital accessibility training and awareness program, resulting in the creation of an Accessibility Community of Practice and an Accessibility Academy. The Academy provided role-based training to over 850 employees last year. Learning paths included roles like designers, developers, product owners and content creators. Learn how we built this program from the ground up, the lessons we learned along the way and how you can create your very own training program in your organization.
