name: Navigating Challenging Conversations with Partners
abstract: When driving accessibility initiatives, leaders will encounter partners who push back. How we respond to this push-back can have affect outcomes. Let's examine how to navigate challenging conversations with cross-functional partners.
description: When driving accessibility initiatives, leaders will encounter partners who push back. How we respond to this push-back can have drastically different effects on the outcome, ranging from wholesale rejection of accessibility to complete mindset shifts toward genuine disability inclusion. In this session, we’ll examine how to navigate challenging conversations with cross-functional partners in a range of scenarios to achieve the best outcomes for our teams, our products and services, and most importantly for the people who will use those products and services. We’ll cover topics such as setting clear expectations around non-negotiables, acknowledging others’ constraints and pressures with compassion, educating with personally meaningful insights, and framing accessibility in ways that align to a growth mindset. The presentation will include supporting slides if permitted by the event space, and all meaningful information in the talk (including information on slides) will be presented verbally as well.

name: Technology for Accelerating Growth in Reading and Writing
abstract: Traumatic events have exacerbated unfinished learning and access to grade level content due to extended remote learning environments. It is time to leverage technology to close the gaps so that all students master essential literacy skills.
description:
COVID-19 and other traumatic events have put a spotlight on unfinished learning, especially in our underserved communities. Literacy Skills that a teacher might expect students to have are not as developed and present access and equity issues regarding engagement with grade level content. It is essential that gaps in literacy skills be closed so that students are prepared for the grade level skill competencies expected at the next school level.
A review of the latest research and testing data will be reviewed.  In addition, research proven techniques that support student success, such as acceleration and social emotional learning will be discussed. This session will explore the top technological tools that are designed to increase student skill development and mastery. Tools that will support decoding, encoding, comprehension, vocabulary, and written expression will be explored.

name: Combining DIY and Purchased AT in the Workplace
abstract: This presentation focuses on utilizing DIY and low-high tech AT options in various employment settings. Learn about multiple materials to consider in DIY projects.  Case studies, videos and images will highlight ways to implement AT in the workplace.
description: This presentation’s main focus is to discuss the benefits of combining DIY and “off-the-shelf” AT to make accommodations and/or modifications in the workplace setting to allow individuals to be as independent and efficient as possible. The first part of the presentation will discuss and demo ideas of AT for individuals with varying impairments (sensory, cognitive, physical and mental health) in multiple types of employment settings and jobs. The process for AT decision making will be reviewed as well as ways to consider and use various levels of AT including DIY, low, mid and high tech. When discussing DIY options, multiple materials and methods will be showcased. The second part of the presentation will discuss how combining the DIY and purchased AT can be beneficial in the work setting via case studies. The presenter will use videos and images to show and discuss various AT possibilities

name: Accessibility in the Mobile Development Lifecycle
abstract: Mobile apps are developed and deployed at a very fast pace, so how can accessibility become a part of that? With automation, quick testing, and definition of done for accessibility we can make it apart of the dev process!
description:
In world where all things point to web developers and how to get accessibility as part of their lifecycle, where is all the information about mobile? Mobile application development is at its highest rate ever, so why is accessibility left out of the conversation? 


Mobile accessibility has been a hot topic over the last few years and mobile developers have been asking how can we effectively bring in accessibility to our development lifecycle without slowing down our day to day processes?

In this talk we will cover ways in which we can leverage accessibility automation quick screen reader testing and build a definition of done for accessibility in order to help bring it into the mobile development lifecycle.

name: How AudioGames Can Inform Development of Accessible Websites
abstract: This discussion will address the fun-filled topic of audio gaming, while providing an insight into how concepts in audio gaming relate to developments in the field of web accessibility. Audio properties, maps, and graphs are the topics of focus.
description: AudioGames are games which rely on audio-only output in response to user input. These games have proliferated in the community of blind individuals for a better part of the early 21st century. AudioGames have entertained kids and adults alike. But how can audio-based games be leveraged to help develop accessible websites? This talk will take an informal approach to informing attendees about what AudioGames are, and how certain concepts found in these games can be employed to realize complex website features.

name: Assessing Digital Accessibility – A Strategic Approach
abstract: Learn about how your organisation can grow its digital accessibility. Find out how a gap analysis can help to prepare a roadmap towards digital accessibility. Learn about the components of a gap analysis report and how to implement its findings.
description:
Assessing the digital accessibility maturity of an organisation assists them to know with confidence where they are currently and what they need to do so that they can become more mature with respect to delivering more accessible digital outcomes. This benefits their customers, employees and other stakeholders.
Intopia typically undertakes a gap analysis which empowers organisations to move from where they currently sit on the digital accessibility continuum to where they wish to be over time.
This presentation will outline the components of that gap analysis. We will explain the value and content of stakeholder interviews, reviews of strategic documentation such as policies, plans and processes as well as samples of comms and website content.
We will discuss the structure of a report, talk about risk assessment and recommendations designed to meet the specific needs of an individual organisation. We will also discuss additional information which can help organisations, such as suggested improvements to existing policies, checklists and resources they can use to follow up the learnings from the report.
The presentation will conclude with thoughts as to what organisations can do with respect to next steps once they have received a gap analysis and how they can put in place a plan to become more mature with respect to digital accessibility. This will include tips on ensuring that motivation remains high and progress is institutionalised so that it survives changes in personnel.

name: Addressing the Workforce Shortage through Tech
abstract: Technology First & the DSP Workforce Crisis: Ohio’s Future Paved by Technology will be presented including data and indicators of progress.  Additional statewide efforts will be reviewed linking to Ohio’s Workforce Taskforce & Technology First.
description:
Ohio has published a report that details data regarding Direct Support Professional recruitment & retention, assistive technology & remote supports, and our commitment to technology to sustain our service system.  Based on this data, Ohio has set benchmarks related to technology and the workforce crisis.  These benchmarks will be described in the session and are as follows:

Indicator 1: Remote Supports service will increase 15 percent by June 30, 2023

Indicator 2: 18 percent of people who use residential supports will use remote supports by 2026

Indicator 3: 25 percent of people who utilize HCBS Services will use Technology or Virtual Supports by 2026

Additional efforts of the state will also be described such as Governor DeWine's Administration recently launching a PSA campaign for recruiting direct care workers, including DSPs. The ad pushes applicants to go to the Ohio Means Jobs website to find job openings. Providers in Ohio are encouraged to post openings on the Ohio Means Jobs website for job seekers to find easily and include "DSP" in the title.

This session will wrap up by linking these efforts with the work of Ohio’s Workforce Crisis Task Force as well as our Technology First movement.

name: Utilizing Campus Resources to Reduce Outsourcing Costs
abstract: We will be sharing lessons learned from working with blind students who have attended our university. We switched from sending textbooks and complex materials to outside vendors, to producing all Braille and tactile graphics ourselves for much less.
description: In the summer of 2016, 3 blind students enrolled at Salem State University in 3 very different programs. It had been years since we had worked with a blind student, and it was a trial by fire and a lot of learning as we went. Initially we depended a lot on outsourcing textbooks and complex materials to outside vendors, but over time we slowly transitioned to producing all Braille, tactile graphics, and alternative format course materials ourselves, in-house, at a significant cost-savings to the institution. Student workers and investing in a few updated products helped make this happen. When the pandemic came along, we were able to use some of the same work flows and existing students workers to assist faculty in captioning recorded lectures for their online courses. Join us as we share our trials, victories, and practical strategies that worked, and continues to work, for the now 6 blind students we have had (and have) the pleasure of working with, as well as the ways it has helped our university culture overall.

name: Three Tools to Improve College Readiness for BVI Students
abstract: Learn about three innovative tools to help college aspiring high school students with visual impairments identify and develop the assistive technology and executive functioning skills needed to meet post secondary educational and vocational goals.
description: Students with visual impairments looking to engage in college and work need a range of tools to access materials efficiently. Perkins School for the Blind has developed several tools to help students (and their educators) identify skill to teach in the K-12 system, to support students to meet their post secondary goals, including assistive technology. The Perkins College Readiness Checklist, Technology Competencies and Promising Practices for Disability Resource Centers can help you plan, develop students' executive functioning, and help students to gain understanding about their goals and the skills they need to meet their high school and postsecondary goals, including further education, training and employment.

name: UDL Classroom Management: Achieving Optimal Sensory Arousal
abstract: Ky is using approach using UDL techniques to merge sensory processing strategies with academic instruction. In this session participants will learn to identify sensory processing needs and academic strategies to satiate student sensory needs.
description:
Because of the recent pandemic, students across the nation were forced to participate in school virtually.  The unusual stress forced upon the students, as well as others living in their homes, was evident upon the return to a traditional school model.  Reports of students’ perceived trauma during this time resulted in a noticeable increase in disruptive behavior.  Students attempted to deal with a heightened sense of threat based on learned fear and isolation by using physical movement, sounds, and other behaviors that were disruptive to learning.

To address this new phenomenon, classrooms in Kentucky began implementing sensory rooms and sensory spaces.  Trainings across the state ensued, instructing educators on identifying sensory processing disorders and strategies to regulate and maintain homeostasis within the student.  With this emphasis, a new strategy emerged for classroom management that uses Universal Design for Learning (UDL). This innovative approach includes reading, writing, and math instruction with sensory components embedded throughout the instructional day.  This integration of sensory regulation and academic instruction uses sensory tool kits and techniques that are good for teaching all students, but absolutely essential for students that experienced trauma.  This new approach to sensory needs and disruptive behavior reduction is OARS (Optimal Arousal Reading-Writing-Math Strategies).

name: Customizing Accessibility Service Delivery
abstract: Learn how we have devised an approach to customize accessibility service delivery including how we provide services depending on the project phase, how we leverage our in-house automation tool, and how we developed our bespoke testing methodology.
description: Since accessibility services needed by product teams vary greatly depending on the project phase, team skillset, and go-to-market strategy, we have devised an approach to customize accessibility service delivery based on these criteria. We advocate a shift-left strategy to integrate accessibility throughout the product development process and this includes embedding accessibility resources in the project team. When embedded, the accessibility resource conducts in-sprint testing, reviews UX designs, creates user stories, and provides guidance to UX designers, front end developers, testers, and product owners at the appropriate phases to ensure accessible product delivery. When requested to perform accessibility audits, the audit is tailored based on phase, delivery timeline, and budget and we offer three types of audits – accessibility basic check, mini-audit, and full audit. We have created a bespoke testing methodology using the Trusted Tester methodology as the starting point but enhanced it to cover test cases related to screen readers, code scanners, contrast checkers, and other testing tools. To make accessibility easily actionable to front end developers and UX designers, we aggregated all WCAG A and AA criteria and created 12 high-level accessibility non-functional requirements. We have also developed an in-house automation tool that leverages open-source tools, performs screen reader automation, and improves our testing efficiency.

name: Piloting User Testing for Digital Accessibility at McMaster
abstract: Learn about the creation of a user testing pilot at McMaster University that foregrounds the integration of Disabled Knowledge, assistive technology users, and community-engaged relationships in digital accessibility and quality assurance work.
description: This presentation seeks to share the use of a disability-centered process in developing a user testing pilot program at a research-intensive Canadian post-secondary institution to engage in digital accessibility end-user testing. We will provide the audience context within which the program was formally solidified in 2020 in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the shifting of in-person work to remote environments; how the team of Disabled staff and students, as well as allies, were assembled with a primary focus on recruiting fluent assistive technology users for university website end-user testing; our student partnership approach to developing testing methodology and program workflows; and how the team has worked to adapt the knowledge-base produced to other digital contexts on our campus. During the first two years of this Program, we have been successful in generating a grassroots service delivery model, working with key campus partners to test their web assets for accessibility and assistive technology compatibility and to educate them about digital accessibility and quality assurance.  To date, the team has worked to test and provide feedback on 10+ institutional web projects, over half of which were strategically aligned with institutional priorities or will have a high impact on campus life for equity-deserving community members. The completion of these projects has also led to the creation of trainings and templates that can be implemented in future programs.

name: Accessibility Guided Automation Testing
abstract: This session covers how this tool helps customers continuously monitor Accessibility on their configured products at different stages (Design, Development, Testing, and Reporting) at one place.Testing time is reduced using Guided Intelligence Check
description:
Every day Phenom connects with several customers to configure multiple products such as career site, chatbots, internal mobility, etc. Most customers inquire about accessibility compliance for the configured products. Initially there was no set process and faced below challenges on:
• Accessibility Understanding and Testing Methodologies
• Dynamic content changes
• Manual process and Reporting
• Difficulty in continuous monitoring on various environments
• More QA efforts for testing
• What to focus on and where to start.
Now with the introduction of the QA Hub (Quality and Accessibility Hub) tool, the customers are delighted with the accessibility service that we are providing. 
Below are some of the key features:
• Provision to run Automated checks and monitor customer sites monthly on Accessibility Score.
• Provision to generate reports in a very detailed manner.
• Introduced an Accessibility Checker on content editor tool, where the customers can verify the customised Automation checks on the content before publishing.
• An automated Guided Intelligence Checks.
• With a powerful configuration we can: 
   1. Centralised Guided Intelligence Checks throughout the organisation.
   2. A few Guided Intelligence Checks are Automated with the help of Robot framework scripts that reduces the load on QA to perform manual testing. 
   3. Snapshot of dynamic components to perform Automation testing.
• A dashboard on the areas to improve the accessibility score.

name: Exploring Novel Designs for ASL Surveys
abstract: Join us as we reframe online survey design for Deaf people who use ASL. We discuss initial study findings and emerging practices for ASL survey interfaces.
description:
Surveys and questionnaires are essential tools for gathering data from individuals and groups. Existing survey platforms (e.g. SurveyMonkey, Google Forms, and Qualtrics) conform to established text-based UI conventions and allow users to create surveys, collect responses, and analyze data quickly and easily. 

Creating surveys in ASL makes it possible to engage the Deaf ASL-signing community ethically, respectfully, and reliably in research and other data collection efforts. However, equivalent platforms and conventions do not exist for those wishing to develop surveys in signed languages, such as American Sign Language (ASL), then collect and analyze participant responses. Instead, ASL surveys are generally built from the ground up for single use cases. 

In this session, we will discuss our study findings of unique prototype designs for ASL surveys and discuss the benefits of ensuring deaf ASL-signing audiences can engage with online surveys in their natural and primary language. Design considerations such as content-related structural elements, interactive video components, and overall layout will be discussed. 

Attendees will leave with a clearer sense of emerging design conventions that align with signed languages, as well as new visions and applications for ASL surveys that truly connect with and engage Deaf signing audiences.

name: A 4 Part Exercise to Understand Inclusivity in the Classroom
abstract: Participants will go through four exercises based on the experience that students have in trying to learn in a virtual environment and be provided examples to improve learner experiences. Note, this presentation will be highly interactive.
description:
Educational institutions today are not only being asked to be accessible but inclusive. With the sudden dramatic switch to virtual learning in early 2020, support systems that students had in with in-person learning were no longer available in the same way. The intent of this session is to provide a space for students, instructors, administrators, and others  to discuss the challenges of and solutions for teaching in an inclusive virtual learning environment. 

Participants will take part in four exercises that demonstrate the experiences of cognitive, visual, motor, and hearing impaired students in virtual learning environments. From the experiences that participants have during the exercises, they will be encouraged to discuss impacts on other student groups when, for example, a time limit is set on a test. At the end of each exercise, suggestions for improving the student experience will be provided. Participants will be invited to add their own suggestions and stories with the goal of increasing the number of solutions available to the entire group.

name: Together Again: AT for Travel and Inclusive Events
abstract: We will introduce a framework for inclusive event planning and utilization of assistive technologies to create a diverse and inclusive event. Using real life scenarios, we will provide accommodation examples and event planning tips.
description:
As the workforce returns to in-person events, employers are seeking a balance between onsite, remote, and hybrid training and development. This effort includes negotiation and openness to flexible and practical solutions.
 Presenters will highlight scenarios addressing workplace barriers involving equipment and travel policies, accessibility issues surrounding software and assistive technologies, and inclusivity of events and trainings. Cost-benefit data will be provided when available. Accessible meetings, events, and training challenges can be seen in a variety of industries.
Event planners and employers can promote social inclusion by considering accessibility both of spaces, information, and work-related travel at the earliest planning stages.  Inviting and responding to individual accommodation requests for AT can meet those needs not sufficiently addressed initially.
 Implementing accommodations across meetings, trainings, and events requires understanding of the limitations, event environment, and accommodation options. Inclusive event planning promotes professional development, job growth, and networking, while fostering a welcoming environment to enhance a sense of community, increase engagement, and encourage attendance.

name: Virtual Reality Systems for Soft Skill Development
abstract: Learn about emerging research technologies implementing virtual reality that are targeted at developing soft skills to improve employment outcomes for autistic young adults
description: Autistic individuals face poor employment outcomes relative to their neurotypical peers, with studies estimating that 50%-75% of autistic adults are unemployed or underemployed in the United States. Poor employment outcomes result in a greater need for financial and social support. Although there have been many strides in developing interventions for autistic children, there remains a gap in addressing employment challenges faced by autistic young adults entering the workforce. Soft skills, such as communication and teamwork, are not easily quantifiable, but can be practiced and improved upon. However, many of the resources available for soft skill training, such as job coaching and manualized curriculums, are expensive and not individualized. 3D simulated environments made in virtual reality can address these limitations by providing varied and individualized soft skill development systems. Our presentation will provide an overview of virtual reality and how it has been used for both hard and soft skill development. We will then present two virtual reality systems that we have developed for job interview training and teamwork skills practice. Both systems are developed to provide training to the autistic individual while also providing meaningful feedback to employers on how they can adapt their practices to improve employment outcomes. The presentation will conclude with a discussion on potential further applications of VR and current barriers.
primary_topic: Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), & Cross/Mixed Reality (XR)

name: Virtual Reality: Somewhere Between the Ditches
abstract: Is Virtual Reality (VR) a driving force in the world of emerging technologies, or has it fallen short on its promise? We’ll look at the challenges it has faced along the way, but also explore case studies where its potential has been fulfilled.
description: Once upon a time, Virtual Reality (VR) was toted as the “Empathy Engine”. But after 3 decades since its inception, is it a driving force in the world of emerging technologies, or has it fallen short on its promise? Diving headfirst into the world of VR, we’ll look at the challenges it has faced along the way, but also explore case studies where its potential has aligned with its initial vision.
primary_topic: Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), & Cross/Mixed Reality (XR)

name: Creating Outdoor Digital Maps Accessible to Blind Users
abstract: Learn how to make a complex geographic map on your app/website accessible to blind users with Audiom, the world's most inclusive map viewer. Any outdoor location map can be made accessible with this auditory and text-based virtual reality interface.
description: Digital accessible non-visual maps have traditionally been described through alternate text, presented in a table, presented as a list of nearby locations to an address, or given as turn-by-turn directions. The problem with these methods is geographic information (the main content of the map) is completely lacking or significantly diminished in these methods. For instance, users can't answer "What clockface direction is the entrance from the elevator?" Audiom is a digital web-based non-visual  map viewer that can accurately represent dynamic  geographic/spatial information non-visually. Audiom can be embedded next to an existing visual map on any app or website, and in many cases use the same data source as the visual map. The Audiom interface is a text-based and auditory virtual reality interface only requiring headphones to view. The user can move an avatar using a gesture e.g., up arrow to move north or left arrow to move west a user-defined distance, and can hear sounds representing different objects on the map through 3D audio. The process for obtaining an Audiom map is: 1) Work with the Audiom team to process the data to make sure it contains the required elements; 2) Get the data into Audiom through the Audiom server or passing it to the embedded map; and 3) View and test the map in your site/app. Audiom can currently represent any outdoor space e.g, neighborhoods, parks, campuses, transit routes, and building complexes.

name: An AI Enabled Storefront Accessibility Annotation Platform
description: Smart DoorFront is an AI-enabled storefront accessibility annotation platform that collects storefront accessibility data to address challenges for people who are blind or have low vision to locate store entrances and improve navigation experience.

name: Indoor Navigation 2023
abstract: Emerging indoor navigation technologies are making buildings and public venues accessible to people who are blind. From basic orientation to step-by-step directions, indoor navigation technology provides the ability to discover and explore.
description: The latest advancements in indoor navigation and mapping technologies aim to address the challenges of navigating without print signs in the day-to-day indoor way-finding tasks faced by people who are blind or visually impaired. Since the built environment is designed for those with vision, both indoor and outdoor environments contain a well-organized set of printed or icon-based signs to aid in navigation. Print signage is, of course, not accessible to people who are blind. Fortunately, improvements in accessible outdoor navigation became more accessible with the development of GPS devices starting in 2000 and with the introduction of several accessible iPhone and Android apps in the past few years. Unfortunately, GPS signals are blocked inside large buildings, such as airports, sports arenas, shopping malls, and the like, leaving people who are blind or visually impaired without any non-visual options for indoor navigation where there is no GPS.

name: How The Blind Life Came to be Known
abstract: Learn how Sam created “The largest resource for assistive technology information on the Internet” and his goal to help everyone live their BEST BLIND LIFE!
description: One day, an unemployed Sam Seavey was looking for some way to occupy his time. Having had some experience making videos for YouTube, he decided to create a new channel dedicated to sharing his life living with vision loss. So, in December of 2013, “The Blind Life” was born! Since then, Sam has turned his hobby of making videos into a growing business, which some have labeled “The largest resource for assistive technology information on the Internet”! With over 50,000 subscribers and almost 800 informative videos, Sam helps people worldwide living with vision loss, offers tips for managing daily tasks, reviews assistive devices, and hosts informative interviews with key stakeholders in the visually impaired community. Featured in USA TODAY, WIRED Magazine, and numerous national and international podcasts on assistive technology, he collaborates with tech giants like Google, SONY, and Amazon. Whether working one-on-one with clients or through his YouTube videos, Sam’s goal is to help everyone live their BEST BLIND LIFE!

name: Creating an Accessibility Machine for 220 Million Users
abstract: In this session we'll talk about implementing a11y processes into large companies, how to create an environment that allows products to be accessible by design. We’ll demonstrate what it takes to allow anyone to create accessible websites, at scale.
description:
Wix is a large website-building company with over 220 million users and over 6000 employees. The Wix website builder offers a complete solution from enterprise-grade infrastructure and business features to advanced SEO and marketing tools, enabling anyone to create and grow online. We provide our users with all the tools and functionality to create high-level, accessible websites, from accessible templates, presets, to tools to audit their own sites for accessibility issues.

With so many users making such a big impact on the internet (~5% of all websites online), we are faced with great challenges, responsibilities, and opportunities in our mission to impact and improve the accessibility level of the internet. An accessibility issue with one Wix product actually affects millions of sites, but when we fix an issue we improve the accessibility of millions of sites at once. This is one of our greatest strengths as a platform and something that has a huge, immediate impact.

While we can provide accessible components and frameworks, we can’t actually control what our users do with them Accessibility isn’t accessible - WCAG is complicated and hard to understand, so it’s even harder to explain it to both our users and our employees Challenge of scaling - Making only one site accessible isn’t a solution.

name: Partners Across Campus Launch Accessibility Training Academy
abstract: One size of accessibility training cannot fit all. But is creating specialized trainings worth the research and effort? Cross-campus collaboration makes it possible. Learn how Kent State University created the Equal Access Academy.
description:
Deciding how (and with what materials!) to teach accessibility compliance and concepts to your enterprise’s employees is a daunting prospect. Evaluating the worth and compatibility of existing trainings can seem to take as long as starting from scratch. Free, open-source trainings are rarely available for all employee roles in your specific industry. But how can you create trainings when you don’t feel like a subject matter expert? And when are you supposed to do this work? You’re completely overwhelmed with EXISTING compliance efforts. 
Accessibility training is a key example of an initial outlay of time and energy paying off dividends in the future; and it’s possible when you collaborate with others at your company or school who are already communicating with and training their teams and clients. We’ll present how the Digital Accessibility team and Student Accessibility Services at Kent State University sought out campus partners and launched 12 reimagined or new trainings in one semester. We’ll share our strategy on how and with whom we made those connections and wrote those trainings. A huge part of our success has been strategic branding and marketing – and we’ll explain our entire process. Learn to create quality trainings and deliverables based on quality information at a scale that is possible at your workplace.

name: Accessibility CoE - The Minimalist Approach
abstract: The session explains how the Accessibility CoE can standardize measuring and tracking compliance and establish a robust program - partnering with sales, vendors, and product teams in design, development, and compliance (VPATs, ACRs) risk management.
description:
In calm water, every ship has a good captain. But to sustain itself in turbulent times, it requires a prepared one. Over the past few years, many technology enterprises have understood the importance of Accessibility, and have been focused on developing a Centre of Excellence internally.  The rise in executive roles like CAO and Global Head of Accessibility in larger enterprises is a testament to the same. However, today’s products and services are increasingly complex. As that trend continues, Accessibility CoE needs to scale up the effort to provide more accessible ways to support key stakeholder teams like Legal, Sales, Product, and Procurement without impacting the budget and operational responsibilities.

Accessibility CoE is the captain of the Accessibility ship in such organizations. It needs a standard and robust approach to ensure that its expertise in Accessibility research, design, engineering, program management, and assistive technologies, works effectively across the company to help teams build accessibility expertise, understand user needs and create great experiences that are inclusive products and easier for everyone to use. An approach we would like to call - "Minimalist", marked by clarity, purpose, and execution.

The session would focus on elaborating different steps - team organization, request handling, and metrics collection of the Minimalist approach to ensure a steady rhythm of reporting and communications to manage Accessibility programs at scale.

name: When Is Being Disruptive a Good Thing?
abstract: In this session, we’ll explore how brands are disrupting the accessibility landscape through strong product and service fundamentals, which disruptive trends will shape the future, and how brands should deliver a more inclusive experience.
description: People find meaning when they make progress in what they’re working to achieve. But for many, meaning and progress can be lost in experiences that are not accessible. That’s why today’s most compelling brands build connections through strong product and service fundamentals that solve real customer needs, are constantly advancing, and are unquestionably accessible—establishing personal connections by telling stories that tap into a customer’s sense of identity and connecting them to something bigger. Join us in a discussion about which brands are disrupting the accessibility landscape, which disruptive trends will be shaping the future, and how brands should be delivering a more inclusive experience.

name: Designing Section 508-Compliant eLearning Microlearnings
abstract: eLearning course designers/developers often create text-only, click-next microlearning to just meet Section 508 requirements. This session discusses high-level steps for creating exciting accessible courses using any eLearning platform.
description:
Accessibility shouldn’t be a process or design decision that is added after the fact. It is often easier to bake in accessible authoring practices in place of remediating to remove access barriers. eLearning, like any other form of online content, needs to be available to people with disabilities. All too often, when course designers and developers attempt to meet accessibility standards, the result is text-only, click-next eLearning that doesn’t embrace the level of engagement made possible by using today’s eLearning rapid development tools. 

The purpose of this session is to present a category-by-category, high-level approach for crafting interactive and accessible gamified eLearning and microlearning for popular rapid authoring software. While the guidance presented will be tool specific, the strategic and technical eLearning authoring approaches can be applied to any authoring process and tool. The session will discuss accessibility requirements for common eLearning interactive elements. This session will discuss using a rapid authoring eLearning development tool (mainly Articulate 360’s Storyline) to develop eLearning microlearning that will both comply with accessibility guidelines and actively engage learners. This presentation will cover two main aspects of accessible eLearning authoring practices: (1) procedural steps to ensure accessibility; and (2) technical Storyline specific guidance.

name: Designing Engaging and Inclusive Learning Experiences
abstract: Learning and Development is more important than ever before. When training isn’t accessible or isn’t designed in away that is conducive to the various ways people learn, it can create a deficit in their ability to understand and retain information.
description:
An organization’s learning and development strategy is more important than ever before. Employees not only

participate in mandatory trainings, such as information security and creating a respectful workplace, but they also

rely upon role-based training to succeed in their current position and advance their career. When training is not

accessible or is not designed in a way that is conducive to the various ways people learn, it can create a deficit in

their learning experience and ability to understand and retain information.

Everyone has a learning style that aids in their ability to understand, apply, and retain the information being

presented.

There are four types of learning styles:

· Visual

· Auditory

· Kinesthetic

· Read/Write

These learning styles develop organically at a very young age and are just as unique as the learner themselves. It is

important to create training material that provides opportunities for each style of learner to experience the training

information in their preferred method.

When developing training, we need to not only keep in mind the different styles of learning, but also how to ensure

all content, multimedia, and exercises created are accessible to all learners, regardless of their abilities. The first step

is understanding how learners will be interacting with the content, what different types of assistive technologies may

be used, and what limitations may exist in the platform or LMS the training will be presented in.

name: Intro to the new Microsoft Adaptive Accessories
abstract: Learn about the new adaptive mouse, hub, and buttons from Microsoft.
description:
The new Microsoft adaptive accessories provide a highly adaptable, easy-to-use system. Each piece is designed in partnership with the disability community to empower people who may have difficulty using a traditional mouse and keyboard to create their ideal setup and increase productivity. The Microsoft adaptive accessories have three main components that empower you to configure, 3D print, and customize your own mouse, keyboard inputs, and shortcuts in ways that work best for your specific needs.

This session will introduce each of the adaptive accessories and will demonstrate the nearly unlimited opportunities to customize physical access to PCs and mobile devices.

name: Empathic Talk With the Visually Impaired in Design Thinking
description: This study found that engineering student researchers had a lack of empathic communication skills for Design Thinking. Engineering programs should be adequately amended to train and produce engineers who are equipped with empathy.

name: User Testing for Digital Products
abstract: Learn about how to co-create with the disabled community, how to embed user testing into product development and ultimately, how to create experiences that delight assistive technology users.
description:
When we think of accessibility, we often think of accessibility standards and compliance. But what’s more important is how different users can use your product or service and if they find delight in using your product. That’s a wide spectrum of user needs and assistive technologies! 

In this session, using examples of past experiments, we’ll go through how to co-create with the disabled community, identify user needs and recruit users in a sustainable way. We’ll learn how to research digital experiences in smart devices (beyond websites) and when to work with different assistive technology users. Lastly, we’ll identify the different points within product development when user testing can be valuable and how to approach it.

name: Tailoring Accommodations to the Individual
abstract: Has your DSPS program begun to lose its way? Do you feel like you are sacrificing maximum student outcomes for the sake of raw efficiency? If so, join our session and learn how to reclaim your purpose by adhering to three simple guidelines.
description:
This session is targeted at DSPS programs in higher education. Our premise is that such programs may be sacrificing maximum student outcomes for the sake of program efficiency.

The goal of this presentation is to reacquaint professionals with the value of meeting with students on an individual level in order to best determine their needs and help them achieve their goals. Our aim is to encourage intake appointments, live training sessions, and follow-up assessments rather than relying on automated systems or tutorial videos that allow such encounters to become secondary. We also want to encourage programs to apply unique rather than one-size-fits-all solutions -- a concept that can work alongside, rather than instead of, Universal Design. Examples involving assistive technology and alternate media services (the presenters' fields of expertise) will serve as proxies for services in general.

Overall, this session is meant to motivate DSPS staff to work more closely with the students we serve, and to remind us of why we do what we do. It will be designed to promote discussion, share ideas, and spark innovation. It's about thinking outside of the box by going back to our roots.

name: Community-Centered Accessibility & Disability Inclusion
abstract: Come to learn about new web applications that promote accessibility within communities and activities that help novice accessibility professionals grow their skills.  We will discuss opportunities to expand accessibility skills by participating.
description:
Most accessibility efforts focus on large organizations but people with disabilities often interact with small or medium businesses, non-profits, and community organizations. These organizations need help improving the accessibility of their facilities, websites, social media, events, and more. Accessible Community’s mission focuses on helping:
●	small-to-medium size organizations become accessible and
●	people with disabilities find accessible and disability support organizations within their communities.
At the same time, this all-volunteer non-profit helps accessibility experts grow their experience and connections.
 We achieve these complementary goals through following efforts:
•	Ta11y.org - a web application that guides novices through accessibility evaluations,
•	Loca11y.org -a web application that helps people with disabilities find accessible organizations in their communities,
•	The Accessibility Mentoring Program that connects novice and experienced accessibility experts, and
•	Virtual communities that share resources and ideas on in specific topics relating to accessibility. 
During this talk you will learn about these activities and how you can participate in each.

name: Dev, Browser, or AT: Debugging Web Accessibility Issues
abstract: CGI will share tips for debugging web accessibility issues. We will outline steps for determining if an issue is caused by a developer, third-party framework, browser, or AT error and then explain how this analysis guides the remediation approach.
description:
CGI will detail the steps we take to perform root cause analysis for a web accessibility issue to determine if the issue is due to a developer, framework, browser, or assistive technology (AT) error. Some of the steps we will discuss include:
- Examine the code to determine whether or not it was coded correctly (developer issue)
- If the code is correct, check to see if the code comes from a third-party development framework being used and is present in the default/"out-of-the-box" version of the component within the third-party framework (framework issue)
- Check the Accessibility API and Accessibility Tree to see if the information is present and mapped correctly (browser issue)
- Research to see if the browser has support for the code (browser issue)
- Check to see if the browser has any open defects for the lack of support as a reference point to see if they're aware of it, it's being tracked, and if there's any movement on the ticket to get an idea if they have plans to fix it (browser issue)
- Launch the AT and test different browser/AT combinations and see if the expected results are announced (potential AT issue)
- If the results are not as expected, search the AT's Github repository to see if there are any open defects for the issue (potential AT issue)

We will wrap-up by explaining the next steps for addressing an issue based on the results of your root cause analysis (i.e. who is responsible for fixing the bug, how it should ultimately be reported, etc.).

name: Building a Comprehensive Digital Accessibility Program
abstract: Building a digital accessibility program means juggling priorities including training, remediation planning, procurement management, and policy development. Learn strategies to develop your DA office. Focus is on higher ed but broadly applicable.
description:
Building a comprehensive digital accessibility program means juggling a lot of priorities including employee hiring and training, remediation planning, procurement management, and policy development. Knowing where to start, especially in a decentralized organization, can be daunting.

In this presentation we will share our story: the first year of our Digital Accessibility Office at Carnegie Mellon University. See our roadmap and learn from the outcomes of our efforts in awareness and outreach, training and professional development, and process and policy improvement. Get strategies for prioritization, risk management, engaging senior leadership, and developing advocates across the organization. 

The presentation focus will be on higher education institutions, but the information will be applicable to anyone starting a digital accessibility program.

name: Accessibility as a Driver of Innovation in Hospitality
abstract: Guided by 100 years of purpose to fill the earth with the light and warmth of hospitality, Hilton is diverse by nature and inclusive by choice. Learn how accessibility drives our innovation and supports the guests and team members we serve globally.
description:
Hilton is a leading global hospitality company with a portfolio of 18 world-class brands comprising 7,000 properties and 1.1 million rooms, in 122 countries and territories and an award-winning Hilton Honors guest loyalty program with more than 139 million members. In 2022, Hilton was recognized as a Best Place to Work for Disability Inclusion in the United States by Disability:IN and The American Association of People with Disabilities (AAPD). 

At Hilton we leverage technology to create distinctive, high-quality, frictionless, and inclusive guest experiences. Accessibility innovation is one of those key differentiators driving delivery of customer value. Accessibility is integrated into every facet of our digital technology development. Our strategic partnerships throughout the enterprise helps us champion for and advance the understanding of the intersectionality between accessible technology and workplace disability inclusion. 

This presentation will highlight Hilton's Accessibility Center of Excellence and offer practical strategies for evolving the reach of an accessibility program. We will describe the innovation, agility, and approaches that have enabled a small team to advocate for people with disabilities and ensure our travel experiences are usable by, inclusive of, and delightful to everyone.

name: Big Picture: All Roads Lead Back to Workplace Accessibility
abstract: Trying to improve accessibility in a small business? Learn from the mistakes of a CEO who re-engineered his company to build more accessible software but figured out that the real opportunity lies in building accessible workplaces.
description:
If you’re here, you probably already believe in moving past compliance culture and improving accessibility through commitment culture.

But what does that look like in a small business? And if Step One was “declare your commitment,” then… what’s Step Two? And how do you keep up the momentum?

I can’t answer that for you, but I can tell you what I tried and where I failed in Year 2 of Olark’s accessibility journey. I’ll share which tactics made it easy to stay on track with our goals, which made it harder, and what I learned in the process. I’ll also answer the ultimate question: how can small businesses improve accessibility and grow at the same time?

Specifically, I’ll discuss how becoming a B-Corp cemented our commitment to accessibility and how engineering a11y values into our organizational structure provided sustained focus. I’ll explain how working on accessibility features in the absence of motivated feedback from paying customers was counterproductive, how economic realities gave us a wake-up call, and why at the end of the day, all roads lead back to the importance of improving workplace access.

Above all, I’ll talk about my most important advice to small business leaders who care about digital accessibility: 1) align your business incentives with accessibility goals, and 2) focus on making your like-minded customers successful.

name: Replacing an Accessible Website: Ensuring a Better New Site
abstract: If you've already made your enterprise website accessible, but it’s due for an upgrade, how do you make sure you’re moving forward on accessibility? We faced this challenge in our web redesign project; we'll share what we did and what we learned.
description:
In early 2020, California State University, Northridge (CSUN) undertook a redesign and upgrade of our enterprise or administrative web presence. CSUN, as you might imagine, has a long-term investment in the accessibility of our official website. The challenge became to finish the project with a new web presence that is at least as accessible as the one it replaced.
CSUN has the Universal Design Center (UDC), a team dedicated to the CSU's Accessible Technology Initiative (ATI). The UDC partnered with the project co-sponsors and their vendors on the accessibility requirements for this project.
In this session, UDC team members will explain our approach to this project, the steps we took to ensure the new web presence was accessible, and lessons learned.
Accessibility is a shared commitment as CSUN, and the project sponsors included it as a requirement beginning with the vendor selection process. Still, garnering explicit executive support was a critical first step. Throughout the project, we advocated for accessibility in planning and goal-setting.
The UDC team gave feedback on early designs, tested prototypes, then tested pre-production pages. We'll describe our testing methodologies in detail.
Training editors is vital so that content meets accessibility guidelines. We'll address the training hand-off from the vendor to the UDC team. 
No project is perfect. Finally, we'll talk about things we might have approached differently, and what we learned from this project.

name: Michigan AT Guidelines for Teachers of Students Blind and VI
abstract: Looking for a method to assess, create electronic portfolios, and generate IEP goals and objectives for your student’s technology skill development? Does your student have a visual impairment? Come and learn how these PreK-12 guidelines can help.
description:
The Michigan Assistive Technology (AT) Guidelines are based on the International Society for Technology in Education (ISTE) Standards, to which the Michigan Integrated Technology Competencies for Students (MITECS) connect will be demonstrated. The AT Guidelines incorporate six key concepts incorporating adaptive devices or accessible tools specifically for students who are visually impaired or blind with or without other areas of disabilities. 
Technology Operations and Concepts.
Creativity and Innovation.
Communication and Collaboration
Critical Thinking and Problem Solving.
Research and Information Technology.
Digital Citizenship.
The AT Guidelines are designed to assist and guide educators’ decisions with students’ assistive technology skills, AT devices, data collection, individualized educational programming (IEPs), resources (i.e., apps, websites, and companies), and professional development. Teachers may use these AT Guidelines to develop specific IEP goals and objectives, develop lesson plans, and provide documentation for reporting technology skill development from PreK through 12th grade. 
Each AT Guideline has the following: 
Students’ skills to perform with suggested teaching activities.
A checklist to track students' progress.
A tool and application sample listing.
A tool record-keeping chart to list items in the student’s toolkit.
AT Glossary. 
AT Resources.
The Assistive Apps resource which supports a teacher's technology curriculum will be demonstrated.

name: Centralization: The Key to Scaling Video Accessibility
abstract: In this session, we will discuss how to achieve centralization and the positive impact centralization has on scaling video accessibility efforts in enterprise-level organizations.
description:
Enterprise organizations face unique challenges when implementing video accessibility processes at scale. Centralization is the key to successfully baking accessibility practices into all stages of the video creation process and scaling these processes to ensure sustainability over time.
 
This session will discuss how to achieve centralization at your organization and reap the benefits of scaling accessibility efforts – whether your primary focus is building a foundation for accessibility or improving existing production workflows – at the enterprise level.

abstract: SiteLint is a next-generation tool for automatically auditing sites for accessibility, combining real-time analytics with  organising the remediation process. We will demo the tool and provide insights into how it was built.

name: Quantifying Accessibility Success at VMware
abstract: In this talk, I will motivate and demonstrate how attendees can create successful large-scale data-driven metrics based on WCAG Success Criterion across large organizations.
description:
Large organizations need to quickly and easily track accessibility across all products and services. How do you standardize and measure accessibility across an organization? What data links to WCAG can companies quantify? How can product owners easily understand which issues have the highest priority? 

In February 2021, from what started as a response to product owners' frustrations, I created the VMware Accessibility Successes (VASes). Now, in 2023, this has proved to be a data-driven foundation for:
- creating a baseline for success measures aligning to WCAG 2.1.
- scoring metrics in line with existing ticketing workflow practices, allowing product managers to prioritize bugs easily and remediate products quickly.
- a product dashboard where senior leadership can track progress.
- creating a score that not only recognizes areas products can improve but also recognizes their success.

Join this exploration into how data-driven metrics were born at VMware and learn how you can use a similar approach for your organization.

name: Improving the Accessibility of Math for Middle Schoolers
abstract: We used AI to analyze online math test patterns and identified barriers for BVI students. Learn about our research, the resulting prototypes and their reception; and the continued work to create navigable equations for multiple AT devices and inputs.
description: For over 540k BVI students in the US, math instruction and assessment, especially online, can pose barriers with significant impact – 75 percent are at least one grade behind their peers in math. A major barrier is the lack of an adequate, two-way method for getting math equations to and from a refreshable braille display. NWEA, a research and educational services nonprofit, in collaboration with Perkins Access, is making middle school math assessments more accessible for BVI students using AI. With AI data analysis, patterns in online math tests and their barriers have been identified in this project, which was awarded a grant by Microsoft’s AI for Accessibility program. Prototype math questions that address the identified barriers were created to meet accommodation needs that otherwise would exclude students with disabilities from higher-level mathematics as well as paths to advanced degrees and STEM-related careers. Process-driven math was integrated into the prototype to simplify the landscape of complex algebraic expressions and reduce the cognitive load on working memory. Equation prototypes were developed to allow screen reader users to select various parts of a mathematics equation and drill into the parts they want to explore. Learn about the revolutionary research, prototypes, their reception by students and teachers and the continued effort to create efficient, navigable math equations for multiple AT devices and inputs, including Nemeth, UEB and voice.

name: How to Make the Hiring Process Inclusive
abstract: Inclusive hiring- Use inclusive language in job descriptions, expand recruiting to include people with disabilities, make interview process welcoming, collaborate with third party recruiters and set up a foundation of success at the internship level.
description:
A global survey by Monster.com found that inclusion in the workplace is important to 86% of candidates worldwide. Furthermore, their research showed that 62% of people would even turn down a job offer if the organization didn’t support an inclusive culture

The purpose of the “How to Make the Hiring Process Inclusive” session is to spread awareness of how to make the hiring process more inclusive.
Some key things that can be done in order to ensure this are -

1. Inclusive Job Descriptions - Be sure to have one that speaks to diverse applicants while being specific about the skillset. Do not include terms or content specific to gender, background, disability or status. Lay the groundwork for a more inclusive workspace.
2. Where to recruit/who should do the recruiting - Ensuring there is diversity in the panelists that conduct the interview. Also, educating panelists to counter “just like me” bias. 
3. The interview process should select questions that focus on talent and not abilities. 
4. Offer internships and coops to targeted groups of people. This is a great way to encourage candidates to join the team and ensure diversity.
5. Partner with third party organizations who can help find talent from diverse groups and ensure that we offer opportunities to all, irrespective of their background, race, gender, disability.
6. Last but not the least, organically create an employer brand that values opinions from ALL. Establish company values that promote inclusion and diversity.

name: Disability Staff Evaluation by Students
abstract: Imagine students evaluating disability staff. Learn the benefits of student evaluation and how to effectively gather and leverage their perspectives.
description: Across most U.S. college campuses, student evaluation of faculty is done every semester for every course taught.  This is vital for evaluating faculty for promotion and tenure.  However, the same student evaluation process is not used for staff of disability centers. These staff are evaluated only by their disability center directors.  Once a year, some registered students with disabilities at many universities provide feedback in satisfaction surveys that include their general assessment of disability center services.  Unfortunately, this disability center feedback does not include student satisfaction with the disability staff member who was assigned to assist them.  Relevant data from one large university disability center (which registers thousands of students) were analyzed in ongoing student surveys.  In addition to an assessment of student satisfaction with specific staff, the analysis of the surveys provides direct feedback on whether the student’s expressed disability needs were met.   The surveys had linked information which included: student enrollment status (e.g., full-time status), demographic variables (e.g., gender), academic variables (e.g., major), and center variables (e.g., the general reason for the meeting with the staff member).  Overall, a detailed evaluation of disability center staff by the students they assist is clearly necessary to accurately assess the overall quality and effectiveness of individual service providers.

name: Digital Accessibility in FinTech World
abstract: This presentation will describe the requirements, challenges, business value, awareness, transition process, accessibility strategy, and implementation in large financial companies.
description:
Digital accessibility is essential to include people with disabilities in our digital world. This is part of human rights and also, it is a law. But, is it enough to force large financial firms to consider the accessibility of their products? Financial inclusion is an often-overlooked component of development policy, and this is especially true when it comes to people with disabilities. But with disabled people representing a market possibly worth $1 trillion, the financial-services sector has every reason to take the lead on the issue. As per the World Bank data, 15% of the world’s population (Almost 1 billion people), experience some form of disability. And to ensure that they can use your products, it is imperative for large organizations to consider digital accessibility in their products. 
Indeed, there are many challenges to executing the accessibility policy in the Fintech firms, which include the lack of awareness of accessibility, custom requirements, and complex products.
This presentation gives the overall scenario of the challenges and a glimpse of the roadmap for accessibility strategy in financial organizations.

name: Accessibility Considerations for Security in Digital Banking
abstract: This session discusses accessibility considerations for low vision users in security for digital banking. JP Morgan Chase’s digital identity and authentication team explores crafting optimally secure experiences for users with disabilities.
description: The domain for fraud has greatly expanded, as more banking activities migrate into digital spaces. Thus, security is a vital element of digital banking for every customer journey. At JPMorgan Chase, we aim to implement identity verification and authentication in ways that protect customers without reducing accessibility. This session examines low vision users’ experience with banking and proposes aspects of accessibility to consider for security in digital banking, based on prior research. We highlight the importance of labeling form fields, as well as specific supports for low vision users to complete their original banking task. When low vision users’ preference for digital channels in banking contexts is considered, this research highlights the importance of usability testing with blind and low vision users in building secure and accessible digital financial experiences.

name: Pitfalls of Machine Generated PDFs
abstract: Accountancy, sales, or invoicing systems can generate on-demand PDFs, but only a handful of tools create screen-reader friendly PDFs. You can't manually fix these files, but your organization can choose an export method that works for all.
description:
PDF files have been around longer than widespread use of the internet. Although some in the accessibility community treat PDFs as a "stepchild," technology advances suggest they are not going away and may even become more complex. HTML may rule supreme, but if a person wants to download and store a bunch of statements, they're usually going to prefer saving them as PDF files.
 Most accessibility professionals are familiar with PDFs created by people using desktop apps. These PDFs or their source documents can be fixed manually. But what do you do when a PDF is generated on demand? Think of every receipt, credit card, bank, sales, inventory, or invoicing statement you have ever downloaded. The method used to generate the PDFs matters. Many server-based tools can create PDFs, but the majority can't produce accessible PDFs even if the source HTML they are based on is accessible.
 In the meantime, PDFs have developed a bad reputation among many screen reader users because millions--if not trillions--of PDFs on the internet today are not accessible. If your organization allows people to generate PDFs on demand, the problem grows exponentially. 
 The speaker has been manually fixing PDFs for accessibility since 2006—about as long as PDF tags have existed. Now in the financial sector, he has worked with developer teams to improve accessibility of on-demand PDFs. He will review the history of PDFs, the PDF/UA standard, and some good and bad methods for creating machine generated PDFs.

name: Vision Rehabilitation Assistive Technology Interventions
abstract: This session will present the assistive technology evaluation process and technology interventions for people with vision loss as practiced at the Lighthouse Guild. Other relevant findings, challenges, and future implications will also be discussed.
description:
The Lighthouse Guild (LG) provides people with vision loss services to attain their goals through a comprehensive multidisciplinary approach. This includes a health care center providing medical services and vision rehabilitation. With the growth of assistive technology, LG opened a new technology center in March of 2022.

As reported by the National Eye Institute, it is anticipated that the number of people in the United States with visual impairment will double by the year 2050. As such, more attention is being given to assistive technology by the people who use it as well as developers and manufacturers. Whether the technology is low or high-tech, a mainstream or stand-alone device, its purpose is to provide individuals access to meet their goals and improve their quality of life. With the abundance of technology available and individualized goals, a proper assessment is advantageous versus an over-the-counter model, which diminishes the risk of technology abandonment. As practiced at Lighthouse Guild, this assessment includes an initial low vision examination with recommendations or referral from the individual's primary eye care provider, followed by an occupational therapy technology assessment, training on that specific technology, and follow-up as needed. Technologies available range from hardware to software, including apps.

This session will present the assistive technology evaluation process practiced at Lighthouse Guild.

name: Are Your Digital Ads Accessible?
abstract: Digital Ads often have significant accessibility gaps, including digital ads available on social media platforms. This presentation will demonstrate the steps required to ensure ads meet WCAG standards using a holistic process.
description:
We often focus on the accessibility of a website and forget about the digital ads that are being displayed on the site or digital ads that are created to drive traffic to the site.  These ads, including digital ads that are now available on Facebook, Twitter or other platforms often have significant accessibility gaps. 
This presentation will demonstrate the steps required to ensure Digital Ads meet WCAG standards using a holistic process from design to testing.  Both display ads and social media ads will be reviewed, as well as video ads which can present significant challenges as the content needs to be accessible to all user groups so must be captioned and sufficiently audio described.  
Finally, no holistic testing of digital ads would be complete without testing with assistive technology.  We will review tips to test the accessibility of digital ads with the JAWS screen reader as well as testing for keyboard access and how to overcome some of the accessibility limitations in popular platforms. 
Developing a better understanding of how the WCAG requirements apply to digital ads and how assistive technology users access your digital ads, ad creators can increase the accessibility of their ads and ensure that their messages are communicated to the widest possible audience.

name: Save Our World With Accessibility & Progressive Enhancement
abstract: Given that 98% of the top websites are not fully accessible and if the Internet was a country it would be the 7th largest polluter — we need better practices to save us. Progressive enhancement can serve accessible, sustainable web services.
description: This session will highlight how progressive enhancement serves not only accessibility and usability but sustainability through best practices for ensuring no one is excluded, regardless of their technology, and how following these practices also reduce your application's impact on the environment.

name: How We Weave Accessibility Into Our Product Process
abstract: In this session, we will explore how accessibility could be woven into each stage of the product development process from research to release, and how our commitment to accessibility at D2L helps us craft inclusive digital learning experiences.
description:
At D2L, we build educational experiences. To us, inclusive design means that we are mindful of the needs of all our users, particularly users with disabilities. Our goal is to ensure that no learner, instructor, or administrator gets left behind and the products that we build are accessible and enhance their experience. To successfully deliver accessible experiences, we bring that mindfulness to the entire product development lifecycle. 

I will share how accessibility is woven into our process in building digital products for education. This includes how we bring a variety of inputs at the various stages of our process from our clients to identify institutional needs, our internal SMEs, QA testing, and our end users through user research. While we recognize the WCAG as a powerful resource, we believe it is a baseline for us to approach our solutions and for us to build accessible experiences that meet our users' needs, we need all those inputs to get it right.  

Our process aims to go beyond usability and ensure that our products are positive experiences for those using them. From early conception of a product or feature to its delivery, we identify and learn what barriers are there around accessibility for our users and those insights shape our solution. We have a system to include users with disabilities anywhere in the process as needed. This approach ensures that accessibility is not a single stitch in our process but threaded throughout that lifecycle at each stage.

name: Reimagining Assistive Technology in the Classroom
abstract: The pandemic created unprecedented challenges in education. But it also provides a chance to dramatically change how we think about AT. We’ll discuss why reimagining AT can benefit how all students learn now – as well as throughout their lives.
description:
Addressing the pandemic’s consequences is ongoing. But one aspect from millions of students being forced to do everything online gives us a real opportunity: to rethink the definitions and roles of “assistive technology” in the classroom.

Even before the pandemic there were signs of change – districts were buying products traditionally used by students with disabilities for all their learners. The continued influence of universal design for learning, combined with unexpectedly having to use technology for most activities, added momentum.

The possibility of broadly integrating assistive technology without the need for traditional processes for every use case could have a major impact in education. In this session we will discuss the:

•  Market dynamics fueling his change
•  Types of products becoming more mainstream
•  Benefits of removing the stigma of using AT
•  Potential barriers from “old school” IEP and 504 thinking
•  Evolving expectations for digital educational materials
•  Imperative of ensuring those who need AT the most aren’t left further behind.

It is interesting to note that the newest cohort – dubbed “Generation Alpha” – will be the first born totally in the 21st century and will be in front of screens for so much of their lives that some are referring to them as “Generation Glass.” Given that future, it is critical that we reevaluate the role AT can play in supporting learning not just in school, but also for learning during the rest of their lives.

name: Accommodating Hidden Disabilities with AT
abstract: This session will examine workplace scenarios involving individuals with hidden disabilities across various industries, focusing on effective strategies and technologies. Cost and benefit data from an ongoing study will be provided as available.
description:
Hidden disabilities are medical conditions that are not noticeable or identifiable at first glance and may include autoimmune disorders, mental health conditions, and organ system dysfunction. Employers often question the value of accommodating employees with hidden disabilities.  
Employees with hidden disabilities who request accommodations should be treated with the same respect and due diligence as those with apparent disabilities. Approaching the interactive process objectively leads to effective accommodation outcomes by clarifying employee needs while maintaining employer requirements. 
While selecting accommodations, tools, and strategies that the individual has successfully and comfortably used previously may serve as a starting point, engaging resources to enhance the interactive process may generate additional options and optimize effective outcomes.  
Presenters will discuss case study examples that implement a range of mainstream and traditional assistive technologies as well as resources to assist with navigating the interactive process. Cost benefit data will be provided as available. 
Effective assistive technology (AT) accommodations benefit employees with hidden disabilities by promoting equity and inclusion while maximizing productivity, morale, and workplace safety. A robust interactive process allows consideration of a range of accommodation options and balances individual preferences with employer priorities to optimize effectiveness.

name: Remote Training Strategies for Employees with Disabilities
abstract: This session will provide best practices and real-world examples of how to maximize equal access for employees with disabilities who are now working remotely and need to engage in remote meetings and obtain remote training.
description:
Everyday work has shifted to a remote setting and employees with disabilities face unique challenges in receiving training, participating in meetings, communicating with colleagues and collaborating on team projects. Many employees with disabilities are finding the process to access remote meetings and the materials presented to be cumbersome and at times inaccessible.  Employers sometimes are uncertain of how to modify their processes to ensure all employees have equal access to all meetings.  Furthermore, specific challenges arise when an employee needs remote training on the Assistive Technology they use in the context of their work applications.  A variety of processes are needed to ensure the employee receives competent training and the AT trainer has sufficient remote access to the employee’s workstation.  

TCS Access’ Senior Assistive Technology Specialist, Ben Soto and Harris Rosensweig, Director of Accessibility will provide best practices and real-world examples of how to maximize equal access for employees with disabilities who are now working remotely and need to engage in remote meetings and obtain remote training. This webinar is ideal for those who manage reasonable accommodations or assistive technology services and employees with disabilities and assistive technology users.

name: Smart Living: A True Tech-First Model of Service Delivery
abstract: The way community-based services in the I/DD field has hit a crisis point.  With not enough funding for the growing population, and not enough staff to meet the need a new way of delivering services must be implemented.
description: For 3 years LADD's Smart Living program has been changing the way the I/DD system provides service.  Using a technology-first mindset, and backed by research through the OT program at Xavier University this model has shown tremendous success.  This session will detail what Smart Living is and present the research data on how this model both saves the system financially, but also increases the level of independence of the individuals at a high level. This model also allows to provide services to more individual with less staff to assist with staffing issues.

name: Keyboard Accessibility: Promoting Accessibility at the Library of Congress
abstract: If you are looking for a way to promote accessibility within your organization, come learn about the Year of Keyboard Accessibility at the Library of Congress. This presentation will provide detailed information to allow you to hold this outreach and
description:
In order to promote accessibility within the Library of Congress, the accessibility team provides internal outreach and training. A new initiative launched in October 2022. This year-long program centers on a single theme as a way of encouraging staff engagement and conversations around the topic.  

This year’s theme is the “Year of Keyboard Accessibility.” This includes:
•	Why supporting keyboard accessibility is a foundational part of overall accessibility, 
•	The importance of focus indicators and page order,
•	How to plan, design, build and test for keyboard accessibility, and
•	How assistive technologies rely on the keyboard focus.

 From October 2022 to September 2023, the team:
•	Holds fun activities and competitions to get people thinking about keyboard accessibility, 
•	Promotes tips and success stories in internal publications,
•	Updates and create new resources around keyboard accessibility, and
•	Provides trainings to improve staff skills in this area.

In this talk we will share the details of this effort to allow other organizations to host a similar activity.
